text: a right-sided central venous catheter terminates in the distal superior vena cava.there are expected postoperative changes of the patient's known ascending aorta and total arch replacement, with multiple mediastinal clips and sternotomy wires, but no evidence of leak.the ascending aortic lumen measures 28 mm at the level of the main and left pulmonary arteries.there is no evidence of leak.a graft which connects the left common carotid artery to the right brachiocephalic artery is widely patent.the right common carotid artery is also patent.there is occlusion of the left subclavian artery near its origin, with presumed retrograde filling by the left vertebral artery.there is predominantly low-attenuation fluid surrounding the ascending thoracic aorta which measures 73 mm in greatest diameter.this fluid extends into the pericardium.there is a small slightly higher- attenuating focus anterior to the left pulmonary artery (3, 48) which measures 33 x 21 mm, likely representing a post-surgical hematoma.the central pulmonary arteries are patent.an aortic valve prosthesis is noted.bilateral low-attenuation pleural effusions are present, large on the left and small on the right, the left of which is loculated and associated with moderate atelectasis.
summary: expected postoperative changes of the thorax, as detailed above, without evidence of residual ascending aortic aneurysm, leak or graft occlusion.the low-attenuation fluid in the mediastinum is postoperative in etiology, as is a small presumed mediastinal hematoma anterior to the left pulmonary artery.bilateral pleural effusions, the left of which is large and loculated.no significant interval change in the appearance of an aortic dissection which extends from the distal arch into the left common iliac artery.these findings were conveyed to dr.___ ___ by ___ ___ at 5 p.m.on ___.

text: there are no filling defects in pulmonary arterial vasculature.no pulmonary embolism.again seen is a calcification in the right coronary artery.there is a small to moderate pericardial effusion.compared to the study of 7 hours prior, the left pleural effusion and associated atelectasis has increased.again seen is an infiltrate in the left lower lobe as well as in the lower portion of the left upper lobe.there is a rounded infiltrate versus pulmonary mass in the apical portion of the right lower lobe.this is worrisome for a mass, however, an infiltrate could also have this appearance, and follow up is recommended after treatment.
summary: no pulmonary embolism.worsening left pleural effusion and atelectasis.interval increase in size of pericardial effusion, from trace fluid to now small.

text: due to the required slow injection of contrast, the study is limited for evaluation of pulmonary emboli.however, there is no evidence of central or main pulmonary artery embolus.the aorta is densely calcified.a right vascular stent is partially imaged.there is dense three-vessel carotid artery disease.dense consolidation involves the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe.bibasilar ground-glass opacities are not well evaluated due to significant motion artifact.septal thickening and small bilateral effusions are consistent with pulmonary edema.there is no pericardial effusion.the central airways are patent to the subsegmental level.mediastinal lymphadenopathy is identified, with multiple pretracheal lymph nodes, the largest measuring up to 16 mm in short axis.the central venous catheter terminates in the superior aspect of the superior vena cava.
summary: no central pulmonary embolus.bilateral lower lobe opacities, with dense consolidation opacification of the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe, concerning for pneumonia.pulmonary edema with effusions.severe vascular calcifications.2.2 cm right groin pseudoaneurysm at the confluence of the aorto- femoral graft and native artery.indeterminant 4.4 cm left adrenal mass.this can be further evaluated with an adrenal protocol ct on a non-emergent basis.mediastinal lymphadenopathy.findings #5 and 6 were entered into the radiology critical results reporting system on ___.

text: there has been interval development of widespread ground-glass opacities throughout the lungs bilaterally as well as diffuse intralobular septal thickening.there are also new small bilateral pleural effusions.there is new left greater than right dependent lower lobe consolidation.there is progressive lingular consolidation as well.note that in the region of this lingular consolidation there is an abrupt cutoff of a pulmonary artery supplying the lingula.this does not have the appearance of a pulmonary embolism but rather invasion or severe narrowing of the artery by this process.there is stable emphysema at the right greater than left lung apices.the endotracheal tube is low lying with tip in the proximal most right mainstem bronchus.there are some confluent enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes which are unchanged.
summary: interval development of diffuse widespread ground-glass opacities and interlobular septal thickening.there are also small bilateral pleural effusions.these constellations of findings are suggestive of chf or volume overload.less likely these findings could be related to leukemic infiltration or atypical infection.progression of persistent lingular consolidation which notably causes encasement and obliteration of a pulmonary artery branch.therefore this is favored to represent either an aggressive infection, (an atypical ___ such as fungus could be considered) or malignancy such as a focal leukemic infiltrate.left greater than right bibasilar consolidation could also be infectious in nature.low lying endotracheal tube in the proximal right main stem bronchus.proximal repositioning recommended.emphysema.progression of the splenic and bilateral renal infarcts.hepatosplenomegaly.ill-defined liver hypodensities in the left and right hepatic lobes as described.these are of unclear etiology but could be related to the additional sites of infarction or leukemic infiltration.slightly increased free fluid in the pelvis.these findings were related with dr.___ at 7:18 on ___ by dr.___.

text: bilateral basal segmental and subsegmental pulmonary emboli are seen.there are large bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis on the right and compressive collapse in the left.the aerated lung fields demonstrate large bilateral multifocal peripheral opacities, which may represent aspiration, infection or infarct.emphysematous changes are seen.there is no pneumothorax.there is no evidence for right heart strain.the pulmonary arteries are enlarged.note is made of aortic, coronary artery and aortic valve calcifications.a 1.2 cm precarinal lymph node is likely reactive.few additional mediastinal lymph nodes do not meet criteria for pathologic enlargement.a central line terminates in the superior vena cava.an endotracheal tube terminates above the carina.a nasogastric tube terminates in the stomach.

text: central airways are patent to subsegmental levels bilaterally.there is no pneumothorax.the lungs are notable for dependent atelectasis.small subpleural opacity is visualized in the left upper lobe (2:31) with similar smaller opacities in a subpleural location visualized more cranially in the left upper lobe (2:22, 21).laterally, at the junction of the right lower and upper lobes is an area of subpleural nodularity (2:27), possibly the sequela of remote rib trauma at an adjacent site.the heart and great vessels reveal atherosclerotic calcification of the coronary arteries and are otherwise unremarkable.there is no mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy.incidental note is made of a small focus of subcutaneous gas in the included portion of the proximal right arm (2:14).
summary: multiple acute and chronic rib fractures and two vertebral fractures as above.the acute fractures are at the bilateral first ribs and right 2nd, 4th, and 5th ribs.liver hypodensity.in the setting of vertebral body chance fracture, this may represent a laceration (probably grade 3), though, given the adjacent surgical clips and lack of perihepatic fluid, other consideration includes post-operative sequelae.right posterior flank hernia (likely ___ hernia).this is age- indeterminate but may be an acute traumatic sequela.small focus of gas in the right arm.please correlate to possible right upper are injury.right fluid collection overlying the iliac crest.this is non-specific with broad considerations included a seroma, hematoma, or abscess.not typical of an acute traumatic injury.

text: an endotracheal tube terminates in a standard position above the carina.there is a right ij introducer sheath, which terminates in the upper svc.there are no filling defects within the central and segmental pulmonary arterial branches to suggest pulmonary embolus.evaluation of subsegmental branches for pulmonary embolus is limited due to contrast bolus and airspace consolidation.the thoracic aorta is of normal caliber without evidence for dissection or aneurysmal dilatation.the heart size is normal.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes are seen.the lungs demonstrate severe diffuse posterior airspace consolidation with nodular ground-glass opacities throughout the perihilar regions and lung apices, consistent with aspiration.no pneumothorax is identified.there is no pericardial or pleural effusion.a small amount of subcutaneous air is noted within soft tissues of the upper left chest, likely iatrogenic.
summary: no evidence of central or segmental pulmonary embolus.evaluation for subsegmental emboli is limited due to contrast bolus and airspace consolidation.bilateral posterior airspace consolidation with associated perihilar ground- glass nodular opacities consistent with severe aspiration.periportal edema, severe gallbladder wall edema and perihepatic and mesenteric ascites likely secondary to volume overload from resuscitation.findings were relayed to the ed dashboard at 12:30 a.m.on ___ and marked for urgent attention.

text: the airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.there are no filling defects in the pulmonary arterial vasculature.no pulmonary embolism identified.there are no pericardial effusions.there are emphysematous changes in the lungs again seen.there are areas of small patchy peripheral consolidations; some of these are also nodular in appearance.no pleural effusions are seen.no pneumothorax.there is interstitial septal thickening again seen.
summary: no pulmonary embolism identified.small areas of peripheral patchy and nodular consolidations.

text: there is bilateral dependent atelectasis and bilateral pleural effusions.there are hazy nodular opacities within the right lung base, which could reflect aspiration or other pneumonitis.ng tube is in expected position.no mediastinal adenopathy.pulmonary arteries are normal in size.
summary: acute occlusion of aortobifemoral bypass graft.reconstitution through hypogastric collaterals with patent common femoral arteries.patent left sfa with single vessel runoff through the peroneal to the foot.occlusion of the right arterial system at the sfa/above-knee popliteal artery portion with minimal reconstitution of flow in the right lower extremity below this.normal appearing thoracic aorta, bilateral common carotid, and bilateral subclavian arteries.markedly thickened colonic wall after recent surgery.this raises question of ischemia, though infection or inflammation could give this picture.free air within the abdomen likely relates to prior surgery, though this is uncertain.apparent dilation of the pancreatic duct within the body and tail with pancreatic parenchymal atrophy likely reflects chronic pancreatitis, though this could be seen with an obstructing pancreatic mass.mrcp is recommended when the patient can tolerate.mottled perfusion of the kidneys bilaterally with patent renal arteries.this perfusion abnormality is nonspecific, but could be seen with hypoperfusion and less likely early embolic phenomenon.dr.___ ___ was informed of these findings on ___ in their entirety.the attending vascular surgeon was informed of the vascular findings at the time of the exam as well as the colonic thickening and kidneys on ___.

text: this study is technically limited in evaluation due to significant motion artifact as well as contrast bolus timing.however, evaluation of the pulmonary vasculature demonstrates no filling defects to suggest a central pulmonary embolus.the aorta is normal in caliber and contour.small foci of sub-segmental atelectasis are visualized bilaterally but no confluent opacities to suggest a pneumonia.the airways are patent to the subsegmental levels.there are no pleural effusions or pneumothoraces.there is no hilar, mediastinal, or axillary lymphadenopathy by ct size criteria.the heart and great vessels are within normal limits.an endotracheal tube is visualized with the tip in the mid trachea.a nasogastric tube is visualized with the tip in the stomach.

text: the lung windows reveal characteristic changes of radiation pneumonitis/evolving fibrosis in the right lung paramediaastinal region.the patient is status post right upper lobe resection in the interval.there is marked narrowing of the right middle lobe bronchus, which has an unusual course, likely due to postoperative and postradiation alteration in course.the segmental bronchi are not narrowed, but there is partial collapse of the medial segment of the right middle lobe.a tiny nodule is noted in the lateral segment of the right middle lobe which in retrospect is unchanged dating back to ___.this is seen on series 3 image 21.a second tiny nodule is identified on series 3 image 27 in the right lower lobe which is also unchanged from the prior study.a third tiny nodule is located in the left lower lobe is also unchanged dating back to ___ ___.there is stable apical scarring in the left lung.the soft tissue windows reveal a small anterior fluid component adjacent to the opacified lung segment in the superior right lower lobe.the previously identified precarinal lymph node is not visualized on the current study.a small fluid density collection in the precarinal region is continuous with the superior pericardial recess.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there is a small to moderate-sized right pleural effusion which is new from the prior study.in the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, the liver, gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands and kidneys are unremarkable.the osseous structures demonstrate a healing segmental fracture of the posterior 6th right rib.no associated blastic or lytic lesions are seen.a well circumscribed lucency is again noted in the right scapula is unchanged.

text: the study is limited by motion and bolus timing.no definite evidence for pulmonary embolism.the aorta and great vessels appear intact.there are coronary artery calcifications.there are scattered mediastinal lymph nodes, notably a 7-mm superior mediastinal node.there is a 12-mm right hilar node.there is no pericardial or pleural effusion.respiratory motion limits sensitivity for detection of pulmonary nodules.there is opacity in the left lower lobe with depression of the left major fissure consistent with atelectasis/collapse.there is also apparent atelectasis/collapse of the inferior segment of the lingula.there is linear opacity in the right lower lobe as well consistent with atelectasis.there are emphysematous changes of the lungs, mainly in a paraseptal distribution.limited images of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.bone windows reveal no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.

text: there are diffuse bilateral patchy foci of ground-glass densities scattered throughout both lungs.moderate bibasilar atelectasis is noted.moderate bilateral pleural effusion.no pericardial effusion is noted.pacemaker leads terminate in the right atrium and right ventricle.there is reflux of the administered contrast material into the ivc and hepatic veins.there is a large lipoma in the right axillary region measuring 3.3 x 9.1 cm.

text: the thyroid is slightly enlarged but homogeneous.there is scattered atelectasis.the lungs are otherwise clear without effusion, consolidation or pulmonary nodule.the airways and pulmonary arteries are patent to the subsegmental level.a small hiatal hernia is noted.a macrolobulated, homogeneously enhancing 4.5 x 1.5 cm mass in the anterior mediastinum (2:26) has no clear fat plane between the anterior left chest wall and left internal mammary vessels.there is a clear fat plane between the mass and the myocardium.there is no adjacent bony destruction.the mass has significantely increased from 2.5 x 1.4 cm on ___.scattered sub 6 mm mediastinal and hilar nodes are not enlarged by ct size criteria.the interatrial septum is fatty replaced.the heart is otherwise unremarkable without evidence of coronary atherosclerotic calcifications.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion or evidence of pleural nodularity/plaques.although this exam was not optimized for subdiaphragmatic diagnosis the imaged intra-abdominal organs are unremarkable except to note transverse colon diverticulosis without diverticulitis.bone windows demonstrate no lesion concerning for metastasis or infection.

text: examination is limited by patient motion.there is no central or segmental pulmonary embolus.the aorta is normal in caliber.there is no evidence of dissection.atherosclerotic calcifications are seen in the aortic root and arch.the heart size is normal.there is no pericardial effusion.the airways are patent to the segmental level bilaterally.there is minimal airspace opacity in the lung bases bilaterally, which most likely represent combination of pulmonary hydrostatic edema and dependent changes.there are few focal patchy opacities in the right middle and lower lobes.there are no pleural effusions.there is no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymph nodes; however, multiple prominent less than 10 mm lymph nodes are seen in the prevascular region of the mediastinum.limited images through the upper abdomen show unremarkable portions of the liver and spleen.there appears to be air within the gallbladder, which may be within stones.

text: the heart size is normal.calcifications are noted in the coronary arteries and of the aortic valve.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber throughout and shows minimal scattered atherosclerotic plaques with calcifications.there is no evidence of dissection.a right lower paratracheal lymph node measures 10 mm in short axis; other small mediastinal lymph nodes are also present, not meeting ct criteria for adenopathy.small lymph nodes are also noted in the axillae, measuring up to 9 mm in short axis bilaterally.increased collapsibility of the trachea during expiratory scan is suggestive of tracheomalacia.paraseptal emphysematous changes are noted.small foci of atelectasis are noted in the right lung.a 3-mm left lower lobe density located parallel to a vessel likely represents an impacted bronchus (3:38).no airspace consolidation, pulmonary nodule, or mass is demonstrated.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.note is made of a small hiatal hernia.

text: the central airways are patent to the segmental levels bilaterally.the heart and great vessels are normal in size.there is no filling defect within the pulmonary artery to suggest pulmonary embolism.bilateral mild-to-moderate loculated pleural effusions.there is also marked thickening of the pleura in the region of a large loculated left subpulmonic effusion, which could represent the patient's mesothelioma.fluid collection within the right major fissure is seen measuring 2.3 x 1.2 cm.post-radiation changes are seen in a paramediastinal distribution in both upper lungs.there is peribronchial thickening bilaterally, particularly on the left in the region of the left hilum.consolidation with air bronchogram involving the left lower lobe with diffuse ground-glass opacity and thickening of the interlobular septa is seen.6-mm noncalcified nodule in the right upper lobe (s2, i47) is seen.there is a small pericardial effusion.the visualized portions of the upper abdomen demonstrate a 1.8 x 1.5 cm enhancing lesion within the left lobe of the liver (s2, i107).osseous structures demonstrate no lucent or sclerotic lesions.

text: there is no pulmonary embolism.thoracic aorta is unchanged in appearance, ectatic and tortuous, measuring up to 3.7 x 3.6 cm in greatest axial dimension on current study.there is a stable appearance of a focal outpouching in the thoracic aorta along the descending aorta.findings may represent a pseudoaneurysm or ulcerative plaque though appearance is stable from ct dated ___.there is no aortic dissection.there is no lymphadenopathy within the chest.atherosclerotic calcification of the thoracic aorta, and coronary artery calcifications are unchanged.moderate cardiomegaly is unchanged.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.central bronchi are patent to the subsegmental level.there is moderate right basilar atelectasis.2 small nodular opacities in the right upper lobe are unchanged and measure 5mm (s3, images 15 and 18).severe biapical centrilobular and paraseptal emphysema is unchanged.limited views of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.

text: thyroid gland is asymmetric with the left lobe larger than the right, stable.numerous enlarged mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes, some of which are calcified (in the subcarinal and right hilar regions) compatible with post-treatment changes, are unchanged since ___ with the largest measuring about 1.7 cm in diameter in the right lower paratracheal station (2:17).multiple enlarged axillary lymph nodes with the largest measuring 2.5 x 1.2 cm on the left and 2.0 x 1.5 cm on the right (2:8) are grossly unchanged since ___.left moderate-sized non-hemorrhagic pleural effusion with associated adjacent atelectasis is grossly stable since prior exam.a subcarinal lymph node measuring 5.5 x 1.3 cm is stable.there is no pneumothorax.linear scarring-atelectasis in the right lower quadrant is stable (300b:45).a calcified granuloma in the left lower lobe (2:25) is stable.

text: the patient is status post ascending aortic replacement with valvular prosthesis and dense suture material about the descending aorta and arch, as well as multiple mediastinal clips.a moderate-sized fluid collection is present in the anterior mediastinum extending from approximately the level of the sternal notch, about the ascending aorta and within the anterior mediastinum to the sternotomy incision, where fluid is contiguous with the osteotomy defect.although a tiny focus of gas is present within the right sternoclavicular joint, this is likely due to vacuum effect, and no evidence of gas is seen elsewhere within the mediastinal collection.the mediastinal fluid appears contiguous with a large pericardial effusion which shows thin peripheral enhancement on the post-contrast images.there is no evidence of extravasation of contrast or of hematoma.the ascending aorta repair is normal in caliber and contour.slight focal prominence of the aortic arch just distal to the anastomotic site to 3.0 cm (4:13) is consistent with post-surgical change, and is decreased from the preoperative ct at which time the aortic arch measured 4.2 cm in a similar location.the sternotomy defect is dehiscent inferiorly, where the sternal halves are separated by 1.3 cm (4:41).although the orientation of the superior four sternotomy wires appears unchanged from immediate postoperative chest x-ray, at least three of the four inferior sternotomy wires are displaced laterally suggestive of dehiscence.there are large bilateral pleural effusions, left greater than right, and bilateral lower lobe atelectasis.no pneumothorax.
summary: large pericardial effusion and moderate-to-large mediastinal fluid collection with probable dehiscence of the sternotomy.in the setting of continued fevers, infection cannot be excluded and clinical correlation is recommended.large bilateral pleural effusions, left greater than right, and lower lobe atelectasis.tiny hypodense liver lesion too small to characterize and unchanged.the results were discussed with ___ ___ at 5 p.m.on ___.

text: views of the upper lungs are limited by patient breathing.again noted is a small nodule in the right upper lobe (series 3, image 13) that does not appear significantly changed from prior study.no new nodules are identified.there is no evidence of mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.heart and great vessels appear unremarkable.again seen is a small hiatal hernia.ct abdomen with & without iv contrast: the liver, gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, adrenals, and kidneys appear unremarkable.visualized loops of bowel appear within normal limits.no pathologically enlarged mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy is identified.there is no evidence of free air or free fluid within the abdomen.

text: no filling defect in pulmonary arterial branches suggestive of pulmonary embolism.lung window images demonstrate increase in bilateral lower lobe compressive atelectasis.there is also worsening of the previously described opacities in dependent portions of the upper, middle, and lower lobes bilaterally.pleural effusion has also increased in amount, now moderate on the left and large on the right.previously described subcentimeter subpleural nodules cannot be identified at present study, maybe obscured by the consolidation process.heart and great vessels are unremarkable.no enlarged mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes according to ct size criteria.evidence of anasarca of abdominal wall soft tissues.limited visualization of abdominal organs demonstrates presence of two biliary stents in place.again seen previously described heterogeneous hypodense hepatic lesion near the dome, and small amount of ascites.bone windows: previously described lucency within the left side of the vertebral body of l1, seems unchanged since study in ___.

text: the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.despite a large amount of prevertebral hematoma, secondary to fractures, the aorta appears intact.there is a fat plane between the aorta and hematoma.a chance fracture at t11 extends through the superior third of the t11 vertebral body into the right t11 pedicle and lamina and both t10 inferior articular facets.there is 8-mm of posterior displacement of t11 upon t10 with locked facets at that level.the spinous cord is markedly abnormal at that level and is likely transected.the left 10 transverse process and spinous process are fractured.the t8 and t9 spinous processes are fractured as are the t9 inferior articular facets.the c7 spinous process is fractured and displaced.there is no pneumothorax.there are lung contusions in the right periphery of the lung.the central airways are clear.scattered mediastinal lymph nodes are not enlarged.there is a chronic left mid clavicle fracture.there are right nondisplaced rib fractures involving the 5th-9th posterior ribs.there are left nondisplaced rib fx involving the 10th and 11th posterior ribs.
summary: chance fracture at t11 with posterior translation of t11 on t10 and locked facets at this level.high concern for spinal cord transection.multiple additional fractures as described.right lung contusions.high attenuation in the lumen of a rlq small bowel loop is of higher attenuation than the aorta and may related to ingested material.intraluminal hemorrhage secondary to small bowel injury would be less likely, but please clinically correlate.findings discussed with dr.___ at 8.30 am by dr.___ on ___.

text: there is evidence of a cabg with the heart mildly enlarged in size and severe calcifications of the native coronary arteries.the great vessels are normal in appearance, without evidence of pulmonary embolism or thoracic aortic dissection.central lymph nodes are borderline to mildly enlarged in size, measuring up to 11 mm in short axis.centrilobular emphysema is severe, with bibasilar atelectases.the lungs are otherwise clear.calcified pleural plaques bilaterally are related to prior asbestos exposure, without evidence of pulmonary fibrosis, pleural or pulmonary mass.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, with both adrenal glands normal in appearance.multilevel degenerative changes of the thoracic spine are noted.

text: there is no axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.coronary artery calcifications is again noted, particularly in the proximal lad.there is volume loss within the right lung and the previously seen pleural effusion has almost completely resolved.the pleural surface enhances, suggesting fibrosis, raising the question of whether this patient has had a pleurodesis.there is also an ovoid fluid collection with an enhancing rim in the right lower lung zone posteriorly which suggests a fibrosing hematoma or post pleurodesis collection.large right lower lung volume mass is difficult to compare to the previous exam, and definite size cannot be assessed due to post obstructive atelectatic component.it appears, however, that the mass is essentially unchanged.there is an 8 mm calcified nodule at the left lung base, unchanged since the previous exam.there is a new 0.7 cm soft tissue density nodule at the left lung base anteriorly, which is not definitely seen on the previous exam.several other small bilateral lung nodules are slightly more conspicuous but not definitely enlarged in the interval.

prior insult.there is secondary bibasilar atelectasis.there is also occlusion of the proximal right basal segmental bronchi with retained secretions.there is also minimal narrowing of the main the posterior membranous wall of the upper trachea, narrowing the sagittal diameter of the trachea from 15.4 to 8.5 mm, for a short segment (1.5 cm) to: 16-18), consistent with focal criteria for pathology, with the largest node in the prevascular space measuring 9 mm.note is made of a lipoma in the prevascular space measuring 2.1 x 2.2 cm (2:26).there is pulmonary arterial text: there is no traumatic aortic injury.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.there is no rib fracture or pneumothorax.the trachea and bronchi are patent to the subsegmental level.the lungs demonstrate no nodule, opacity, or pleural effusion.note is made of minimal bilateral subsegmental atelectasis.the soft tissues appear unremarkable.
summary: partially visualized cervical spine fracture, see separate ct cervical spine study and separate report.no other evidence of traumatic injury to the chest, abdomen or pelvis.bilateral adnexal cysts; recommend further evaluated with ultrasound.findings posted to the ed dashboard.

text: mild bilateral pleural thickening is noted at the lung bases as well as at the left pulmonary apex.there is residual relaxation atelectasis noted at bilateral lung bases.coronary vessels are calcified.atherosclerotic plaque is noted within the origin of the left subclavian artery.the visualized heart and pericardium are otherwise unremarkable.the visualized liver is homogenous in density with no focal lesions.the gallbladder shows presence of a gallstone, unchanged from prior but with no evidence of cholecystitis.the spleen is normal in size and configuration.the pancreas is normal in size, without evidence of mass lesions.the bilateral adrenal glands are unremarkable.the visualized kidneys enhance and excrete contrast symmetrically without evidence of hydronephrosis, stones, or masses.the visualized stomach is unremarkable.the visualized small bowels show no evidence of obstruction, mass or bowel wall thickening.a trace amount of free fluid is noted adjacent to the liver (3, 83).a small right-sided paraaortic lymph node is noted measuring 9.4 mm in shortest diameter (3, 75).a few left-sided paraaortic lymph nodes are noted, which do not meet ct criteria for lymphadenopathy.there is no free air in the abdomen.an infrarenal filter is noted within the inferior vena cava.the ivc below the filter contains low-attenuation material consistent with a thrombus which extends distally and bilaterally.on the right side there appears to be partial occlision of the right common and external iliac veins, and complet occlusion of the right common femoral vein.the calliber of the ivc distal to the filter is reduced suggesting the chronic nature of the thrombus.atherosclerotic calcifications are noted within the aorta extending into common iliacs bilaterally.distal abdomina aortic dissection is noted which appears stable since ___.
summary: no evidence of malignant focus to explain patient's dvt.perisistent chronic ivc thrombosis distal to the infrarenal filter, with extension bilaterally.partial occlusion of the right common and external iliac veins with complete occlusion of the right common femoral vein.cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis is once again noted.prostatic enlargement is noted.

text: the aorta and major branches are patent with normal three-vessel branching arch and no signs of acute aortic pathology.the pulmonary arterial tree is well opacified without pulmonary embolus.within the right lung, there is a large hydropneumothorax predominantly basally located which contains more air and less fluid than on the previous studies, compatible with known interval pleurx catheter placement; however, no significant reexpansion has taken place, consistent with trapped lung likely due to extensive metastatic infiltration of the right lung.there has been interval increase in size of the right upper lung lesion measuring 7.7 x 4.3 cm, with resultant increase compression on the upper lobe airways and subsequent increased collapse of the right upper lobe.extensive septal thickening and ground-glass changes in the entire right lung is compatible with lymphangitic tumor spread.circumferential pleural thickening is noted along with near complete collapse or metastatic infiltration of the right lower lobe.the left upper lobe is clear.left lower lung dependent opacity is slightly more dense than the previous examination, compatible with aspiration or infectious process.large mediastinal nodes are again noted, largely unchanged in paraesophageal location, measuring at least 35 x 27-mm, relatively unchanged (2:44).the trachea and airways to the left lung are relatively patent.right airways are markedly attenuated by tumor.there is no axillary adenopathy.the imaged upper abdomen is unremarkable aside from enhancing lesions draping over the liver, likely reflecting tumor involving the diaphragmatic pleura.
summary: no pulmonary embolism or acute aortic pathology.extensive metastatic disease in the right lung with increasing size of juxta-mediastinal soft tissue surrounding the right upper lobe airways with resultant decrease in aeration of the right upper lobe and unchanged extensive pleural thickening with lymphangitic tumor spread throughout the right lung.right basal hydropneumothorax with pleural catheter contains more air in less fluid than on the previous study, without significant reexpansion-findings raise the possibility of a trapped lung.resolved lingular opacity with left lower lobe dependent opacity compatible with aspiration or infectious process.

text: the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.calcification in the aortic valve is severe, moderate calcification is in the mitral annulus, dense calcification is in the lad, moderate calcification is in the right coronary artery.cardiac size is top normal, bilateral pleural effusions are small greater on the right side, there is mild calcification of the aortic wall in the arch, there is no calcification in the ascending aorta, minimal calcification is in the descending aorta medially, enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes measure in the right upper paratracheal station 14 mm, in right lower paratracheal station 13 mm, in the subcarinal station 19 mm, evaluation of hilar lymphadenopathy is limited due to lack of iv contrast this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.of note the suprarenal abdominal aorta measures up to 32 mm ap and has dense wall calcifications.there is vicarious excretion of contrast in the gallbladder.the kidneys are small, show multiple hypodense cortical lesions, small to be characterized, likely cysts.on the right there also appear to be parapelvic cysts, this evaluation is limited due to the lack of iv contrast.dense calcification is in the celiac artery, sma and splenic artery.2-mm nodule in the left upper lobe (3:20) is not calcified, a calcified granuloma is in the left upper lobe (7:75), two non-calcified less than 3 mm nodules are in the left upper lobe (7:81 and 82), noncalcified elongated nodule in the left upper lobe measures 3.8 mm (7:96), tiny granuloma is in the left upper lobe (7:106), 3- mm nodule in the left upper lobe is noncalcified (7:147), 5.8-mm nodule in the left lower lobe is noncalcified (7: 209), 3-mm noncalcified nodule is in the right upper lobe (7:113), 4-mm nodule in the right middle lobe is noncalcified (7:171).moderate centrilobular emphysema is located in the upper lobes.a focal area of ground-glass opacity in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe is associated with bronchial wall thickening, small areas of peribronchial consolidation and peribronchial ground-glass opacities in the lower lobes bilaterally.there is mild interlobular smooth septal thickening in the bases bilaterally.there are no bony findings of malignancy.degenerative changes and compression fractures are in the lower thoracic spine and l1.
summary: multifocal infectious process, these abnormalities also could be due to aspiration.small bilateral pleural effusion.mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy that is greater on the right hilum measuring up to 11 mm in the right hilum, is reactive.severe aortic valve calcifications.emphysema.multiple calcified and noncalcified less than 5 mm nodules, follow up is recommended in three months.

text: there is a chest tube entering the mid left hemithorax extending superiorly with its tip adjacent to the mediastinum apically.there has been interval re-expansion of the apical left upper lobe.the previously demonstrated fluid collection anteroapically has cleared.the fluid collection which extends from the left lung apex to the left lung base appears not significantly changed compared with prior.the density of the fluid is low.empyema cannot be excluded, though there is no evidence of pleural enhancement.this does not appear consistent with hemorrhagic fluid.there is completel collapse of the left lower lobe.there is a small amount of pleural fluid on the right with associated right lower lobe atelectasis.this is not significantly changed.again demonstrated are multiple rib fractures involving the left hemithorax.there is trace pericardial effusion.no pneumothorax is present.in the imaged portion of the upper abdomen again demonstrated is bilateral adrenal hemorrhage.
summary: there has been re-expansion of the apical portion of the left upper lobe.the fluid collection in this area has been cleared.there is a persistent left pleural effusion extending from the left lung apex to the left lung base with complete collapse of the left lower lobe.there is a small right pleural effusion with associated atelectasis.bilateral adrenal hemorrhages.multiple left-sided rib fractures.

text: airways are patent up to subsegmental level.there is extrinsic compression of the right bronchus intermedius, (400b:24), from a loculated fluid effusion.there is collapse of the right lower lobe, and right middle lobe.there is new partial opacification of the left lower lobe.no definite enhancing mass seen.there is a right pleural effusion, with chest tube in place with tip at the right lung apex.there is a new right anterior loculated pleural effusion.there is a loculated pleural effusion in the minor fissure, measuring roughly 10 x 2.3 cm, (401b:18), with interval increase in size.there is small left pleural effusion.4-mm ground glass nodule is seen in the right upper lobe, (2:10) with mild interval decrease in size compared to prior ct likely infectious.there are no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes according to ct size criteria in the mediastinum, hilum, or axilla.heart size is normal.there is no pericardial effusion.vessels are of normal caliber.there is no pneumothorax.this study is not tailored to evaluate subdiaphragmatic contents.there is an ng tube in place.there is an endotracheal tube in standard position.
summary: loculated right pleural effusion, with new anterior and worsening interfissural component, and adjacent atelectasis of the right lower lobe and right middle lobe.extrinsic compression to the bronchus intermedius from loculated effusion.new small left pleural effusion, with adjacent atelectasis at the left lung base; however cannot exclude superinfection/pneumonia.4-mm ground glass nodule in the right upper lobe, attention on next followup, likley infectious with interval decrease in size.chest tube in place extending into the major component of the pleural effusion along the chest wall and the tip at the right lung apex; however, not draining the loculated effusion.

text: chest with contrast: again noted are bilateral pleural effusions and bibasilar atelectasis.multifocal areas of consolidation are present in both lungs.the prior ct scans are of the abdomen since this has not been well documented or characterized previously.the consolidation is worse in the left upper and lower lobes as well as in the lingula with several scattered areas of consolidation throughout the right lung.small mediastinal lymphadenopathy is noted.precarinal lymph nodes are also present.the largest is approximately 2.5 x 1.8 cm in size.in addition, enlarged left axillary lymph nodes are noted.
summary: multifocal consolidation throughout lungs, worse on left side than right.no new drainable fluid collection in the pelvis.the catheter is in satisfactory position.extensive inflammatory changes remain present.a small intracutaneous fistula cannot be excluded arising from a loop of small bowel located anteriorly in the mid pelvis.

text: an et tube is seen with the tip approximately 3.7 cm above the carina.the aorta appears normal in course and caliber with mild atherosclerotic calcifications noted.there is no evidence of dissection.the central pulmonary artery appears patent.the heart is upper limits of normal in size.coronary artery calcifications are noted.no lymphadenopathy is detected.bilateral simple layering pleural effusions are seen, right greater than left.compressive atelectasis of the left lower lobe and portions of the right upper and right lower lobe are seen.there is no evidence of lung contusion.areas of ground-glass opacity in the upper lobes may reflect hypoventilatory changes though there is also note made of scarring in the lung apices, left greater than right.there is no pneumothorax.
summary: large bilateral simple-appearing pleural effusions with associated compressive atelectasis, notable in the left lower lobe.probable acute fracture of the distal sacrum with associated presacral hematoma.recommend correlation with site of pain.et tube in appropriate position.bilateral renal hypodensities, likely cysts, though too small to characterize with cortical irregularity suggestive of chronic scarring.diverticulosis without evidence of diverticulitis.

text: there are extensive bilateral pulmonary emboli with filling defects involving the right and left pulmonary arteries extending into all three lobar branches and multiple segmental and subsegmental branches.there is slight leftward bowing of the interventricular septum as well as reflux of contrast into the ivc, both suggestive of right heart strain.in addition, there is enlargement of the main pulmonary artery measuring 3.3 cm suggesting pulmonary arterial hypertension.all of these findings are compatible with massive pe.the aorta is unremarkable in course and caliber.there is mixing of contrast with blood within the aortic lumen, which limits our evaluation for dissection.there is no lymphadenopathy in the chest.the heart is normal in size, and there is no pericardial effusion.there is no pleural effusion.the airway is patent to the segmental level bilaterally.a punctate calcification is noted within the otherwise normal-appearing thyroid gland, which is only partially imaged on the non-contrast phase.no worrisome nodules or mass lesions are seen within the lungs.there is a small focus of atelectasis along the major fissure in the superior segment of the right lower lobe.there is no evidence of pulmonary infarction.limited views through the upper abdomen are unrevealing.
summary: massive pulmonary embolism with a large clot burden within left and right main pulmonary arteries and their respective branches.ct evidence of right heart strain and pulmonary arterial hypertension as described.findings were discussed with dr.___ at the time of preliminary review, and findings were flagged as urgent on the ed dashboard.sesha

text: the pericardial effusion is moderate-to-large in size measuring relatively low density of up to 20 hounsfield units.the previously demonstrated pericardial drainage has been removed in the meantime interval.the superior vena cava and inferior vena cava are not dilated and there is also no shift of the interventricular septum, thus there is no radiographic evidence of tamponade.small mediastinal lymph nodes do not meet the size criteria for pathological lymph node enlargement as well as there is no hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.the airways are patent to the level of segmental bronchi with some secretions demonstrated in the right main bronchus.the lungs are essentially clear.the small bilateral pleural effusion is demonstrated, left more than right.the images of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.oral contrast is demonstrated in the transverse colon.there are no bone lesions suspicious for malignancy.
summary: moderate-to-large pericardial effusion with no radiological evidence of tamponade.small pleural effusion, left more than right.

text: no large central pulmonary emboli are identified.the pulmonary emboli beyond this cannot be excluded based on the quality of the study.there are bilateral pleural effusions which have not changed significantly since the prior exam.there is compressive atelectasis of both lungs dependently.the heart size is unchanged.there is an endotracheal tube, ng tube and a central venous line.there are scattered lymph nodes in the axilla and mediastinum likely reactionary in nature.the aorta is unremarkable.there is a tiny pericardial effusion.lung windows demonstrate severe multifocal air space opacities which have become more dense and consolidative since the prior study.there has been some clearing of the opacities in the right upper lobe however the remaining pulmonary parenchyma has worsened.the extensive multifocal nature of these opacities yields a large differential diagnosis including but not limited to, ards, diffuse infection, and pulmonary hemorrhage.the imaged portion of the upper abdomen demonstrates intraabdominal ascites.there is diffuse anasarca.bone windows demonstrate no destructive lytic or blastic lesions.multiplanar reformatted images aid in the interpretation of the pulmonary parenchyma.axial images through the lower pelvis and lower extremities demonstrate no evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the commmon femoral, superfiscial femoral and popliteal veins.there is diffuse anasarca throughout the subcutaneous tissues and musculature.
summary: limited study for evaluation of pulmonary emboli; however, there are no large central pulmonary emboli.bilateral large pleural effusions, not significantly changed in size since the prior study.multifocal opacities throughout the pulmonary parenchyma which have worsened since the prior exam.the differential diagnosis is broad and is as listed above.no evidence of dvt in the lower extremities.

text: please note that study was extremely limited due to suboptimal bolus administration.within this limitation, there are no central filling defects identified.slightly heterogeneous and possible filling defects within the subsegmental and segmental branches, for instance in the left lower lobe (4, 64) are identified.these may represent artifact from poor bolus timing versus possible small pulmonary emboli.there is no ct evidence of right heart strain.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.there is no axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy identified.there is no pleural effusion, focal parenchymal consolidation or pneumothorax identified.a 2-mm subpleural nodule along the right upper lobe (4, 42) is identified.minimal bibasilar atelectasis is noted.an additional subpleural nodule in the left upper lobe (4, 44) is identified and may represent pleural thickening.limited views of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.there is a small hiatal hernia.
summary: no evidence of large central filling defects within the pulmonary arteries.however, given suboptimal contrast administration, more distal pulmonary emboli within the segmental and subsegmental arterial branches cannot be excluded.repeat study could be performed if clinically indicated.findings were discussed with dr.___ via telephone at 7:40 p.m.

text: the mass in the right upper lobe today measures 25 x 22 mm, essentially unchanged compared to the prior study.just inferior to this, there appears to be a second 4-mm nodule which may have been present on the prior study, but is difficult to directly evaluate given differences in slice thickness.in the left lower lobe again seen is a 6 mm nodule (3:27), unchanged.no new nodules or masses are identified within the lungs.there remains paraseptal and centrilobular emphysematous change, particularly in the upper lobe, which are stable.in the mediastinum, the previously noted right paratracheal lymph node today measures 11 x 14 mm, slightly decreased in the interim.the left lower paratracheal lymph node today measures 21 x 11 mm, unchanged.the right lower paratracheal lymph node today measures 15 x 11 mm, also stable.finally, the subcarinal lymph node today measures 19 x 9 mm, stable.the great vessels appear unremarkable apart from minimal calcification along the aortic arch.the heart size is normal.there is a trace amount of pericardial fluid.the central airways are patent without endoluminal lesion.in the visualized upper abdomen, again seen is a peripherally enhancing lesion in the dome of the liver measuring approximately 38 x 14 mm, not significantly changed in size.in the inferior right lobe of the liver, today there is an area of irregular enhancement measuring approximately 30 x 21 mm.on prior studies, this lesion was not clearly apparent.a small left kidney cyst is unchanged.a small hyperdense nodule along the posterior wall of the stomach is probably ingested material.osseous structures again demonstrate degenerative changes of the spine.however, there are no concerning lytic or sclerotic lesions.
summary: stable size of the right upper lobe mass as well as the mediastinal lymphadenopathy compared to the prior study.a 4 mm nodule just inferior to the right upper lobe mass may be more prominent today due to differences in slice thickness, but continued attention to this area is recommended on subsequent studies.stable lesion in the dome of the liver, however, there is a newly apparant irregular area of enhancement now noted in the inferior right lobe of the liver, which may represent a perfusion abnormality or a second lesion.for further evaluation of this finding, an mri of the abdomen is recommended with gadolinium.jr

text: due to necessity of injection of iv contrast through a central venous line, this study is somewhat suboptimal for pulmonary embolus evaluation; however, allowing for this, no filling defect is seen in the central pulmonary arteries to suggest pe.there is diffuse multifocal multilobar pneumonia, with the densest consolidation in the lower lobes posteriorly.there is diffuse ill-defined consolidation seen throughout both lobes diffusely, however, consistent with the given history of ards.the extent of consolidation is worse compared to the prior ct.multiple borderline enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes likely reactive.small bilateral pleural effusions, slightly improved compared to the prior study.no pneumothorax.limited axial imaging through the upper abdomen demonstrates no abnormalities.the patient is intubated, with persisting overinflation of the endotracheal tube balloon cuff superiorly.
summary: endotracheal tube balloon cuff remains overinflated.multifocal, multilobar consolidation, densest in the lower lobes, consistent with multifocal pneumonia complicated by ards.the extent and distribution of the consolidation is slightly worsened compared to the prior ct.due to the standard technique and short interval since the prior study, it is difficult to comment on possible fibrotic changes.no evidence for pulmonary embolism.small bilateral pleural effusions, slightly improved.mediastinal lymphadenopathy, likely reactive.discussed with the covering resident after the study.

text: the heart size is normal.the thoracic aorta and pulmonary artery are normal in caliber.no pulmonary embolism is detected to the subsegmental levels.there is a moderate amount of centrilobular emphysema a the upper zones.a large left lower lobe consolidation is present.crowding of vessels and bronchial are compatible with superimposed atalectasis.narrowing of a segmental bronchus is seen (3:49).an underlying obstructive mass cannot be excluded.within the right lower lobe posteriorly, there are several areas of patchy consolidation (3:68), compatible with focal areas of consolidation.multiple enlarged lymph nodes are present in the left axilla and throughout the mediastinum, and are likely reactive from underlying inflammation..these do not meet ct criteria for lymphadenopathy.the included views of the liver, spleen, and stomach are unremarkable.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.large left lower lobe consolidation and atelectasis, compatible with pneumonia.underlying obstructive mass cannot be excluded in this region, and followup imaging is recommended once consolidation has been cleared.small right lower lobe consolidations compatible with multifocal pneumonia.moderate upper-zone centrilobular emphysema.

text: the great vessels are normal in caliber without evidence of acute injury there is no evidence of mediastinal hemorrhage, pericardial or pleural effusion.there is mild bibasilar atelectasis.no pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum is seen.there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.the airways are patent.there is a small hiatal hernia.
summary: no evidence of acute injury in the chest, abdomen, or pelvis.

text: patient is status post left lower lobe lobectomy with left-sided small pleural effusion identified.within the periphery of the right upper lobe is focus of ground-glass attenuation, unchanged dating back to the chest ct from ___.within the left upper lobe, a new ill-defined focal opacity is demonstrated with a somewhat linear configuration, and could represent an inflammatory process.diffuse centrilobular emphysema is identified.no pulmonary nodules are noted.airways are patent to the level of segmental bronchi bilaterally.there are extensive calcification involving the coronary arteries, aortic valve, and thoracic aorta.patient is status post cabg.heart, pericardium, and great vessels otherwise are unchanged.there has been slight interval increase in size of several mediastinal lymph nodes.the largest lymph node is within the precarinal station and measures 12 mm wide, which is increased from the prior exam when it measured 10 mm.small prevascular lymph nodes are subcentimeter in size, but have increased in the interval.an aorticopulmonary window lymph node also is increased now measuring 8 mm, previously 5 mm.no axillary or hilar lymphadenopathy is identified.
summary: persistent ground-glass opacity in the periphery of the right upper lobe, unchanged compared to ___.this may represent an area of bronchoalveolar carcinoma or an inflammatory process.continued followup is recommended.status post left lower lobe lobectomy.focal opacity within the left upper lobe is non-specific, and could be secondary to an inflammatory etiology.continued attention to this region on subsequent follow-up exams is recommended.slight interval increase in size of mediastinal lymph nodes, likely reactive in nature.unchanged marked mucosal enhancement within the gallbladder with a small outpouching, which in the correct clinical setting may be suggestive of adenomyomatosis.dfddp

text: multiple hypoattenuating thyroid nodules are stable since ___.there are small mediastinal lymph nodes, which are stable in size and appearance and do not meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.there is a trace pericardial effusion.there is no pleural effusion.central airways are patent to the segmental levels bilaterally.the lungs remain clear.no concerning pulmonary nodules are noted.
summary: significant increase in size and number of numerous hepatic metastases, consistent with progression of the disease.

text: the patient is status post left mastectomy and rectus flap reconstruction.the post-operative appearance of the left outer chest wall is unchanged.there is a right subclavian central venous catheter terminating at the cavoatrial junction.there is no axillary or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.a left hilar lymph node measures 10 mm in shortest axis dimension, slightly larger than its previous size of 8 mm.the heart, great vessels, and pericardium are unremarkable.a small amount of enteric contrast remains in the esophagus.there are no pleural or pericardial effusions.a large cavitating lung nodule in the left lower lobe (series 3, image 22) measures 41 x 32 mm in axial dimensions, slightly larger than previous measurements of 37 x 29 mm.there is persistent cavitation and now an air- fluid level within the mass.distal to the mass, there is also new peripheral opacity which is most consistent with post-obstructive atelectasis.a pleural based nodule at the right apex measures 9 mm in diameter, slightly larger than the prior diameter of 6 mm.a spiculated 6-mm nodule in the left apex is unchanged.the 3-mm nodule in the right middle lobe is likewise unchanged.no new lung nodules or masses are identified.peripheral thickening of the interlobular septa in the anterolateral left upper lobe, is similar to before and most suggestive of radiation change.
summary: mild interval progression of pulmonary metastases.new opacity distal to the large left lower lobe cavitary lesion, most likely due to postobstructive atelectasis.there is also new fluid within the cavitating lesion.stable small hypodense foci in the liver, which are too small to characterize.

text: a 4 x 4 cm heterogeneous mass in the apical portion of the apicoposterior segment of the left upper lobe extends to the apical and mediastinal pleural surface (at the level of the left subclavian artery take off).it has irregular margins with mild adjacent indistinctness of the adjacent lung parenchyma and irregular interlobular septal thickening.a prevascular, 11mm wide, mediastinal lymph node is mildly enlarged by ct criteria; although adjacent lymph nodes are not as large, all are suspcious for malignancy by virtue of location, while 9 mm pre-cranial (3:21) and a 9 mm subcarinal (3:26) lymph node are not enlarged by ct criteria, and less likely to be malignant.in the right upper lobe is a stellate 8-mm lesion in a peribronchovascular pattern.a 4-mm nodule is noted in the right upper lobe (6, 1:20).a right lower lobe nodule measures 3 mm (6:158).the thyroid gland is unremarkable.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.the pulmonary artery measures 3.7 cm in the axial dimension and is enlarged but no filling defects are noted.no pericardial effusions are present.the patient has a mitral valve prosthesis.mild calcific atherosclerosis of the descending aorta is noted.although this examination was not intended for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, the partially imaged abdomen shows a hypertrophied left adrenal gland.
summary: 4 x 4 cm heterogeneous mass in the apical portion of the apicoposterior segment of the left upper lobe.this is contiguous with the apical pleural surface and the mediastinal pleura at the level of the left subclavian artery.enlarged prevascular node measuring 11 mm with prominent but not enlarged precarinal and subcarinal lymph nodes.multiple noncalcified nodules in the right lower lobe are subcentimeter in a peribronchovascular distribution and could represent peribronchial inflammation or a nodule.left adrenal gland hypertrophy.

text: there is a stable pericardial effusion.the heart and great vessels are otherwise unremarkable.there are no pathologically enlarged axillary, mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes.there are unchanged bilateral loculated and posterior layering pleural effusions.there are persistent multifocal areas of consolidation.there is slight interval improved aeration in the left lower lobe.
summary: slight interval improved aeration in the left lower lobe with persistent multifocal opacities and posterior layering as well as loculated effusions.unchanged appearance of the abdomen and pelvis.unchanged appearance of multiple peripheral splenic infarcts.

text: an indwelling left-sided chest tube is positioned posteriorly and medially.the moderate-sized loculated left-sided pleural effusion is smaller, with near complete collapse of the left lower lobe has some new areas of increased aeration.a small right-sided pleural effusion with associated partial right lower lobe atelectasis is unchanged.a left-sided subclavian central venous line and tracheostomy tube are appropriately positioned.there is mild narrowing of the trachea distal to the tracheostomy tube.there are mild atherosclerotic calcifications of the thoracic aorta and dense atherosclerotic calcification of the coronary arteries, especially the lad.a 16-mm prevascular lymph node (2:13) has mildly enlarged.the remaining mediastinal lymph nodes including an 8-mm right paratracheal node are stable.there is upper lobe predominant minimal centrilobular emphysema.an 8-mm ground-glass opacity within the medial segment of the right middle lobe may be infectious or inflammatory.this examination is not tailored for infradiaphragmatic evaluation.the visualized portions of the upper abdomen are limited by streak artifact from retained barium within the stomach.hypodensity of the spleen is not well evaluated.please see the recent ct torso of ___ for further details.there are no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.
summary: mild interval decrease in size of moderate-sized loculated left-sided pleural effusion with associated near complete atelectasis of the left lower lobe.superimposed infection cannot be excluded.small right-sided pleural effusion with right lower lobe partial atelectasis.mild tracheal narrowing may represent underlying tracheomalacia.enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes.

text: ct of the chest with iv contrast: the patient is intubated with the endotracheal tube ending approximately 5.5 cm above the carina.an ng tube is seen coursing through the esophagus and ending within the stomach.there is a small hiatal hernia.there is no intrathoracic vascular injury.there is dependent atelectases bilaterally.otherwise the lungs are clear.there is no pleural effusion or pericardial effusion.
summary: non-displaced right fifth rib fracture.otherwise no acute thoracic, abdominal or pelvic injury.findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ at the time of review on ___, ___.

text: examination is suboptimal due to patient motion.there is no main, lobar, or large segmental pulmonary embolus.there is no evidence of acute aortic syndrome including intramural hematoma, dissection, or aneurysm.a right subclavian line terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction.the heart is normal in size, with a trace simple pericardial effusion that is likely reactive.again noted is a 1.4 cm lobulated cystic lesion at the left lung apex, which may represent a subpleural bleb or pneumatocele from prior infection/trauma.multiple nodular, partially confluent opacities have developed in the left lower lobe.there is a persistent small simple left pleural effusion, with associated compressive atelectasis.regional bronchial wall thickening is also present.this constellation of findings is most reflective of aspiration and/or pneumonia.the right lung is clear, other than mild dependent atelectasis.scattered prominent axillary, mediastinal, and hilar lymph nodes are likely reactive.mild degenerative changes are noted in the thoracic spine.
summary: no evidence of pe.left lower lobe opacities with associated effusion, likely representing aspiration and/or pneumonia.

text: the endotracheal tube terminates 1.4 cm from the carina.there is dense consolidation of the right lower lobe.there are bilateral pleural effusions, moderate-to-large on the left and small on the right, of intermediate density on the left (28 ___) with some pleural enhancement on the left.there is associated compressive atelectasis of the left lower lobe.patchy and linear opacity at the lung apices.evaluation for pulmonary embolus is limited given the suboptimal opacification of the pulmonary arteries; however, there is no large pulmonary embolus to the segmental level.the heart and great vessels are normal, without pericardial effusion.no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy meeting ct criteria for pathologic enlargement is noted.
summary: dense right lower lobe consolidation consistent with pneumonia.large left pleural effusion with pleural enhancement; infection cannot be excluded.small right effusion.patchy consolidation at lung apices suggests aspiration or infection.fluid collection in the surgical bed, extending along the stomach and pancreatic tail, with marked stranding in left upper quadrant.extraluminal hyperdense material at the ge junction may represent surgical pledgets or extravasated contrast.cannot exclude anastomotic leak.notably, however, there is no intraperitoneal free air (endoscopy with insufflation was performed prior to this examination to assess for leak).limited evaluation for pulmonary embolus due to timing of contrast, but no evidence of large pulmonary embolus.peripancreatic fluid may be tracking from surgical bed, but recommend obtaining pancreatic enzymes for clinical correlation to exclude pancreatitis as a cause of left upper quadrant inflammatory change.ett terminates 1.4 cm above the carina.consider repositioning.findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ at 10:15 p.m.and dr.___ ___ at 11:00 pm on ___.please also refer to report of subsequent fluoroscopic evaluation on ___.

text: chest: a right lower lobe subpleural fat attenuation 12 x 8 mm nodule probably represent an intercostal lipoma (2:51).there is no pathologic enlargement of the supraclavicular, axillary or mediastinal lymph nodes.a calcified left thyroid nodule measures 21 x 21 mm and extends retrosternally.the great vessels appear normal.the cardiac size is normal without evidence of pericardial effusion.there is no pleural effusion.right basilar linear atelectasis is minor.there are no pulmonary nodules.
summary: no ct evidence of thoracic, abdominal or pelvic primary malignancy.uncomplicated descending colonic and sigmoid diverticulosis.left thyroid nodule would be better evaluated with thyroid ultrasound.

text: the heart and great vessels appear unremarkable without evidence of traumatic aortic injury or dissection.no pleural or pericardial effusion is present.no pathologically enlarged axillary or central lymph nodes are noted.there may be mild gynecomastia present.there is mild-to-moderate centrilobular emphysema with small region of linear atelectasis and/or scarring noted within the anterior portion of the right lower lobe adjacent to the major fissure.there is no pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion.small amount of secretions are noted adjacent and just distal to the endotracheal tube within the trachea with the airways appearing otherwise patent to the subsegmental level.

text: the aorta is normal in size throughout without evidence of acute pathology.moderate atherosclerotic calcifications involve the arch extending into proximal arch vessels.the pulmonary artery is well opacified, demonstrating occlusive and partially occlusive lobar, segmental and subsegmental bilateral pulmonary emboli extending into the left upper lobe, lingula, and left lower lobe pulmonary arteries on the left, and into the right lower lobe, and to a lesser extent into the right upper lobe pulmonary arteries.there is some enlargement of the right ventricle and straightening of the interventricular septum, that may suggest right cardiac strain (rv/lv ratio on axial images 1.7).however other signs of strain are not present: the main pulmonary artrey is not dilated (3.1 cm) compared to the ascending aorta (3.9 cm) and there is no reflaux in the ivc.the heart is top normal in size without pericardial effusion.patient is status post intubation, with et tube terminating at 2.5 cm above the carina.a feeding tube traverses through a widely patulous esophagus into the stomach.within the lungs, a small peripheral wedge-shaped opacity, best demonstrated on coronal view (400b, 23), is suggestive of a pulmonary infarct.there is also bilateral basilar atelectasis.there is no large pleural effusion.right apical linear scarring with associated calcifications appears unchanged, likely related to prior granulomatous disease.limited subdiaphragmatic evaluation demonstrates no significant visceral abnormality.

text: there is no pulmonary embolism.thoracic aorta is normal in caliber and contour throughout.mild atherosclerotic calcification is present in the aortic arch.there is mild coronary artery calcification, and mitral annular calcification.heart is enlarged, with prominent left atrial enlargment.there is no pericardial effusion.there is no right pleural effusion.there is a small left pleural effusion, which is loculated predominantly medially.there is mild associated left basilar atelectasis.multiple enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes measure up to 1.4 cm in the prevascular space (3, 36).central airways are patent to the subsegmental level.multiple areas of ground-glass opacity are present in a predominantly peribronchiolar distribution throughout both lungs, slightly more prominent in the apices bilaterally.there is no focal consolidation or pulmonary nodule or mass.limited views of the upper abdomen demonstrate a small hiatal hernia.there is a 2.4 cm focal hypodensity in the right lobe of the liver (3, 81), consistent with a simple cyst.there is no osseous lesion suspicious for malignancy.

text: there is no evidence of aortic dissection or a definite pulmonary embolism.as noted on prior examinations, the main pulmonary artery is dilated and many of the upper lobe branches are noted to be slightly narrowed and irregular likely related to fibrosis and scarring from patient's underlying tuberculosis.on today's examination, there is an area of stenosis with lack of distal filling noted within a right upper lobe pulmonary artery branch where a focal stenosis was noted on prior examination.it is unclear if this change in caliber is related to focal pulmonary embolism, in situ thrombosis from tight stenosis noted on prior examination or slight progression of fibrosis within the area.there is a reidentification of a questionable filling defect noted within the posterior basal right lower lobe branch which was noted on prior examination and is felt to likely represent respiratory variation/artifact present on both exams.conceivably, this may repesent chronic clot.evaluation of lung parenchyma again displays the patient to be status post left-sided pneumonectomy with the left hemithorax noted to be fluid filled, with the wall of the hydrothorax, again demonstrating a hyperdense and undulating appearance.the right lung apex displays unchanged apical pleural thickening and traction bronchiectasis as well as unchanged nodular opacities which may reflect underlying scarring.the right hilum and minor fissure is retracted superiorly.previously noted right axillary mass is no longer visualized and patient is noted to be status post partial right mastectomy with a surgical drain in place.no other pathologically enlarged nodes are present in the axilla, mediastinum, or hila.areas of pleural thickening along the lateral right pleura are also stable in appearance.limited examination of the upper abdomen is unremarkable.
summary: equivocal findings for acute pulmonary embolism affecting a right upper lobe branch, previously noted to display tight stenosis and a small amount of flow distally, now appearing cut off on today's examination.the differential for this lesion includes a small embolus, in situ thrombosis, or continued stenosis from areas of fibrosis and traction bronchiectasis noted within the right apex.it is felt unlikely that, given the preexsiting stenosis and presumed lower overall blood volume/flow, that a solitary clot would lodge itself solely in t his location.furthermore, that such a small "clot" occluding a very small branch to a likely hypoperfused lung segment would cause clinically relevant symptoms is highly doubted.resolution of previously noted soft tissue density in the right axilla, patient is known to be status post right modified mastectomy with surgical drain in place.unchanged appearance to left-sided hydrothorax status post left pneumonectomy.

text: soft tissue encasing the confluence of the right subclavian and common carotid arteries, extends into the right superior mediastinal and upper peritracheal space.the inferior aspect of the right internal jugular vein is narrowed, and the right brachiocephalic vein is obliterated.the left brachiocephalic vein is narrowed just proximal to its confluence with the svc (image 2:16).the svc is reconstituted from numerous superior intercostal collaterals.volume loss is observed in the right lung, with elevation of the right hemidiaphragm.bilateral geographic-appearing paramediastinal opacities in the upper lobes and in the superior segment of the right lower lobe suggest prior radiation therapy.the right clavicle is expanded and heterogenous with a thickened cortex and trabecular lucencies, also likely radiation induced.a 3 mm nodule in the right major fissure and a 2 mm nodule in the left major fissure are not calcified and appear nonspecific with respect to malignancy or benignity (image 3:24).a nonspecific, noncalcified 3 mm peripheral nodule is also noted in the left lower lobe (image 3:47).the tracheobronchial tree is patent to the subsegmental levels.several 10-11 mm subcarinal lymph nodes are present.an 11 mm right hilar node is also noted.heart size is normal.there is no pericardial effusion.there is a very small right pleural effusion.the imaged portion of the upper abdomen appears similar to the ___ abdominal ct scan, with bilateral biliary catheters and biliary dilatation in the posterior right hepatic lobe.a 3 mm sclerotic lesion in a left anterior rib was present on previous ___ ct scan (image 3:47), nonspecific- appearing and possibly representing a bone island.

text: no filling defects are seen within the pulmonary arteries to suggest pulmonary embolism.pulmonary arteries are well seen into the subsegmental level.pulmonary arteries are normal in size.the aorta is normal in caliber throughout the thorax.there is mild aortic atherosclerosis as well atherosclerosis at the origin of the great vessels.great vessels are widely patent.coronary artery shows extensive calcifications as well.heart size is within normal limits.compared to ___, there is a new development of moderate-large bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left.pleural effusions are dependent and without evidence of loculation.there is compressive atelectasis of the lower lobes bilaterally, right greater than left and of the right middle lobe as well.collapsed lung parenchyma does enhance normally, arguing against pneumonia, however, there are fluid-filled airways in the right lower lobe which likely reflects retained secretions.a component of aspiration cannot be completely excluded here.there is no evidence for pulmonary edema within the lung parenchyma.scattered centrilobular emphysema is again noted.central airways are patent, with the endotracheal tube tip a few centimeters above the carina in expected position.borderline enlarged right paratracheal lymph node is essentially unchanged from the prior study.ap lymph node and prevascular lymph nodes as well as upper right paratracheal lymph nodes have slightly increased in size but do not meet pathologic size criteria.this is likely reactive.similarly, borderline right hilar lymph node measuring nearly 1 cm in short axis is possibly slightly larger than the prior study, again, likely reactive.a subcarinal lymph node is also borderline and unchanged.there is trace pericardial fluid, slightly increased from prior.ng tube has its tip within the stomach.visualized portions below the diaphragm show no definite abnormality.visualized portions of the base of the neck also show no definite abnormality.
