text: the patient is intubated with the endotracheal tube in appropriate positioning.two left-sided chest tubes have been placed, although it is unclear if they lie within the major fissure or if they traverse lung parenchyma.multiple locules of gas is seen tracking along the anterior and lateral aspect of the left chest wall.the presumed entrance wound is seen in the left anterolateral chest wall (2; 31).most of the left upper lung is filled with fluid, presumably blood.there is minimal left pleural fluid.a few locules of pleural gas are also seen, but there is no large pneumothorax.the right lung as well as left lower lung demonstrates dependent atelectasis, but overall, the right lung is clear.the heart and great vessels appear unremarkable; streak artifact from the contrast bolus limits assessment of the left subclavian artery.however, gas tracking nearby its course as well as the comminuted left clavicular fracture increase the likelihood that this vessel is injured.
summary: opacification of the left upper lung concerning for pulmonary hemorrhage; course of the chest may be within the major fissure versus through lung parenchyma.comminuted mid shaft fracture of the left clavicle.soft tissue defect in the lateral aspect of the left chest wall with locules of gas coursing along the extrathoracic soft tissues.streak artifact from the contrast bolus limits assessment of the subclavian artery, but given the presumed trajectory of the bullet as well as the adjacent comminuted clavicular fracture, suspicion for subclavian artery injury should be raised.the above findings were discussed with ___ ___ of the trauma team at the time of the study.findings in the ascending and transverse colon may represent inflammatory bowel disease.correlate with history.the above findings were reiterated to ___ ___ at approximately 9:30 am on ___ by ___ ___ over the phone.

text: the heart is stable in size with new leftward shift of the mediastinum secondary to the left upper lobe lobectomy.there is atherosclerotic calcification involving the coronary arteries, aortic arch and descending aorta, which is mild to moderate in severity.no mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy is identified.secretions are noted layering within the esophagus.the left upper lobe bronchial stump demonstrates a normal postoperative appearance without evidence of recurrence or residual disease.the trachea and remainder of the central bronchi are patent.there is loculated pleural fluid within the upper left anterior hemithorax adjacent to the mediastinum.also noted is a small dependent left pleural fluid collection in addition to left lower lobe atelectasis.evaluation for small nodules is markedly limited secondary to motion and the expiratory phase of imaging.diffuse ground-glass opacities are noted bilaterally, which may be secondary to airtrapping.a 3-mm right upper lobe nodule (4:69), a 9-mm right lower lobe nodule (4:157), and a 2-mm right lower lobe granuloma are unchanged in size and appearance.several nodules previously identified are not identified on the current study, likely secondary to left lower lobe atelectasis, motion and subsequent suboptimal imaging.no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are identified within the osseous structures.a mild compression fracture of the t6 vertebral body is unchanged.although, this study was not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, images of the upper abdomen demonstrate a 1.5 cm fat-containing lesion within the left kidney, likely representing a small angiomyolipoma, which is unchanged in appearance.there is peripheral calcification involving the fundus of the gallbladder, potentially representing either porcelain gallbladder or a peripherally calcified gallbladder stone.this finding is unchanged in comparison to multiple prior studies.also noted is stable nodular thickening of the left adrenal gland.
summary: expected postoperative changes status post left upper lobe lobectomy with no definite evidence of recurrent or residual disease.small dependent left pleural effusion and small loculated anterior pleural fluid collection within the upper left hemithorax, which may be postoperative in nature.a followup ct in three months is recommended for further assessment.limited evaluation of multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules secondary to motion artifact and expiratory phase of imaging, rendering suboptimal image quality.assessment of nodules may be performed in three months, at which time, attention should be paid to obtaining end inspiratory images.diffuse ground-glass opacities noted bilaterally, potentially related to airtrapping secondary to expiratory phase of the imaging.stable peripherally calcified gallbladder fundus likely representing either a peripherally calcified gallstone versus a porcelain gallbladder.followup with ultrasound is recommended for further characterization.stable nodular thickening of the left adrenal gland.stable 1.5 cm fat-containing lesion within the left kidney likely representing a small angiomyolipoma.

text: no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes are identified.the heart, great vessels, and pericardium appear grossly normal.assessment of lung fields again demonstrates a right upper lobe bulla.there is a 5 mm nodule within the right middle lobe which was present on the previous study and appears unchanged in size.no new pulmonary nodules are identified.there is a trace right pleural effusion which is smaller in size than it was in the ___ ct of the abdomen.there has been a slight interval decrease in size in the moderate dependent left pleural effusion.there is linear pattern of opacity at the right lung base consistent with atelectasis.adjacent to the left effusion, there is air space opacification with an intense, homogeneous pattern of enhancement.the imaging appearance favors atelectasis.there is a stable appearing 3 cm left adrenal adenoma.the osseous structures are unremarkable.

text: there are multiple small scattered mediastinal lymph nodes, all of which do not meet size criteria for pathologic enlargement, the largest being a pretracheal lymph node measuring up to 7 mm in transverse dimension.there is no axillary or hilar lymphadenopathy.note is made of main pulmonary truncal enlargement measuring up to 3.7 cm, that can be seen in the setting of pulmonary hypertension.there is an extensive atherosclerotic calcification involving the thoracic aorta and coronary arteries and major branches of the thoracic aorta.there is no evidence of aortic dissection.the heart appears unremarkable with no evidence of pericardial effusion.the lungs are clear without parenchymal consolidation, pleural effusions, or pulmonary nodules.
summary: several osseous fragments in left shoulder joint, which is also distended with fluid.while no overt or displaced fracture is seen, if there is recent trauma with resulting pain to the left shoulder, mri may be considered for assessment for occult fracture.age-indeterminate anterior/superior subluxation of the left glenohumeral joint, likely related to chronic rotator cuff injury.extensive atherosclerotic disease involving the entire aorta and its major branches, and the coronary arteries.osterior subcutaneous tissues.

text: the thyroid gland is incompletely visualized.there is no supraclavicular or axillary lymphadenopathy is present.multiple prominent mediastinal lymph nodes are identified, the largest of which is noted to be precarinal (2:20) measuring 1.2 cm in the greatest dimension.atherosclerotic changes are identified within the thoracic aorta without associated aneurysmal change.atherosclerotic plaques are also noted throughout the coronary vasculature.heart size is normal without pericardial effusion.airways are patent to the subsegmental level.emphysematous changes are noted particularly in the bilateral lung apices.chronic interstitial changes in combination with atelectasis are noted in the bilateral lung bases, left greater than right.tree-in-___ opacities are also noted in the right upper lobe and right lower lobe.these later findings are suggestive of a small airway infection or inflammation.calcified plaques are identified within the left subpulmonic pleura as well as tracking along the left major fissure.

text: on mediastinal windows, a few enlarged lymph nodes are again noted with the largest one in the precarinal region measuring 1.3 cm.the adenopathy is not significantly changed compared to the prior study.a loculated fluid collection is identified in the non dependent portion of the left upper thorax, slightly decreased in size compared to the prior study.the previously seen small bilateral pleural effusions in the bases have largely resolved.on lung windows, a 7.3 x 5.8 cm thick walled cavity with internal septations is present in the right upper lobe.this has increased in size and the wall has also increased in size compared to the prior study.immediately inferiorly, ill-defined areas of consolidation is identified with air bronchograms, new compared to the prior study.the previously seen diffuse ground glass opacities have largely resolved.residual densities are present in the bases.there are also areas of bronchiectasis especially in the lung bases, also unchanged.limited examination of the upper abdomen demonstrates no significant change in the retroperitoneal lymph nodes.
summary: enlarged cavity in the right upper lobe with thickened wall with no definite internal dependent mass to suggest aspergilloma; adjacent new area of consolidation in the right upper lobe posteriorly, both concerning for infection.previously described diffuse ground-glass opacities and alveolar have significantly improved.slight decrease in pleural fluid in the left hemithorax.persistent intrathoracic lymph node enlargement, consistent with sarcoid.these findings were discussed with dr.___ over the telephone after the examination.

text: the thoracic aorta demonstrates no evidence of aneurysmal dilatation or dissection.there is a ng tube, endotracheal tube and right subclavian central venous catheter in satisfactory position.there is no pneumothorax.there are bibasilar dependent consolidations with associated small pleural effusions.the airways are patent to the segmental level bilaterally.there are no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar or mediastinal lymph nodes.

text: there are no filling defects in the pulmonary arteries concerning for pulmonary embolism.apparent linear filling defect in the left lingular branch is not confirmed on the reformatted images, and is likely to represent a volume averaging.there is no evidence of aortic dissection.tiny mediastinal lymph nodes are seen, not meeting ct criteria for pathologic lymphadenopathy.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.the largest left axillary node measures 7 mm in short axis diameter.a large right pleural effusion continues to be present, similar in size compared with the prior study.there is compression atelectasis in the right lower lobe.there is no left pleural effusion.there is no new concerning nodule or mass in the lung parenchyma.the airways are patent to the segmental levels bilaterally.pleural thickening and enhancement remain worrisome for metastatic involvement.
summary: increase in mesenteric lymphadenopathy, stable burden of disease otherwise, including peritoneal carcinomatosis with large ascites and omental caking.stable large right-sided pleural effusion with concerning pleural thickening and enhancement.mild left hydronephroureter, similar in extent to the prior study, without evidence of delayed contrast excretion.

text: no incidental thyroid findings.no supraclavicular, infraclavicular, or axillary lymphadenopathy.in the mediastinum, several normally sized lymph nodes are seen, but no adenopathy is documented.moderate coronary calcifications, no pericardial effusion.on the right, a probably non-recent moderate pleural effusion is seen.pleural surfaces show no evidence of uneven thickening or nodularity.the right effusion is homogeneous.in the lung parenchyma centrally adjacent to the effusions, several areas of focal, rounded opacities are seen that partly show curvilinear complying opacities and appear to reflect areas of rounded atelectasis.this would suggest chronicity of the changes.the pleural surfaces overall are even.no evidence of pleural lesions.adjacent to the right pleural effusion, the ribs are normal, there is no evidence of pathologic fractures or osteolytic lesions.the diaphragmatic contour on the coronal reconstructions appears normal.no disease in the upper abdomen that could explain pleural effusion.multiple bilateral kidney cysts.small hiatal hernia.in the remaining lung parenchyma, noncharacteristic millimetric subpleural granulomas and small areas of fibrosis are seen.none of these require follow.

text: the aortic root, ascending aorta, aortic arch, and descending aorta are normal in size and contour.no asymmetrical wall thickening or hematoma is present to suggest aortic injury.no dissection is present.no pleural or pericardial effusions are present.there is bilateral apical scarring, which appears chronic in nature.there is also mild bibasilar atelectasis within the dependent portions of the lungs.no focal pulmonary nodules are identified.there is no significant axillary, mediastinum or hilar lymphadenopathy.osseous structures within the chest demonstrate no evidence of fracture or hematoma.air is present in the anterior soft tissues of the neck directly anterior to the trachea, extending cranially from the level of the manubrium.the trachea appears mildly ectatic at the superior most aspects.the subcutaneous air is most likely a result from the patient's known mandibular fracture.there is no mediastinal air.no fluid collections or blood/hematoma are seen in the visualized portions of the anterior neck adjacent to the subcutaneous air.for a detailed description of the neck soft tissue, please refer to the ct of the cervical spine.
summary: no evidence for traumatic aortic injury.no evidence of intra-abdominal organ injury or fracture throughout the visualized portions of the axial and appendicular skeleton.air in subcutaneous tissue anterior to trachea, likely from the patient's mandible fracture.

text: the thyroid gland is normal.there is no hilar, mediastinal, supraclavicular or axillary lymphadenopathy identified.there has been a previous left axillary lymph node dissection.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.the heart size is normal without pericardial effusion.the great vessels are unremarkable.there is a mass in the posterior right lung posterior that measures 20 x 16 mm, image 2:28, as compared to 20 x 18 mm on the prior study.the lungs are otherwise clear without other nodules, focal consolidations or pleural effusions.there is a right-sided anterior chest wall nodule that measures 11 x 6 mm (image 2:25), as compared to 14 x 13 mm on the previous exam.

text: there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism within the main, primary or secondary branches of the pulmonary artery.there is no evidence of aortic dissection.collaterization of vessles along right chest following right sided contrast injection, likely indicates stricture of right subclavian vein (3a:14).heart is mildly enlarged.there is no pericardial effusion.there is no mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy by size criteria.imaged thyroid gland is unremarkable.mild emphysema is present.there is no evidence of pneumonia.bilateral small nonhemorrhagic pleural effusions with associated adjacent atelectasis are noted.there is no pneumothorax.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.large anterior abdominal hematoma at the location of anterior abdominal hernia repair mostly anterior to surgical mesh, with multiple foci of loculated air, extends into the peritoneal cavity inferiorly.small amount of hemorrhagic fluid in the pelvis.fat stranding and small foci of air in the right upper quadrant related to recent cholecystectomy.status post billroth ii procedure.small bilateral pleural effusions with adjacent atelectasis.

text: no significant mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy is identified.the great vessels are intact.the heart and pericardium are within normal limits.small left pleural effusion is present.lung window images reveal biapical scarring.multiple, small, air-filled cystic structures are identified within the left upper lobe, the largest measuring approximately 2.3 x 1.6 cm.patchy linear opacities are seen in the right upper and middle lobes, as well as in the lingula.given these linear opacites and multiple cystic structures, these findings are likely representative of chronic changes associated with prior infection.a non- calcified, 13 x 7 mm nodular opacity with ill-defined borders is also seen in the left upper lobe.no pneumothorax is identified.multiple rib fractures are identified within the left lateral and posterior 4th through 8th ribs.most of these are clearly acute, but two posterior rib abnormalities suggest healed fractures from prior injury.adjacent to these rib fractures is an area of hematoma additionally, a patchy opacity is seen adjacent to these rib fractures in the left upper lobe, likely representing small pulmonary contusion.the airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.
summary: multiple left-sided rib fractures with surrounding hematoma and small area of pulmonary contusion.no pneumothorax.several, small, air-filled cystic lesions seen within the left upper lobe, along with scattered patchy areas of linear opacity.these findings likely represent chronic changes associated with prior infectious processes.no free air, free fluid, or visceral injury identified within the abdomen or pelvis.l2 compression fracture.non-calcified nodular opacity in left upper lobe with ill-defined margins.this may relate to chronic changes as described above.follow chest ct scan is recommended in 6 weeks after resolution of findings associated with acute injury to evaluate for stability of this nodule.if persistent, a pet-ct may be indicated.

text: there has been interval removal of left chest tube.small left apical and medial pneumothorax is seen with a small loculated air in the major fissure, significantly smaller in size compared to prior ct ___.no pneumothorax on the right is identified.there is collapse of the left lower lobe and a partial atelectasis of the posterior and medial basal segments of the right lower lobe.the left lower lobe collapse is new since prior study.additionally, previously seen contusions in the right upper lobe have largely improved.however, there are now several areas of ground- glass opacities, particularly in the right upper lobe and lingula, with more consolidative opacities in the posterior segment of the right upper lobe and within the left lung base adjacent to the left lower lobe collapse.these may reflect consolidation related to aspiration.a small right pleural effusion persists.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable, with no evidence of pulmonary embolism.no pericaridal effusion is identified.there are several scattered mediastinal and axillary lymph nodes, with the largest mediastinal node in the right paratracheal region (3:15) measuring approximately 1 cm in short axis dimensions.the largest left axillary node measures approximately 1.2 cm in short axis dimensions.this examination is not tailored for detailed evaluation of subdiaphragmatic regions.the visualized portions of the upper abdomen reveal free fluid within the right subphrenic region, which is new since ___.
summary: no pulmonary embolism.small left apical and medial pneumothorax.left lower lobe atelectasis and partial atelectasis of the posterior and medial basal segments of the right lower lobe.scattered ground-glass opacities with more consolidative opacities in the right upper and left upper lobes, may represent sequela from aspiration.free fluid in the right subphrenic space, new since prior study and incompletely assessed on this ct chest.multiple left rib fractures and fracture of the right first rib redemonstrated.findings were discussed with dr.___ at the time of interpretation.

text: the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there is mild bronchiectasis with mild bronchial wall thickening in the lower lobes, more so in the left.few of the bronchi have mucus plugs.multiple less than 3-mm lung nodules, some of them ground-glass and some of them soft tissue density are all stable since ___.lung nodules are seen in series 5, image 49, 76, 79, 94, 107, 135, 158, 183, 188, 201.there are no new lung nodules.right 8-mm parafissural nodule is also unchanged.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.in the lower lobes, ground-glass opacities are consistent with atelectasis and are stable.lymph node anterior to the innominate artery measuring 6 mm is unchanged (2, 17).otherwise there are no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes.calcification in the lad is again noted.trace pericardial effusion is unchanged.lymph nodes in the cardiophrenic angles are stable.cardiac size is normal.the aorta is normal in caliber.there are no bone findings of malignancy.there is an old fracture in the right clavicle.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.the spleen measures 11 cm, decreased in size from prior study.the patient is after liver transplant.patient has known splenic and paraesophageal varices.there is minimal stranding or trace of fluid surrounding the upper pole of the right kidney.persistent periportal edema.
summary: stable lung nodules.no new lung abnormalities.stable abdominal findings.please refer to complete description of abdominal findings in prior abdomen ct from ___.

text: the visualized heart and pericardium are unremarkable.bibasilar atelectasis is noted.mediastinal, axillary and hilar lymph nodes do not meet ct size criteria for pathology.there is no contusion, pneumothorax, or hemothorax.no worrisome pulmonary nodules.the imaged portion of the thyroid gland is normal.
summary: multiple fractures including: (1) comminuted right acetabular fracture with associated dislocation of the right femoral head,(2) bilateral superior and inferior pubic ramus fractures, (3) fracture of the right ischial tuberosity, (4) comminuted right distal femoral shaft fracture, (5) open fractures of the right tibia and fibular mid shaft, (6) fracture of the right fibular head, and (7) posterolateral right tibial plateau fracture.asymmetric increase in muscle bulk in the anterior right thigh likely due to hematoma, correlate for possible compartment syndrome.no evidence of active bleeding or vascular compromise.small peripancreatic fat stranding around the tail of the pancreas, correlate with serum amylase and lipase levels.a small lesion within the right lobe of the liver (2a:91) may represent a small hemangioma.

text: pulmonary arterial tree is well opacified, with no evidence for filling defect to the subsegmental level.there is no evidence for pulmonary embolus.the aorta is normal in caliber, configuration and contour, with no evidence for acute aortic syndromes.origins of the great vessels are unremarkable.there is a large left pleural effusion, with adjacent rounded atelectasis.there is no definite underlying mass lesion or consolidation identified.there is no pleural enhancement or thickening.the right lung is clear.there is a small dependent right-sided effusion.there are no consolidations, nodules, or masses in the right lung.there is no pneumothorax.mild diffuse bronchial wall thickening is noted, suggesting underlying chronic bronchitis.within the mediastinum, there are multiple lymph nodes identified in the subcarinal, pretracheal, and periaortic regions, measuring up to 1.4 cm (2:24).heart is notable for dense coronary artery calcifications.there is no pericardial effusion.the trachea and central airways are patent to the subsegmental level, with no endobronchial lesions identified.the thyroid appears unremarkable.this examination is not tailored for evaluation of subdiaphragmatic structures, however, limited views of the upper abdomen demonstrate dense calcifications in the pancreas, consistent with chronic pancreatitis.the liver and spleen appear grossly unremarkable.
summary: no evidence for pulmonary embolus or acute aortic syndrome.large left pleural effusion, with no underlying mass lesion or consolidation identified.however, given identification of mediastinal adenopathy and the size of the pleural effusion, this is highly suspicious for underlying malignancy, and close interval followup is recommended.repeat scanning after thoracentesis, if performed, is suggested to assess the currently collapsed lung in the left hemithorax.bronchial wall thickening suggestive of chronic bronchitis.coronary calcification.pancreatic calcification consistent with chronic pancreatitis.

text: there has been slight interval enlargement in the anterior prevascular node, which now measures 21 x 27 mm (2:16).the hilar nodes and other central nodes appear unchanged and are not pathologically enlarged by ct criteria.the previously noted bilateral pulmonary embolism has resolved.there has been no interval change in the bronchial wall dilatation, centrilobular nodules and tree-in-___ opacities of the lungs, which predominantly affect the upper lobe and are compatible with the reported history of tuberculoses.there has been interval appearance of new nodules; for example, the nodule located within the left upper lobe (2:15), and resolution of the some of the prior nodes.the largest mass lesion located in the superior segment of the right lower lobe which is calcified is larger, measuring 17 and 18 mm compared to the prior when it measured 13 x 16 mm.no pleural effusion or pericardial effusion is noted.calcification of the coronary arteries are visualized.multiple hypodense lesions within the kidneys,comaptible with simple cysts are unchanged.multiple small hypodense lesions within the liver are unchanged and are too small to characterize.the adrenal glands, spleen appear unremarkable.
summary: interval resolution of bilateral pulmonary embolism.unchanged bilateral bronchial wall thickening, centrilobular nodules, and tree-in-___ opacities which is suggestive of unchanged status of tuberculosis of the lungs.interval appearance of new nodules within the lung and disappearance of some of the old nodules suggest the waxing and ___ response to the treatment.the largest mass located within the superior segment of the right lower lobe has enlarged.slight interval enlargement of the central lymphadenopathy.

text: a small amount of plaque is noted at the origin of the right brachiocephalic artery (3:24).the thoracic aorta is mildly dilated measuring 4.3 cm in diameter.a small amount of atherosclerotic and calcific plaque is noted of the mid descending aorta (3:61).however, there is no evidence of acute aortic dissection.there are no filling defects within the pulmonary arterial vasculature.the proximal portions of the coronary arteries are well opacified.there is no pericardial effusion.note is made of significant pectus excavatum deformity of the chest wall.there is mild upper lobe centrilobular emphysema.aside from bibasilar atelectasis, the lungs are clear.the images of the partially visualized upper abdomen demonstrate several low-attenuation areas present within both kidneys which are consistent with simple cysts.no suspicious lytic or blastic lesions are identified.
summary: scattered areas of atherosclerotic plaques throughout the thoracic aorta, however, there is no acute aortic dissection.enlarged ascending aorta measuring 4.3 cm in greatest diameter.enlarged pulmonary artery is suggestive of underlying pulmonary hypertension.note is also made of diffuse centrilobular emphysematous changes.no pulmonary embolism.bilateral, simple-appearing renal cysts.

text: there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes are present.a prevascular/upper mediastinal lymph node measures 14 mm in short dimension.a right paratracheal lymph node measures 19 mm in short dimension.a ap window lymph node measures 15 mm in short dimension, and a subcarinal lymph node measures 15 mm in short dimension.hilar lymph nodes are also present.there is a 17 mm right hilar lymph node.there are small bilateral pleural effusions, and bilateral atelectasis at the bases.
summary: bilateral atelectasis dependently, with small bilateral pleural effusions.multiple enlarged mediastinal and right hilar lymph nodes are present.duodenal wall thickening.mesenteric stranding with small retroperitoneal lymph nodes.the spleen has a heterogeneous enhancement pattern.this is nonspecific in appearance.this may represent infiltration by lymphoma; given the duodenal thickening and multiple enlarged lymph nodes, lymphoma should also be considered.there is a well-demarcated hypodensity within the pancreatic head, incompletely characterized on this study.

text: evaluation of the lung parenchyma demonstrates bibasilar airspace disease suggestive of pneumonia, greater on the left when compared to the right, which has slightly improved in the interval.the previously described right lower lobe cystic area is redemonstrated (series 2/image 21) and appear stable in the interval.a small right pleural effusion is present.a larger left pleural effusion is identified with multiple air pockets, which may have been introduced by the catheter, that have slightly progressed in the interval.it now measures 12 cm in an ap dimension, 3 cm transverse, and 9 cm longitudinally.the hounsfield units for the fluid range from 23-27, consistent with a slightly complex fluid.no peripheral enhancement is seen.the previously placed pigtail catheter in the left lateral chest wall is seen however the tip appears to be abutting a rib and inadequately draining the pleural space.the tracheobronchial tree centrally appears patent.the svc, ivc, aorta and its branches appear unremarkable.the heart appears mildly enlarged.no intraluminal filling defect is seen in the pulmonary arterial trunk major branches or segmental branches.evaluation of the distal pulmonary arteries is limited due to obscuration from adjacent consolidation.a few subcentimeter mediastinal lymph nodes are noted.the esophagus is normal course and caliber.the visualized upper abdominal solid viscera demonstrate no gross abnormality.there is suggestion of mild splenomegaly.the osseous structures demonstrate mild degenerative change.
summary: redemonstrated multifocal pneumonia which has improved in the interval.no lung abscess is seen.stable rml cystic area.interval increase in left partially loculated hydropneumothorax.the pigtail catheter tip appears to be abutting a rib and may require repositioning.findings discussed with dr.___ via telephone on ___ at 1400hrs.

text: the right internal jugular central venous line tip is at the cavoatrial junction.there is no filling defect within the central venous system to suggest thrombus formation and no secondary findings of thrombosis such as venous collateralization.significant streak artifact from a pacing device in the left anterior chest wall is noted with a single chamber icd device in satisfactory position.there is cardiac enlargement predominantly right ventricular and atrial enlargement with a right-sided aortic arch.a stent is noted in the left subclavian artery (2.7).enlargement of the main pulmonary artery is 34 mm, right main pulmonary artery is 23 mm, and left main artery is 25 mm suggesting pulmonary arterial hypertension.no pericardial effusion.the endotracheal tube is satisfactory with its tip at the thoracic inlet.a moderately large right pleural effusion and small left pleural effusion have developed since the previous ct.multifocal consolidation has worsened in the upper lobes bilaterally associated with diffuse ground glass opacities also in the right middle and lower lobes with some improvement in the dense consolidation in the left lower lobe, though this remains severe.limited views of the upper abdomen are unremarkable except to note focal fatty infiltration in the liver adjacent to the falciform ligament.no destructive or sclerotic bone lesions.the patient is status post median sternotomy with intact sternal wires.
summary: no direct or indirect evidence of central venous thrombosis.the tip of the internal jugular catheter is at the cavoatrial junction.interval worsening of consolidation and ground glass opacities throughout the lungs, predominantly in the upper lobes and right lower lobe with some interval improvement in the consolidation in the left lower lobe.new moderately large right pleural effusion and small left pleural effusion.cardiac enlargement with right sided aortic arch

text: there is interval improvement in the previously demonstrated left pleural/upper chest fluid collection.stranding in the anterior neck soft tissues with multiple foci of air is demonstrated, consistent with the patient's neck infection, that was more fully imaged on the neck ct of one day prior.there is a picc catheter that terminates in the svc.there are coronary artery calcifications.there is a trace right-sided pleural effusion, new compared to the previous exam.the previously demonstrated left-sided effusion has resolved.there are small areas of atelectasis in both lower lobes.note is made of a prominent left paratracheal node measuring 9 mm.there are multiple other small mediastinal nodes that do not meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.the airways appear patent to the level of segmental bronchi bilaterally.there is no pneumothorax.

text: there is status post pancoast tumor following induction chemoradiation.the right upper lobe spiculated mass appears minimally smaller than at the last examination.the extent of pleural thickening is unchanged.no new lesions have occurred in the right upper lobe.the pre-existing subtotal consolidation of the left lower lobe has markedly improved.the areas of parenchymal consolidation have decreased in extent, also decreased are the pre-existing signs of volume loss.on today's examination, the remaining alterations are primarily located at the periphery and the bases of the left lower lobe, the medial aspect of the consolidation could partly be caused by the rounded atelectasis.there is no evidence of left-sided pleural effusion.there are no other parenchymal abnormalities in the left lung.the pre-existing subcarinal lymph node has decreased in size from 25.5 x 21.2 to 17.6 x 20.1 mm.the pre-existing left paratracheal node has only minimally decreased in size._____ are the other mediastinal lymph nodes.also unchanged are the signs of paramediastinal stranding.as on the previous examination, lipomatous hypotrophy of the interatrial septum is noted.there is no evidence of pericardial effusion.the appearance of the adrenals, notably the right rounded 1-cm lesion is unchanged.small pre-existing liver cysts.no evidence of bone destruction.
summary: slight decrease in size of the right apical pancoast tumor.marked decrease of left lower lobe infection.overall slight regression in size of mediastinal lymph nodes.otherwise, no relevant change.

text: the patient is status post median sternotomy.there is surgical suture material/stent material present at the apex of the ascending aorta.surgical clips are noted in the anterior mediastinum.surgical clips are also noted in the region of the proximal aorta.there is a marked interval reduction in the caliber of the ascending aorta, now measuring 4.1 cm in maximal diameter.there is a large amount of air in the mediastinum surrounding the aorta and in the anterior mediastinum.there is a moderate amount of fluid surrounding the aorta and in the anterior mediastinum.there is a small left-sided pneumothorax with left-sided subcutaneous air.a chest tube is seen entering the left hemithorax terminating in the left superior hemithorax.there is an et tube in satisfactory position.there is a pacemaker with leads terminating in the left ventricle.there is an ng tube terminating in the stomach.pericardial leads are noted.there are bilateral pleural effusions with left lower lobe consolidation and patchy consolidation of the right lower lobe.there is a 13 mm left-sided superior mediastinal node.there is a 12 mm precardinal lymph node.there are no pathologically enlarged axillary lymph nodes.there is a small amount of soft tissue density material layering along the posterior wall of the distal trachea that may represent debris.
summary: air-containing fluid collections surrounding the ascending aorta and anterior mediastinum.this may represent postsurgical change.however, infection cannot be excluded.left-sided pneumothorax with chest tube in place.bilateral pleural effusions with left lower lobe consolidation and patchy consolidation of the right lower lobe.hypodense lesion in the midpole of the right kidney that is incompletely evaluated on this study but may represent a simple renal cyst.the above findings were communicated with ___ ___, ___ time of interpretation of the study.

text: imaged thyroid gland is unremarkable.aorta and major branches are patent with a bovine arch incidentally noted.mediastinum is unremarkable.coronary vascular calcifications are noted.heart and pericardium are otherwise unremarkable without pericardial effusion.trachea and central airways are patent to the segmental levels.the esophagus is normal in appearance.the lungs are clear bilaterally with minimal bibasilar atelectasis.
summary: no acute traumatic injury to the torso.

text: heart and pericardium are normal without pericardial effusion.multiple subsegmental and segmental pulmonary emboli in bilateral lower lobes are seen, but better assessed on cta chest of ___.otherwise, great vessels are unremarkable.there is no pathologic mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.dependent atelectases are present in the lungs bilaterally.in addition, there are scattered pulmonary nodules, with a nodule in the right upper lobe measuring 4 mm (3:20), a nodule in the lingula measuring 4 mm (3:30) and an ill-defined nodular opacity in right lower lobe (3:34) measuring 8 mm.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there is no evidence of pulmonary consolidation or pulmonary edema.there is no pleural effusion.
summary: large heterogeneous mass within the right lobe of the liver, suspicious for hepatocellular carcinoma.perfusional abnormalities of the remainder of the right lobe of the liver, with a more focal rounded area of low attenuation in segment v/vi, which could represent a perfusion abnormality.however, a satellite second lesion cannot be excluded.pulmonary nodules are nonspecific.follow-up ct in three months is recommended to exclude metastatic disease.bilateral segmental and subsegmental pulmonary emboli.

text: conglomerate of enlarged subcarinal lymphadenopathy has again increased in size, currently measuring 35 x 26 mm, previously 28 x 22 mm.no significant hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy is present.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are unremarkable.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.central bronchi are patent to the subsegmental level.lung windows again demonstrate unchanged appearance of multiple tiny bilateral pulmonary nodules.there are no new nodules or focal consolidations.small lipoma in the left lateral chest wall is unchanged.

text: the ascending aorta is mildly dilated measuring 4.2 x 4.3 cm at the level of the right main pulmonary artery, but is unchanged compared to ___.there is no periaortic hematoma, intimal flap, or penetrating atherosclerotic ulceration.the pulmonary arteries are well opacified and demonstrate no evidence of intraluminal filling defects.there is a left internal jugular central venous line with the tip in the upper svc.there is an endotracheal tube present with the tip several centimeters above the carina.there are small bilateral pleural effusions with associated bibasilar atelectasis.the effusions have increased since ___.there are no consolidations.the bronchi are patent to the subsegmental levels.there are several mediastinal lymph nodes, but none which meet ct criteria for pathological enlargement.the largest is in the subcarinal region measuring 8 mm in short axis.small hilar nodes are also present.note is made of coronary artery calcifications.limited assessment of the upper abdomen shows no overt hepatic lesion.an ng tube is present with the tip in the stomach.

text: hypodense nodule in left thyroid lobe (2:5) measures 7 mm, unchanged since ___ exam.no axillary, supraclavicular, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.bilateral pulmonary emboli involving right lower and left lower pulmonary artery branches are present, new since the prior study.no evidence of right heart strain or pulmonary infarct.the great vessels are otherwise unremarkable.the heart is normal.herniation of lung parenchyma through defects in the right anterolateral chest wall are similar to prior.multiple bilateral subcentimeter pulmonary nodules are not appreciably changed since the prior exam.the largest measures 6 x 4 mm in the right upper lobe (2:33).other unchanged nodules are located in the right upper lobe (2:35), left upper lobe (2:40), left lower lobe (2:29), and lingula (2:55).no new pulmonary nodule or diffuse pulmonary abnormality.the pleura is intact with trace bilateral effusion.
summary: bilateral pulmonary emboli without evidence of right heart strain or pulmonary infarction.status post partial left nephrectomy without evidence of local recurrence.stable appearance of several bilateral pulmonary nodules, measuring up to 6 mm.previously described enlarged left paraaortic node has decreased in size and no longer meets ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.findings were communicated via phone call by ___ ___ to anish ___ on ___ at 1532.findings were made at 1520.

text: the thyroid gland is normal.no axillary lymphadenopathy present.within the mediastinum, there are two enlarged enhancing lymph nodes, specifically pretracheal node measuring 15 mm and a prevascular node measuring 12 mm.there is also right and left anterior descending coronary artery calcification, pericardial fat, and a left hilar mass with probable left lymphangitic spread into the left upper lobe.this most likely represents the primary lung malignancy.there is also a left greater than right pleural effusions with some atelectasis of the bilateral lower lobes.right jugular catheter ending in right atrium.
summary: left hilar mass with upper lobe lymphangitic spread concerning for a primary lung malignancy.left greater than right pleural effusions.numerous diffuse metastases within the liver and right adrenal gland.left anterior abdominal wall subcutaneous metastasis

text: the heart size is normal.there is an aberrant right subclavian artery, which is a normal variant.this artery is somewhat prominent and mildly compresses the upper esophagus.there is a small pericardial effusion, slightly increased in size in the interval.again noted is a large left pleural effusion and small right pleural effusion.the right effusion is slightly smaller in the interval.within the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, there is partial visualization of an ivc filter.no focal abnormalities are detected in the upper abdomen.there are stable postoperative changes in the left upper lung.atelectasis is present at the left lung base.no new nodules or masses are identified to suggest metastatic disease.there is a small calcified granuloma in the right upper lobe.there is emphysema.bone windows demonstrate no suspicious lytic or sclerotic abnormalities.

text: apparent peripheral filling defect in the posterior subsegmental branch of the left lower lobe pulmonary artery, image #49-52 series 2a is noted.no other filling defects are identified.the aorta demonstrates atherosclerotic calcifications with no aneurysmal dilatation.there is no definite evidence of dissection; however, timing is not optimal for evaluation of the thoracic aorta.the heart is enlarged.there is no pericardial effusion.fluid in the pericardial recess surrounding the root of the aorta is noted.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes in the prevascular region measuring up to 0.9 cm are noted.there are also paratracheal subcentimeter lymph nodes which are increased in number.there is also a subcentimeter subcarinal lymph node, image #30 series 2a.there is no pneumothorax.bilateral small pleural effusions with bilateral lower lobe atelectasis - consolidation with air bronchograms are noted.near atelectatic changes throughout both lungs are seen.
summary: peripheral filling defect in the posterior segment branch of the lower lobe pulmonary artery may represent a chronic pulmonary embolism versus lymph node.no other filling defects are seen.severe liver cirrhosis with recanalization of the umbilical vein and varices adjacent to the gastroesophageal junction and moderate intra-abdominal ascites.apparent wall thickening of the ascending colon may be related to liver disease and intra-abdominal ascites; however colitis cannot be excluded.clinical correlation is recommended.peripancreatic fluid may be related to liver disease; however pancreatitis is not entirely excluded and correlation with amylase, lipase is recommended.these values were not available at the time of this dictation.bilateral small pleural effusions and lower lobe atelectasis - consolidation.

text: left upper lobectomy for a lung mass invading the prevascular mediastinum followed the two comparison studies.strands of soft tissue in the aortopulmonary window are probably the residua of local dissection.no soft tissue is noted around the left upper lobe bronchial stump.small subcarinal (8 mm) and right hilar (10mm) nodes are stable since the preoperative pet ct.a small high attenuation pleural abnormality in the left apex is most likely due to organized hematoma.the left lower lobe is appropriatedly hyperinflated.post- surgical change follows rib resection in the left upper chest wall.centrilobular emphysema in the right lung is moderately severe in the upper lobe, milder elsewhere.a 2-mm nodule in the subpleural region of the right upper lobe (5:116) and two tiny nodules in the perifissural region of the right upper lobe (5:143) are all stable..in images limited to the upper abdomen, the enhancing 2.1x 1.9cm right adrenal mass is unchanged in size since pre-operative imaging; the nonenhanced pet ct showed this non-avid mass had attenuation values consistent with mixed lipid and soft tissue contents, likely an adenoma.an ivc filter remains in situ.small cysts in the liver are unchanged.there are no bone lesions suspicious for malignancy.
summary: post-operative soft tissue in the ap window and left apical hematoma could mask local tumor recurrence.close followup advised, to include tiny right lung nodules, stable over the past six months.stable subcarinal and right hilar lymph nodes, not pathologically enlarged by ct size criteria.probable right adrenal adenoma, unchanged.

text: contrast quality is sufficient to rule out recent pulmonary embolism in the central and lobar pulmonary arteries.as compared to the previous examination, the extent of the pre-existing bilateral pleural effusions has markedly increased.this increase is more obvious on the right than on the left.as a consequence, the dorsal parts of both lungs show atelectatic changes.these atelectatic changes are much more severe on the left than on the right.on the left, the entire lower lobe is atelectatic, resulting in a severely over expanded and emphysematously destroyed lung that occupies the apical ventral parts of the left hemithorax.this extensive emphysematous changes and the overexpansion of the lung parenchyma mimics the pneumothorax seen on the chest x-ray.the well-ventilated areas of the right lung show evidence of mild overhydration.in addition, a peripheral rounded consolidation has newly appeared (3,11) that could be of atelectatic or infectious in origin.along the right major fissure, and at the right lung base, additional atelectatic areas are visible.there is minimal widening of the mediastinum, notably at the level of the aortopulmonary window, but without evidence of focal adenopathy.the aorta and the supra-aortic branches appear normal, the known coronary calcifications are unchanged.radiopaque punctate material is seen prespinal location (3, 16).the examination does not extend much in the abdomen, but the known peg device and at least two hypodense liver lesions are seen.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.extensive bilateral pleural effusions with massive lower lobe atelectasis on the left and subsequent hyperinflation of a severely emphysematous left lung (that mimics pneumothorax on the chest x-ray).smaller areas of atelectasis at the right lung base.newly appeared rounder right upper lobe opacity that could be of atelectatic or infectious.mild fluid overload.no evidence of mediastinal lymphadenopathy.peg device, hypodense liver lesions.

text: multiple pulmonary nodules seen throughout both lung parenchymas appear stable compared to the prior study on ___.the largest nodule in the right lower lobe (2:27) now measures 34 x 26 mm and is stable compared to the prior study where it measured 35 x 28 mm.the largest left lower lobe lesion (2:34) is now 28 x 28 mm, previously 29 x 28 mm.no new lung nodules identified.no pleural or pericardial effusion noted.heart and great vessels are unremarkable, except for atherosclerotic calcification of the aorta.a right hilar node measures 9 mm in its short axis,approaching the limit for significant adenopathy,the node is stable since the prior study.no other significant mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy noted.
summary: stable multiple pulmonary nodules.no new lung nodule identified in the current study.no findings suggestive of local recurrence or progression of metastatic disease .

text: the pulmonary arterial tree is well opacified with contrast.there are no filling defects within the pulmonary arterial tree to suggest pulmonary embolism.the heart is enlarged and there is an associated small to moderate pericardial effusion.the aorta is unremarkable.there are small bilateral axillary lymph nodes that do not meet ct requirement for pathologic enlargement.there are small prevascular and paratracheal lymph nodes.there is a 1.6 x 3.1 cm right hilar lymph node not present on the prior study.lung windows reveal extensive severe emphysematous change as noted on the prior study.there has been interval resolution of the bibasilar airspace consolidation.there is new collapse of the right middle lobe.the trachea and bronchi are widely patent to the segmental level, and no obstructing endobronchial lesion is identified.evaluation is somewhat degraded by patient respiratory artifact.there is bilateral dependent atelectasis.there are small, right greater than left, pleural effusions.there are multiple sub-cm somewhat ill defined rounded opacities within both lungs.the largest is present within the inferior aspect of the right upper lobe and measures approximately 7 mm in greatest dimenstion (series 3, image 77).these nodular densities were not definitively visualized on the prior study.the incompletely visualized liver and spleen are grossly unremarkable.

text: the pulmonary arteries are well opacified up to subsegmental levels, without evidence of acute pulmonary embolism.the thoracic aorta has mild atherosclerotic calcifications, but no acute aortic pathology is seen.the ascending thoracic aorta is mildly dilated measuring 3.8 cm.moderate coronary arterial calcifications are seen.there is no pericardial effusion.the major airways are patent to subsegmental levels bilaterally.however, there is diffuse thickening of the airways, with impaction of some small airways indicative of airways disease.patchy ground-glass opacity is seen throughout both lungs, reflective of airtrapping.stable paramediastinal scarring in the right upper lobe is noted.no consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax is detected.no significant mediastinal, hilar or axillary adenopathy seen.dilation of the upper esophagus with ingested food material is seen, raising concern for esophageal dysmotility/stricture the study is not tailored for evaluation of the subdiaphragmatic organs.within this limitation, the imaged upper abdomen is unremarkable.

text: the patient is intubated with tracheostome cuff over- inflated, measuring up to 3.3 cm.the left upper lobe spiculated lesion is increased in comparison to both previous cts, measuring now 3 x 3.8 cm instead of 2 x 1.3 cm in ___ and 1 x 0.9 cm in ___.this mass is invading the mediastinum with no fat plane seen between this mass and pulmonary and mediastinal vessels at this level.severe emphysema, centrilobular and paraseptal in the upper lobes and predominantly centrilobular in the lower lobes is unchanged.mediastinal lymph nodes do not meet the criteria for mediastinal lymphadenopathy.the heart size is enlarged and there is no pericardial effusion.the post- cabg clips are unchanged with heavily calcified native coronary arteries.the sternal titanium plates are in unchanged place with some decrease in the fat stranding in the anterior chest wall and with no discrete collections founded.the images of the upper abdomen demonstrate normal liver, spleen, right kidney, adrenals and pancreas and clips in the upper abdomen of unknown surgery.the appearance of the left kidney with two large hypodense lesions demonstrated as well as atrophy of the cortex.there are no bone lesions suspicious for malignancy.

text: again demonstrated is a uniformly enhancing 8-mm diameter horseshoe-shaped nodular opacity in the periphery of the right upper lobe (image 95, series 4), with an adjacent pleural tag.this is without change in size, shape, and enhancement since the prior cta of ___.assessment of the remainder of the lungs is remarkable for mild centrilobular and paraseptal emphysema.soft tissue structures demonstrate circumferential soft tissue thickening surrounding the origin of the left subclavian artery, with a subsequent 2 cm segment demonstrating complete lack of opacification, with subsequent return of complete intraluminal contrast opacification at the level of the medial head of the left clavicle.this is unchanged in appearance from the prior study as well as a prior cta of the neck of ___.no enlarged mediastinal or hilar lymph nodes.heart size is normal, and there is no pericardial or pleural effusion.exam was not specifically tailored to evaluate the subdiaphragmatic region, but no concerning abnormalities are identified in this region on this very limited assessment.skeletal structures demonstrate no evidence of suspicious lytic or blastic lesions.
summary: 8-mm intensely enhancing peripheral right upper lobe nodular opacity is unchanged.by report of dedicated catheter angiography study, this is not consistent with a pulmonary arterial venous malformation.differential diagnosis includes a bronchial artery aneurysm and less likely an intensely enhancing carcinoid or other neoplasm.continued ct surveillance recommended in six months.persistent circumferential soft tissue thickening at origin of left subclavian artery with subsequent short segment complete occlusion of approximately 2 cm in length with subsequent opacification distally.this is nonspecific but could potentially be due to subclavian steal phenomenon.differential diagnosis includes thromboembolic etiology and an inflammatory arteritis.

text: the heart is enlarged.there are coronary artery calcifications and calcification in the bypass graft to the circumflex artery.the pericardium is unremarkable.the aorta and great vessels are unremarkable.there is a prominent right paratracheal lymph node which does not meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.there are also small lymph nodes in the pretracheal region.there is no hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.the lungs are notable for scattered areas of atelectasis most notable at the lung bases and dependently.there are moderate bilateral pleural effusions.there is also evidence of ascites in the abdomen.the organs of the upper abdomen are incompletely visualized but no gross abnormalities are detected.

text: unenhanced images of the chest display no evidence of intramural hematoma and prominence of the intraventricular septum, likely related to patient's known underlying anemia.contrast-enhanced images of the chest display no evidence of aortic dissection or pulmonary embolism to the subsegmental level.heart and great vessels appear unremarkable.left-sided port is stable in position.previously described mediastinal lymphadenopathy displays no change since ___.largest nodal conglomerate again noted to be subcarinal measuring 29 x 17 mm.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.small 3-mm right lower lobe pulmonary nodule is again noted and is unchanged.the lungs are otherwise clear and display no focal consolidations.mild linear regions of scarring and/or atelectasis within the lingula and right middle lobe are stable.

text: chest: there is no evidence of filling defect within the main, left, right, lobar or subsegmental pulmonary arteries.evaluation of the subsegmental arteries is limited due to respiratory motion, particularly at the lung bases.there is no evidence of intramural hematoma, aortic aneurysm or dissection.there is some atherosclerotic plaque with ulcerative plaque at the inferior margin of the aortic arch laterally which is a stable configuration compared to prior exam from ___, without surrounding inflammatory changes.there is a 3 mm pleural-based nodule in the right upper lobe (series 3a, image 34) which was seen on prior chest ct dated ___.lungs are otherwise notable for bibasilar atelectasis.central airways are patent.there is a 1.0 cm short axis right paratracheal node at the thoracic inlet (series 3a: image 16) which has enlarged since ___ where it had measured 7 mm in diameter.given relatively rapid interval enlargement this may be reactive; however, metastatic disease is not excluded given history.elsewhere, there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary adenopathy.dense atherosclerotic calcifications are noted in the coronary arteries.there is no pericardial or pleural effusion.
