text: endotracheal tube terminates 3.5 cm above the carina.the previously seen posterior tracheal perforation with communication to the right pleural space is not visualized in the current study.again noted right hydropneumothorax, which is decreased since prior study.a small left pleural effusion is unchanged.the airways appear patent up to subsegmental levels bilaterally.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes are seen in the paratracheal region, prevascular space and both hila, with the largest lymph node measuring 11.8 mm.these lymph nodes have not significantly changed in size since the recent study.in this patient with esophageal cancer, metastatic disease cannot be ruled out and continued followup of these lymph nodes is recommended.no significant axillary lymphadenopathy is detected.multifocal pulmonary peri-bronchovascular nodular and ground-glass opacities are seen diffusely distributed throughout both lungs and have minimally increased in the left lung since the prior study.consolidative changes seen in the both lung bases have improved since the prior study.2 mm lung nodule is seen in the right lung apex (2:9) and is unchanged since prior study.trace pericardial effusion is unchanged since prior study.the small epicardial lymph nodes are unchanged , measuring up to 6 mm (2:36).the patient is status post esophagectomy and resection of the neoesophagus, without evidence of new mediastinal fluid collections.
summary: previously seen posterolateral tracheal perforation, is no longer visualized.decreased right-sided hydropneumothorax and the small left pleural effusion.the multifocal ground-glass and peribronchovascular nodular pulmonary opacities, have progressed in the left lung, and likely represent infection or inflammation.bibasilar consolidation improved.a 2 mm right apical lung nodule.recommended attention to this nodule in followup studies.post-surgical fluid collection adjacent to the spleen now measures 3.3 x 2.3 cm, and is modestly decreased since prior study.multiple prominent mediastinal lymph nodes may be reactive, although in this patient with history of esophageal carcinoma, metastatic disease cannot be excluded.recommended attention to these lymph nodes in followup studies.liver cirrhosis with mild splenomegaly.multiple left renal calculi.aneurysmal dilation of the left common iliac artery.

text: multiple small mediastinal and hilar nodes are slightly more prominent than on the prior study.for example, a precarinal node measures 8 mm in short axis, unchanged.a right hilar node measures 12 mm in short axis (7:24), previously 11 mm.a left hilar node currently measures 9 mm in the short axis (7:21), previously 7 mm.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.there are aortic valve leaflet calcifications, calcifications of the mitral valve, and coronary artery calcifications, particularly involving the lad.a port-a-cath is present in the right chest, with the tip at the cavoatrial junction.two lung nodules in the right lower lobe are not significantly changed from prior exams, including a 2-3 mm nodule (7:27) and a 4-mm nodule (7:28).a 3-mm nodule at the left base (7:25) is not significantly changed.the central airways are patent to the subsegmental level bilaterally.a very vague mosaic attenuation is seen in the lungs, not significantly changed from prior study.there is no consolidation.
summary: multiple large hepatic lesions are increased in size compared to ___ ___, suggesting disease progression.small pulmonary nodules are not significantly changed.

text: opacification of the pulmonary vasculature is visualized with no filling defects suggestive of pulmonary emboli.no evidence of aortic dissection or intramural hematoma.the aorta is normal in caliber.heart demonstrates right atrial and right ventricular enlargement.redemonstration of small pericardial effusion.no mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy identified.there is a slight increase in size of the previously identified right pleural effusion with interval resolution of left pleural effusion.the right breast is retracted and small with extensive skin thickening and a large 6.6 x 3.5 cm soft tissue spiculated mass(3:38) compatible with tumor.enlarged right axillary lymph node measuring 16 mm, as well as a subcutaneous right lateral chest wall subcutaneous soft tissue nodule measuring 28 mm are slightly decreased in size compared to prior study (3:16, 26).there is overall improved aeration of both lungs.persistent but improved ground-glass opacities bilterally with smooth septal thickening are compatible with mild pulmonary edema.improved aeration permits better visualization of previously poorly seen multiple pulmonary nodules, as well as reveal some nodules which were not clearly noted on the prior exam due to the presence of multifocal pneumonia.the pulmonary nodules which can be correlated with the next preceding study are overall smaller in size.notably, the previously demonstrated right lower lobe opacification (3:45), right middle lobe opacification (3:52), and lingualar pulmonary nodule are decreased in size.airways are patent to the subsegmental level.though this study is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, there is redemonstration of multiple bilateral adrenal gland nodules concerning for adrenal metastases.previously seen liver lesions are not well visualized on this exam.
summary: no pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection.mild pulmonary edema.given improved aeration, there are newly apparent pulmonary nodules, which may reflect metastases.pulmonary nodules that could be correlated with prior ct are decreased in size possibly indicating an infectious/inflammatory etiology or if metatstatic, response to treatment.opacifications concerning for pneumonia on prior study are improved and decreased in size.slight increase in size of right pleural effusion.resolution of left pleural effusion.stable appearance of right sided soft tissue nodules.redemonstration of vertebral body sclerotic lesion and bilateral adrenal nodules, concerning for metastases.

text: the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there are moderate-to-severe emphysematous changes predominantly in the upper lobes bilaterally.compared to prior study, ___ pet-ct, large upper lobe consolidation, a smaller right middle lobe consolidation, consistent with multifocal pneumonia, and likely bibasilar atelectasis are new.a spiculated calcified nodule in the left apex is unchanged.right lower lobe posterior pleural thickening with calcification has minimally increased from prior study.there are scattered calcified granulomas.left small supraclavicular lymph nodes are stable.the mediastinal lymph nodes have increased in size; for instance, a right upper paratracheal lymph node that was 6 mm now is almost 9 mm, in the right lower paratracheal station, a 9 mm lymph node was 7 mm, in the left lower paratracheal station, a 9 mm lymph node was 8 mm, right hilar lymph node is also more prominent than before measuring 9 mm.there is trace of pericardial effusion that is stable.there is no pleural effusion.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.a hypodense lesion in the spleen measuring 11 mm is unchanged.stones within the gallbladder are partially imaged.right port-a-cath tip is in the cavoatrial junction.there are no bone findings of malignancy.
summary: multifocal pneumonia.increased thickening of the posterior right lower lobe pleura with calcification.findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ on ___ at 3:15 p.m.

text: the patient is status post intubation, with tip of endotracheal tube terminating just below the thoracic inlet.there are small mediastinal nodes, however, there is no significant mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy.coronary artery calcification.the heart is normal in size, and there is no pericardial effusion.there is tiny pleural fluid with bilateral lower lobe atelectasis in the dependent portions.in the lung windows, there are faint scar-like opacities in the medial portion of both lobes, without definitive mass or consolidation or suspicious nodule.there is small amount of mucus secretion in the trachea, however, there is no endobronchial lesion to the subsegmental levels.
summary: no ct evidence to suggest primary malignancy in chest, abdomen, and pelvis.diverticulosis.faint opacities in both lungs, dependent atelectasis, without suspicious mass or consolidation or nodule.small mediastinal nodes.sludge or layering milk or bile in gallbladder.enlarged prostate gland with calcification and seeds.nonspecific pancreatic tail hypodense focus, likely tiny cyst or focal fat.

text: on the non-contrast phase, no intramural hematoma is seen.following the administration of iv contrast, pulmonary arteries opacify normally and there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.the aorta is normal in course and caliber.there is no lymphadenopathy in the mediastinum or along the pulmonary hila.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.small bilateral pleural effusions are seen.there is no pericardial effusion.the heart is normal in size and shape.extensive peribronchovascular irregular nodularity is again noted with findings appearing essentially unchanged from the prior ct from approximately 13 days ago.of note, there is marked thickening along the left inferior pulmonary vein, which causes marked luminal narrowing and findings are best seen on series 3, images 53 through 55.similarly on the right, there is marked bronchovascular thickening along the right middle lobe bronchus with complete luminal opacification of the right middle lobe segmental bronchus.additional areas of airway impaction are seen with areas of distal bronchiectasis, which are most notable in the right middle lobe.there is a stable appearance of the peribronchovascular spiculated nodularity seen on series 3, image 65, which measures 12.7 mm in maximal diameter, though its distribution is most compatible with a process involving the airway.there is extension along the left pulmonary vein seen on series 3, image 60, with likely some degree of luminal obstruction seen distal.innumerable areas of tree-in-___ fine nodularity are seen scattered throughout both lungs in a peripheral distribution, which may indicate some degree of mucoid impaction versus atypical infectious process.given the overall stability from prior study despite the interval treatment, findings are concerning for malignancy.bronchoscopy with biopsy is strongly recommended.within the included portions of the upper abdomen, a cirrhotic appearance of the liver is seen which is better assessed on a recent ct abdomen and pelvis from ___.also noted is a small volume of abdominal ascites.bone windows demonstrate no suspicious lytic or blastic osseous lesion.
summary: extensive pulmonary parenchymal abnormalities, described above, grossly stable from recent prior study.given the associated venous and bronchial obstruction caused by soft tissue encasement, the possibility of multicentric neoplasm is a strong concern.correlation with bronchoscopy with biopsy is needed at this time for a more definitive diagnosis.no pulmonary embolism.small bilateral pleural effusions.cirrhotic liver, ascites.findings were posted to the ed dashboard at the time of initial review.

text: multiple lymph nodes are seen in the upper mediastinum, slightly larger compared to the prior ct study.some of the nodes are calcified.there are bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy, also slightly larger than the prior study.the aortic and supraaortic vessels are within normal limits.the cardiac size is within normal limits.there is a new, small subpleural density in the right lower lobe.there are also atelectatic changes in the right lower lobe.
summary: mild increase of mediastinal/axillary lymphadenopathy.stable disease at the abdomen/pelvis.

text: the thyroid gland is unremarkable.there is no axillary or mediastinal lymphadenopathy by ct size criteria.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable.the patient is status post left pneumonectomy with post-surgical changes and soft tissue surrounding the staple lines, unchanged.fluid fills the left pneumonectomy cavity with mild enhancement of the pleural surfaces as previously.no locules of air are noted within the mediastinum or pneumonectomy silhouette to suggest stump compromise.coronary artery calcifications are unchanged.in the right apex, a 9-mm nodule has increased in size compared to the previous examination where it measured 8 mm.no new nodules have appeared.the right lung is otherwise clear.no right pleural effusion is present.the airways are patent down to the subsegmental level.
summary: no foci of infection identified.9-mm right upper lobe nodule has increased in size compared to the previous examination.no new areas of metastasis.unchanged soft tissue thickening surrounding the surgical staples from left pneumonectomy.thickening of the rectal wall is non-specific.clinical correlation is recommended.right renal calyceal diverticulum with layering stones or milk of calcium has increased in size since ___, of uncertain significance.

text: the patient is intubated, endotracheal tube ends 3.9cm above the carina.a nasogastric tube is within the esophagus.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of dissection.contrast bolus timing in the pulmonary artery is suboptimal.additionally, evaluation of the subsegmental pulmonary arteries is limited by atelectasis.within these limitations, there is no filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolism.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are within normal limits.no pathologically enlarged axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph nodes are identified, ranging up to 8 mm in the precarinal station (2b:30).there is no pericardial effusion.no right pleural effusion.there is a small left non-hemorrhagic pleural effusion with complete collapse of the left lower lobe and partial right lower lobe collapse.heterogenous opacities adjacent to the collapsed parenchyma may be due to respiratory motion or atelectasis, but infection cannot be excluded.the upper lung zones are clear.
summary: suboptimal contrast bolus in the pulmonary arterial tree.no filling defect to suggest pulmonary embolism.left lower lobe collapse and partial right lower lobe collapse.adjacent heterogeneous opacities may be due to atelectasis or respiratory motion, but infection cannot be excluded.small left nonhemorrhagic pleural effusion.thin rim-enhancing curvilinear collection in the splenectomy bed.superinfection cannot excluded on imaging.early or partial small bowel obstruction with the transition point at the jejunojejunostomy site.more distal small bowel loops are intermittently dilated with a collapsed terminal ileum and large bowel.reflux of fluid into the afferent loop of the gastric bypass.fibroid uterus.anasarca.fatty liver.findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ (surgery) in person at 11:45am ___ at time of initial review.

text: a tracheostomy tube is in place, unchanged.since the prior study, a metallic stent has been placed in the upper aspect of the neoesophagus.this contains an air-fluid level cranially, and is nearly filled with fluid distally.surrounding the mid portion of the stent is a moderate amount of air, which is likely contained within the lumen of the neoesophagus, although the walls are not well visualized.adjacent low attenuation material within the pleural space is unchanged in size and extent from the prior study.again, multiple surgical drains are in place extending through the inferior posterolateral right chest wall.there is no rim-enhancing collection to suggest the development of a new abscess.the adjacent lung parenchyma again demonstrates atelectasis.since the prior study, a small left pleural effusion has nearly resolved.mild dependent atelectasis is present on the left.an additional linear opacity in the right mid lung is also compatible with atelectasis.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to subsegmental levels.assessment for tracheomalacia is not possible on the single inspiratory images.the heart remains enlarged.there is no pericardial effusion.a right picc terminates in the cavoatrial junction.atherosclerotic calcifications are noted of the coronary arteries, aortic arch and origin of cervical vessels.there is no hilar, mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy by size criteria.while this exam is not optimized for assessment of the abdomen, no new abnormalities are noted in the upper abdomen.again demonstrated is a large simple cyst of the left kidney, with an adjacent smaller hypodensity, cholecystectomy clips, and multifocal diverticula of the colon containing hyperdense material.
summary: stable appearance of periesophageal fluid following stent placement.drains remain within the pleural space, with no interval increase in periesophageal fluid.no periesophageal abscess.adjacent compressive atelectasis.interval near resolution of left pleural effusion.multifocal atelectasis.exam not optimized for assessment of tracheomalacia.colonic diverticulosis without diverticulitis.

text: there is extensive pneumomediastinum predominantly situated around the distal esophagus at the gastroesophageal junction.there is a moderate- to-large sized left pleural effusion with attenuation measurements within those of simple fluid.within this effusion and scattered throughout the hemithorax predominantly in the fissures and at mediastinal reflections, there are soft tissue attenuation foci with rim lucency which are markedly similar to foci noted within the distended stomach.these are highly suspicious for foodstuff.for such findings reference series 3 images #11, 13, 21, 27, 30, 35, 46.there is resultant atelectasis in the compressed left lower lung.there is a small-to-moderate predominantly anteriorly layering pneumothorax.the mediastinum remains midline and there is no ct evidence for tension physiology.there is dependent atelectasis in the right lung which is otherwise unremarkable.at the level of the main pulmonary artery (series 3 image 29) the ascending aorta measures 3.9 cm and the descending aorta measures 3.1 cm.at the aortic hiatus, the aorta measures 3.0 cm.1 cm below the level of the renal artery takeoffs, the abdominal aorta measures 2.3 cm.at the iliac bifurcation the abdominal aorta measures 2.0 cm.the right common iliac artery measures 1.5 cm.the left common iliac artery measures 1.6 cm.there is diffuse non- calcified and calcified plaque throughout the thoracic and abdominal aorta.no penetrating ulcer is identified.there is no dissection flap.no periaortic hematoma is seen.extensive pneumomediastinum is noted adjacent to the distal thoracic aorta at the level of the gastroesophageal junction as described above.there is no bowel wall thickening or end-organ segmental infarction noted.there is a markedly enlarged heterogeneous right lobe of the thyroid.no focal mass lesion is identified.no pathological lymphadenopathy is seen within the chest.the tracheobronchial tree is within normal limits.the heart is grossly normal in size.no definite pericardial effusion is seen.there is baseline coronary artery disease noted.indwelling pacemaker wires are evident with a pacemaker generator in the left upper chest.although not optimized for pulmonary artery evaluation, no definite pulmonary embolism is seen.there is a small splenule.at least two small layering gallstones are evident near the gallbladder neck.the gallbladder is incompletely distended with no wall thickening or adjacent inflammatory reaction.scattered simple cysts are seen in both kidneys.there is no hydronephrosis and the kidneys enhance symmetrically.the remaining solid abdominal organs are unremarkable.no bowel dilatation is evident.there is scattered stool throughout the colon.as noted above, there is no bowel wall thickening or other signs of mesenteric ischemia.no free intraperitoneal fluid or air is seen.an appendix is not definitively identified although no inflammatory changes are noted in the right lower quadrant.imaging of the pelvis is limited by significant streak artifact from an indwelling right total hip prosthesis.the prostate appears moderately enlarged.the bladder is incompletely distended.no pathologic lymphadenopathy is seen in the pelvis.degenerative changes are evident throughout the thoracolumbar spine.no fractures are noted.
summary: findings in the chest are highly concerning for esophageal rupture.this would account for the pneumomediastinum, pleural effusion with apparent internal food stuff, and left pneumothorax.consider oral contrast-enhanced scan for further validation.diffuse atherosclerotic disease of the aorta with no aneurysm, dissection, or acute aortic pathology.cholelithiasis with no evidence of cholecystitis.no obvious bowel pathology.enlarged prostate with mildly distended bladder.correlate clinically.enlarged thyroid.likely goiter.correlate with clinical exam and thyroid biochemical profile.if indicated consider ultrasound for further evaluation.the results were reviewed with the emergency department team immediately upon acquisition and slightly later with the thoracic surgery team.the wet read was posted to the ed dashboard as well.

text: no pulmonary embolism is seen from the main pulmonary arterial trunk to the level of the subsegmental pulmonary arterial vessels bilaterally.a few small mediastinal lymph nodes are identified, however they do not meet criteria for pathologic enlargement.no hilar or axillary lymph node enlargement is seen.a small amount of atelectasis is seen within the right upper lobe.within both lower lobes, there is patchy and nodular areas of consolidation, worse in the right lower lobe.no pleural effusions are seen.the heart and pericardium are normal in appearance.there is the suggestion of a filling defect within the posterior aspect of the superior vena cava in its distal portion, but this is related to the entrance of the azygous vein.bone windows demonstrate no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.the imaged portions of the upper abdomen show no abnormalities.coronal reconstructions: images reconstructed in the coronal plane show no pulmonary embolism.
summary: no pulmonary embolism identified.bilateral lower lobe patchy consolidations, worse on the right consistent with infectious process.apparent filling defect in the posterior aspect of the superior vena cava in its distal portion is related to the entrance point of the azygous vein.no other definite thrombus of the svc can be apprecited on this examination.

text: there is an intramural hematoma of the thoracic aorta extending from the aortic root and continuing throughout the chest into the visualized portion of the upper abdomen.these images extend to immediately below the esophageal hiatus, but not further below.although filling of the celiac and common hepatic arteries is demonstrated on the most inferior images, the abdominal aorta and its major branches cannot be evaluated further by this study, accordingly.there is a primary site of ulceration of the ascending aorta beyond the left branch point to the left carotid artery, but prior to the takeoff of the left brachialcephalic artery.extending from the point of ulceration in both directions is a false lumen with contrast filling which extends proximally toward the aortic root.the calcified left and right coronary arteries fill with contrast, but are at risk as the intramural hematoma extends to their origins.distally, beyond the point of communication between the true and false lumens, the false lumen is seen to extend distally toward the apex of the aortic arch along a distal extent of about 2.5 cm.however, as this is a single phase study in the early arterial phase, the possibility of more distal extent of contrast filling of the false lumen on a slightly longer time scale cannot be excluded on this study.in addition, there is a focus of ulceration with intramural hematoma at the proximal right brachiocephalic artery, immediately prior to the origin of the right carotid, which is surrounded with intramural hematoma that extends distally around the right common carotid.the more superior portion of the imaged right common carotid appears normal, however.the left common carotid and brachiocephalic arteries fill normally with contrast and do not appear involved.intramural hematoma extends to the most superior abdomen, and presumably below the imaged region, which cannot be evaluated here.there is also an additional focus of high density, within the intramural hematoma in the descending portion of the aorta, anteriorly, at the level of the left atrium, associated with a third separate focus of ulceration.the mid proximal ascending aorta has a true lumen of 25 x 32 mm in axial dimensions, and including the hematoma in the wall measures up to 41 x 47 mm axially.at the root the contrast filled true lumen measures 39 x 37 mm at the aortic root.there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.no evidence of pulmonary embolism is identified.there is extensive emphysema bilaterally, and biapical scarring.there are small bilateral pleural effusions, greater on the left than the right, with bibasilar fibrosis, particularly conspicuous at the right base.there is a large hiatal hernia.otherwise, the partially visualized upper abdominal organs are unremarkable.
summary: ulceration with dissection of the ascending thoracic aorta, including intramural hematoma which extends proximally to the aortic root and distally at least as far is the partially visualized upper abdomen.___ type a.extensive emphysema, with bibasilar atelectasis fibrosis and small effusions.a second of focus of focal ulceration in the right brachial cephalic artery with intramural hematoma.third aortic ulceration in the distal ascending aorta.because this is a single phase study, in the early arterial phase, the true extent of the patent false lumen could not be assessed.also, the abdominal extent of the intramural hematoma, may not be entirely imaged.dr.___ was contact___ with the major results at the time of interpretation, and the case was discussed in detail with dr.___ from cardiothoracic surgery.

text: the left pleural effusion demonstrates interval increase, and there has been interval removal of a left chest tube.the posterior and inferiormost aspect of the collection demonstrates a focal pleural enhancement (the split pleura sign).the lateral and superior portion of the pleural fluid collection does not demonstrate pleural enhancement, but is loculated, and demonstrates a small amount of layering on decubitus images.a mediastinal fluid collection abutting the suture line is stable, with interval resolution of several foci of gas, and without peripheral enhancement.no right pleural effusion or pericardial effusion is seen.post-surgical changes within the left lung parenchyma from recent surgery are stable.there are scattered ill-defined areas of ground-glass opacity, consistent with mild hydrostatic edema.no pneumothorax.there are several prominent precarinal lymph nodes within the mediastinum which are stable, and measure up to 7 mm (2a:16).post-surgical changes within the left lateral chest wall are again seen.this study was not designed to evaluate structures below the diaphragm.several hypodensities are seen within the superior aspect of the right kidney, the largest of which measures 3.2 cm (2a:51), and likely represent cysts.the visualized portions of the adrenal glands, spleen, and pancreas are normal.no imaging findings within the osseous structures are suspicious for malignancy.degenerative changes are seen within the thoracic spine.
summary: increase in partially loculated left pleural effusion.posterior and inferiormost aspect demonstrates pleural enhancement (split pleura sign), suspicious for complex exudative effusion such as empyema.anterolateral and superior component of pleural effusion is loculated, but does not demonstrate peripheral enhancement.mild hydrostatic edema.stable mediastinal fluid collection adjacent to operative site.

text: cta of the chest.the pulmonary vasculature does not show filling defects.there is no evidence of thrombi within the pulmonary arteries.there is bilateral pleural fluid on both sides.there are atelectatic changes in both bases.there is no evidence of solid lung lesions.
summary: no evidence of pe.bilateral pleural effusions with atelectatic changes in both bases.

text: endotracheal tube is at the upper margins of the clavicular heads located 6.8 cm above the carina.patient is status post right-sided decortication with two chest tubes in place, one tip terminating at the apex, the other at the lung base.ng tube is seen to the level of the body of the stomach.there are diffuse enlarged mediastinal nodes, significantly bigger than the prior study suggesting a reactive etiology, the largest measuring up to 12 mm in the superior mediastinum.since the prior study, (___) there has been the development of ___ consolidation involving nearly the entirety of the right upper and right lower lobes sparing the anterior segment of the right upper lobe.the consolidation is relatively ___ measuring 30 hounsfield units.there remains a small residual right- sided empyema with thickened enhancing pleura ajacent to consolidation.on the left, there is a small pleural effusion and ajacent consolidation, relatively homogeneous, which might represent aspiration/infectious consolidation.the imaged portion of the upper abdomen is unremarkable within the limitiation of this unenchanced study.no osseous lesions are appreciated.coronal and sagittal reformatted images confirm the above findings.
summary: extensive right-sided consolidation involving nearly the entirety of the right upper and lower lobes; findings consistent with massive aspiration or hemorrhage.rapidly developing pneumonia should also be considered.small residual right-sided empyema.new small left pleural effusion with greater than expected associated atelectasis, raising the possibility of pneumonia on the left as well.prominent mediastinal lymph nodes, likely reactive.

text: in the ten-day interval since the previous exam, there has been rapid progression of a patchy diffuse pattern of ground glass opacities and more confluent areas of consolidation.consolidation is most pronounced at the right lung base.there are also more nodular areas within the lung parenchyma, for example in the left lower lobe laterally, which are new since the previous exam.some of the pulmonary consolidation has a rather linear configuration in the right hemithorax, suggesting this patient may have had prior radiation therapy.the patient is intubated with the tip of the endotracheal tube located approximately 5.5 cm above the carina.there is an ng tube which passes into the stomach.there are two right-sided central venous lines, one of which terminates in the lower svc and the second terminates in the upper right atrium.soft tissue windows demonstrate bilateral pleural effusions, right larger than left, which have increased since the prior study.the heart is enlarged and there are coronary artery calcifications.no pericardial effusion is seen.there is no evidence of pathologically enlarged lymph adenopathy in the mediastinal, hilar or axillary regions.a limited number of images obtained through the upper abdomen demonstrate ascites within the abdomen.there is a wedge-shaped low-attenuation region within the parenchyma of the spleen which has the appearance of a splenic infarct.this was not clearly seen on the patient's previous exam, although that study was performed without iv contrast and, thus, comparison is somewhat limited.numerous calcified gallstones are again seen in the gallbladder.the adrenal glands are unremarkable.note is made of increased attenuation within the soft tissues along the bilateral flanks, likely reflecting third spacing of fluid.once again, note is made of degenerative changes in the spine but no destructive bone lesions are identified.
summary: significant interval worsening of diffuse ground glass and more confluent parenchymal consolidation involving both lungs, with more nodular areas seen currently than on the previous scan ten days ago.increasing bilateral pleural effusions.the interval progression is probably multifactorial including a progressive infectious process, along with either hydrostatic edema or ards.splenic infarct not clearly seen on the patient's previous ct scan.while comparison with that scan is limited as that evaluation was without iv contrast, the splenic infarct is likely new.moderate ascites, unchanged.

text: no pulmonary nodules or masses are detected.low lung volumes and scattered subsegmental atelectasis suggest the study was performed during expiration.there is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.the heart and great vessels are normal.there are no pathologically enlarged thoracic lymph nodes.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to the subsegmental level bilaterally.on this study not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation no abnormality is detected of the upper abdomen.a small 7-mm nodule along the undersurface of the left hemidiaphragm is probably a splenule or non-pathologically enlarged lymph node.no lytic or sclerotic osseous lesions are seen.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary nodule or mass.

text: there is no mediastinal, axillary, or hilar adenopathy.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there are coronary artery calcifications.there is no pleural effusion.the left-sided central catheter tip is in the distal left brachiocephalic vein and appears somewhat more horizontally orientated than on prior chest radiograph.the right upper lobe mass has significantly decreased in size, now measuring 29 x 21 mm (4, 63), compared to 37 x 36 mm on prior.findings are more suggestive of resolving infection than neoplasm.there is emphysema.there is a large hiatal hernia.although this exam is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, limited view of the upper abdomen shows liver cysts and gallstones, which were better seen on recent ct.there is a small right adrenal nodule, the left adrenal is normal.
summary: interval decrease in size of the right upper lobe mass, more suggestive of abscess than neoplasm, follow-up to resolution is recommended.small right adrenal nodule.

text: there are no intraluminal filling defects from the level of the main pulmonary artery through the subsegmental pulmonary arteries.there are multiple pathologically enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes including a 12 x 14 mm pretracheal node and a 12 x 18 mm subcarinal node.the heart and great vessels are within normal limits.there is ground glass opacity within the right middle and lower lobes.several bullae are present within the right lung consistent with given history of copd.the visualized portions of the liver, spleen, and right kidney are within normal limits.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.mediastinal lymphadenopathy.ground glass opacity within the right middle and lower lobes in a somewhat dependent position which may represent aspiration.emphysematous changes.

text: filling defects are demonstrated in the right pulmonary arteries, most predominantly in the right upper lobe pulmonary artery branches and probaly in the subsegmental branches in the right lower lobe pulmonary arteries as well.note is again made of bilateral pleural effusions, atelectasis and patchy air space disease.detailed description pleaese see the prior ct chest obtained several hours ago.3d reconstruction images are consistent with the above findings.
summary: pulmonary embolism as described above.these findings were discussed with the house staff upon completion of the study.

text: the major airways are patent to subsegmental levels bilaterally.the largest pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe (2:26), along an area of atelectasis or scarring now measures 11 mm and is larger since the prior study 8 mm (2:26).previously described pulmonary nodules in the right lung base are larger in size, now measuring 11mm (2:55), previously 8mm.a subtle 3-mm ground-glass opacity in the right lung apex (2:14), subpleural punctate nodules in the right lower lobe (2:37,39,47) are new since the prior study.a thrombus within the left inferior pulmonary vein extending into the right atrium is unchanged in size and extent since the prior study.in comparison to the prior study, there is mild increase in the small- to moderate pericardial effusion.there is no evidence of tamponade.the thoracic aorta and pulmonary arteries are unremarkable.no significant mediastinal, hilar or axillary adenopathy is seen.
summary: mild interval increase in the size of a few right lung pulmonary nodules, and few small new nodules.multiple new sub-centimeter liver lesions, are worrisome for metastatic disease, recommended an ultrasound or mri for further evaluation.no significant interval change in the right nephrectomy bed hematoma, without evidence of recurrent masses.extensive multifocal metastatic disease involving bilateral ribs, right humeral head, right femoral neck, right acetabulum and left sacral ala are unchanged.no new osseous metastatic disease.no significant change in the left inferior pulmonary vein thrombus extending to the margin of the left atrium.

text: since the prior examination, multifocal opacification is now resolved.however, there is now areas of diffusely increased ct attenuation.there is a subpleurally based 7-mm intrapulmonary lymph node in the superior aspect of the right middle lobe (series 4: image 105).the remainder of the lung parenchyma is clear.there has been improvement in hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy.multiple scattered mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes now do not meet size criteria for pathologic enlargement, the largest demonstrated within the subcarinal region measuring up to 7 mm and within the left hilar region measuring up to 6mm.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable with no evidence of pericardial effusion.the central airways appear at the borderline range for pathologic enlargement.there is a rounded area of mucus demonstrated in the dependent portion of the trachea just proximal to the bifurcation measuring 11 x 8 mm (series 4: image 69).this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.there is extensive cholelithiasis without secondary signs of cholecystitis, within the visualized portion of the gallbladder.in addition, there are two subcentimeter hypodensities demonstrated within segment iii of the liver, too small to accurately characterize.the visualized upper abdomen is otherwise unremarkable.

text: the heart, mediastinum, and aorta are unremarkable except for aortic arch calcification, and coronary artery calcification.the dilution of the contrast bolus combined with atelectasis and respiratory motion make evaluation for small segmental/peripheral or small pulmonary embolus difficulty.no large or central pulmonary embolus is seen.there is a small left pleural effusion with associated atelectasis.there is a lesser degree of atelectasis at the right lung base.in the upper lobes bilaterally, a pattern of diffuse ground-glass opacity in a central, peribronchovascular distribution may relate pulmonary edema, but given the history of fever, infectious etiology should be considered.the trachea and bronchi are patent to the subsegmental levels.there is extensive lymphadenopathy, especially in the aorticopulmonary window, where a somewhat necrotic lymph node is seen measuring 2.7 x 1.5 cm (3:32).in addition, the bones demonstrate extensive, diffuse metastases throughout nearly all ribs with adjacent soft tissue component, the scapula, and the near entire thoracic spine.the most severely involved rib is the left fifth rib, which also demonstrates a soft tissue lesion causing compressive atelectasis of the left lower lobe (3:42).spinal metastases are extensive and diffuse, with the t9 vertebral body demonstrating the most severe destruction.osseous structures also demonstrate degenerative change.limited axial images of the upper abdomen demonstrate a nodular, cirrhotic appearing liver.
summary: suboptimal evaluation for pulmonary embolus, as above, although no large, central embolus identified.extensive osseous metastatic disease due to prostate cancer.central interstitial thickening in upper lobes may be due to pulmonary edema, but given fever, also consider infectious source.due to history of malignancy, malignant component is also possible.recommend follow-up to resolution.findings posted to the ed dashboard.

text: there is loculated moderate-sized right pleural effusion.the loculation is seen to extend along the major fissure and mediastinal aspect of the lung.the effusion has enhancing along its parietal surface and contains multiple pockets of gas.these areas of gas could be from recent intervention such as thoracentesis, the result of broncopleural fistula or the result of gas-producing bacteria.these findings should be correlated with clinical history.in the right lung base there is opacity with air bronchogram seen in the area adjacent to the collection.this may be a combination of atelectasis and consolidation.there is a small pleural effusion in the left lung base, which has associated compressive atelectasis.there are also ground-glass opacities seen in the left upper lung.there is biapical pleural scarring.there are secretions seen within the bronchi leading to the right and left lower lobe segments.in the visualized portion of the abdomen there are gallstones.there is also mild central intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation.there are hepatic and renal cysts.on bone windows there is degenerative change and marked scoliosis.however, there are no suspicious lesions.

text: again detected are multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules.these nodules are not significantly changed in appearance and size since the previous ct scan.there is a left-sided pleural effusion with no significant hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.there is no evidence of pulmonary emboli in either lung.in the imaged portion of the abdomen, again detected is a low attenuated splenic lesion, with internal calcification, which appears unchanged in appearance but cannot be measured in all dimensions in this limited examination.the imaged portion of the liver is unremarkable.

text: overall, there has been no marked progression of disease as will be detailed below.there is extensive hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, the majority of which has progressed.for example, a lymph node in the subcarinal station (series 2:31) now measures 3.9 x 3.3 cm (previously 3.6 x 2.9 cm).in addition, a paraesophageal station lymph node (series 2:34) is now increased to 3.1 x 2.4 cm (previously 2.9 x 2.7 cm).the lymphadenopathy extends to the prevascular space station.multiple axillary lymph nodes are nonspecific and do not meet size criteria for pathologic enlargement.the tracheobronchial tree is patent to the subsegmental levels.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable with no evidence of metastatic involvement, though there is compression of the distal right main pulmonary artery by surrounding hilar adenopathy.multiple irregular pulmonary nodules, some of which are hyperenhancing have also progressed indicative of progression of disease.for example, a conglomeration of pulmonary nodules immediately abutting the pleura in the superior segment of the right lower lobe, with the largest representative now mass, measuring 3.8 x 1.9 cm has increased from prior (previously 2.9 x 1.5 cm).multiple other pulmonary nodules scattered throughout all the lungs are grossly unchanged.
summary: interval progression of disease as manifested by interval progression of extensive mediastinal and hilar adenopathy, interval increase in size of several pulmonary nodules, and interval increase in diffuse osseous metastatic involvement, most prominent within the left humerus where an expansile lytic lesion results in associated pathologic fracture.

text: there are segmental and subsegmental pulmonary emboli involving all three upper lobe segmental pulmonary arteries.there is a right interlobar pulmonary artery embolism with extension into the right lower lobe segmental arteries.no pulmonary embolus seen within the left pulmonary arteries.no evidence of right heart strain.the main pulmonary artery is prominent, measuring 3.6 cm in maximal dimension at the bifurcation, but similar to prior.there is mild atherosclerotic calcification of the aortic arch and at the origins of the supra-aortic vessels.there is no evidence of aneurysm or dissection.there is no mediastinal hemorrhage, or pneumomediastinum.there is no mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.unchanged mediastinal lipomatosis and prominent extrapleural fat is likely secondary to steroid therapy.bilateral interlobular smooth septal thickening and peribronchovascular ground-glass opacities are most pronounced within the upper lobes, similar to prior, consistent with cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.
summary: pulmonary emboli within the right upper lobe segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries, as well as the right interlobar pulmonary artery, and segmental right lower lobe pulmonary artery without evidence of right heart strain.unchanged bilateral ground-glass opacities most pronounced in the upper lobes consistent with patient's history of cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.superior endplate compression fracture of l2, new compared to ___.new acute and subacute bilateral rib fractures.

text: there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.there are no nodules, consolidations, or effusions of the lungs.
summary: large retroperitoneal hematoma with active extravasation of contrast from an arteriovenous fistula between the right common iliac artery and the left common iliac vein with pseudoaneurysm formation.thrombosis of the common iliac artery with reconstitution immediately proximal to the bifurcation of widely patent external and internal iliac arteries.embolus into the right anterior tibial artery.these urgent findings were communicated with both ___ ___ of neurosurgery team at 1:30 p.m.and dr.___ of the vascular surgery team at 2:00 p.m.at this time, the patient was already being prepared for surgical intervention by the vascular surgery team.

text: again, the pateint is s/p left pneumonectomy with shift of the mediastinal structures and heart into the left chest with fluid filling the remainder of the left hemithorax.on series 4, image 29, there is a heterogeneous appearance to the posterior pleura.this may represent volume averaging.however, soft tissue thickening cannot be excluded.on the prior exam this region contained some fluid.the heart and great vessels appear grossly normal.of the two preivously reported nodules in the right lower lobe only the more posterior one is identified.this has not changed in size or characteristics.the previously reported nodular pleural thickening is not apparent on today's exam.thoracic osseous structures are unremarakble.sternal wires are noted.
summary: heterogeneous appearance to the left pleura posterior to the heart.previously, this area contained a small amount of fluid.this may represent partial volume averaging.however, a soft tissue component cannot be excluded.recommend attention to this region on follow-up exams.stable right lower lobe nodule.

text: there has been interval improvement in the size and extent of the previously identified right upper lobe nodular airspace opacities along the major fissure, in the right middle lobe, and near resolution of the opacities previously in the right cardiophrenic angle.better appreciated on this study are nodular airspace opacities in the right lower lobe, not clearly imaged on the pet-ct because of technical limitations.these findings are consistent with what is presumably an infectious process.the left lung is clear.a 13 mm x 7 mm right hilar lymph node, probably reactive is unchanged.there are no other pathologically enlarged lymph nodes in the axilla, mediastinum, or left hilum.there is global cardiomegaly with disproportionate left atrial enlargement.heavy calcification of the aortic valve could be hemodynamically significant.atherosclerotic calcification is present in the left anterior descending and left circumflex coronary arteries.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.moderate-size hiatal hernia, a 13-mm cyst in the dome of the liver, and multiple granulomatous liver, left upper quadrant splenule and an interpolar left renal cyst are all unchanged.the imaged portions of the adrenal glands are normal.there are no bone findings of malignancy.

text: no lower cervical adenopathy by size criteria.three-vessel aortic arch.heart size is enlarged with right greater than left hypertrophy.the pulmonary trunk is enlarged measuring 4.3 cm, consistent with known pulmonary artery hypertension.atherosclerotic coronary artery calcifications are noted.there are subcentimeter prevascular lymph nodes, a 12-mm paratracheal lymph node and an 8-mm subcarinal lymph node.no significant hilar adenopathy.there are large right greater than left pleural effusions which are markedly increased from comparison.there is a right upper lobe airspace consolidation which extends into the right middle lobe.bilateral pulmonary edema is noted.normal appearance of the gastroesophageal junction.no suspicious liver lesions.focal fat versus perfusional anomaly adjacent to the falciform ligament.there is a new right inferior pole hypodense region measuring 2.6 x 2.6 cm concerning for additional septic emboli.stable subcentimeter renal cystic lesions are noted bilaterally.normal appearance of the gallbladder, pancreas, spleen, adrenals.ureters are unobstructed.the bladder is drained by a foley catheter with a small amount of gas, likely related to instrumentation within the bladder lumen.small and large bowel are unobstructed without focal wall thickening.osseous structures demonstrate grade 2 anterolisthesis of l4 on l5.there is compression of the t12 vertebral body with hypodensity in the superior endplate region of both the t12 and t11 vertebral body with irregularity of the endplates and 4 mm of retropulsion of the disc.no other areas are concerning for osseous seeding.patient is status post median sternotomy.atherosclerotic aortic disease is noted with complete occlusion of the right common femoral artery with distal reconstitution.appearance is unchanged from comparison.

text: multiple subsegmental filling defects are identified.these are seen in the left anterior and right anterior subsegmental branches as well as in the posterior lower lobe subsegmental branches.there is a suggestion of recanalization of these lower lobe filling defects suggesting chronic pulmonary emboli in these regions, whereas there appears to be some dilatation in the upper lung branches suggesting the possibility of acute emboli.multiplanar reformations confirm these findings.the heart is enlarged.the pericardium and great vessels are normal other than mild aortic calcifications.several sub-cm pretracheal and aorticopulmonary window lymph nodes are seen.there is no axillary lymphadenopathy.marked diffuse bilateral basilar interstitial thickening with ground glass opacification represents interstitial restrictive lung disease.no focal consolidations in the lungs are seen.scarring in the right upper lobe is also seen.kyphosis is noted in the upper thoracic spine.no suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous lesions are seen.the incompletely visualized dome of the liver is normal.
