text: there is a large mass within the left lung abutting the left heart border and invading the mediastinal airway and vascular structures.this mass causes complete collapse of the left upper lobe bronchus and partial collapse of left lower lobe bronchus.measurable solid components measures 8.4 x 5.6 cm (2:25) and 3.1 x 3.1 cm (2:34).this mass compresses the left main pulmonary artery to a diameter of 5 mm (2:21).additionally, the left main stem bronchus is narrowed to 3 mm at the hilum of this invasive mass and adjacent lymphadenopathy.large conglomerate lymph nodes in the subcarinal and right hilar region also causes narrowing of the right bronchus intermedius to 3.5 mm and compression of the right upper lobe bronchus.this right hilar lymphadenopathy measures up to 22 mm.additionally, there is a very large right supraclavicular lymph node measuring 34 x 41 mm.the patient is intubated.just above the level of the carina, lymphadenopathy compresses the trachea to 10 mm x 9 mm.within the remainder of the lung fields, multiple metastatic nodules and masses are identified, the largest within the right middle lobe measuring 28 x 35 mm.there are no significant pleural effusions.the heart is normal in size.as described above, there is significant narrowing of the left main pulmonary artery.there is probable narrowing of the left main pulmonary artery that is compressed between subcarinal and right hilar lymphadenopathy (2:26).there are atherosclerotic calcifications seen within the aorta and coronary arteries.there is a small pericardial effusion.within the imaged portion of the abdomen, the gallbladder is noted to be distended (2:59).additionally, just above the gallbladder is a subtle rounded density, which may represent metastatic lesion measuring 5.1 x 4.7 cm, (series 2:54).this lesion is seen best on liver windows.the imaged portions of the pancreas and spleen are normal.the adrenal glands are thickened, but no focal masses are identified.bone windows show no evidence of suspicious lytic or sclerotic osseous lesions.
summary: large central left lung mass with post-obstructive collapse of left upper lobe and partial collapse left lower lobe.associated large bilateral hilar and mediastinal conglomerate lymph nodes, which encase the airway and the central pulmonary arteries.additional findings of metastatic disease throughout the lungs and a large right supraclavicular lymph node.trachea and bronchi are encased/narrowed by conglomerate nodal disease, with most severe narrowing at left main bronchus proximal to left upper lobe obstruction.oval soft-tissue density structure in gallbladder fossa region, likely a distended, sludge filled gallbladder but solid mass is difficult to exclude.a right upper quadrant ultrasound is recommended to confirm and further characterize this finding.probable discrete mass within the right lobe of the liver superior to the gallbladder fossa.this finding can be evaluated on the right upper quadrant ultrasound to evaluate the gallbladder.

text: no prior study for comparison.correlation was made with multiple recent chest x-rays.there is no pulmonary embolism to the subsegmental level.the first and the second sternotomy wires are broken with multiple free fragments and multiple bone fragments, mostly in the manubrium where there is dehiscence of up to 1.9 cm wide.anterior mediastinal fat is slightly edematous with no collection.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes are enlarged, up to 14 mm in the precarinal region, 11 mm in the prevascular region, 12 mm in the ap window, 15 mm in the upper right paratracheal region, and 22 mm in the subcarinal region.mild aortic valvular calcifications and severe coronary artery calcifications are seen.bilateral pleural effusions are small.free fluid and free air in the upper abdomen are likely due to recent peritoneal dialysis.multifocal peribronchial consolidation and ground-glass opacities are associated with septal thickening and more focal areas of consolidation in the left lower and right lower lobes.airways are patent to the subsegmental level.there is no bone lesion suspicious for malignancy.
summary: broken first and second sternotomy wires with multiple free fragments, multiple bone fragments and minimal stranding of the anterior mediastinal fat, worrisome for osteomyelitis and dehiscence.no collection.no pulmonary embolism to the subsegmental level.mild aortic valvular calcifications and severe coronary artery calcifications.multifocal peribronchial consolidation and ground-glass opacity associated with septal thickening, likely due to pulmonary edema.more focal areas of consolidation in both bases could be due to aspiration, multifocal pneumonia, or atelectasis surimposed on pulmonary edema.ascites and small amount of free air in the upper abdomen, likely due to very recent peritoneal dialysis.small bilateral pleural effusion.multiple mediastinal lymph nodes, could be reactive, should be followed.

text: comparison ___.
summary: unchanged appearance of subcarinal lymphadenopathy, hepatic mass, and numerous sub- 5 mm pulmonary nodules.

text: there are numerous prevascular, mediastinal, and subcarinal lymph nodes, which do not meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.the largest of these appears to be a 1.3-cm node in the subcarinal space.there are bilateral moderate-size pleural effusion.in addition, there appears to be more loculated component to an effusion seen in the left lung base.lung-window images demonstrate compressive atelectatic changes at both lung bases.there is diffuse patchy ground-glass opacification seen throughout both lung fields.no focal consolidation or pneumothorax is seen.ct angiogram demonstrates a normal-appearing aorta within the thorax.the pulmonary artery is dilated, measuring 3.8 cm at the level of the bifurcation.there is no pulmonary embolus.the heart and pericardium are unremarkable, other than coronary calcifications.the visualized portion of the upper abdomen is unremarkable.the osseous structures demonstrate no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.the soft tissues are normal.a central venous catheter is seen with its tip terminating in the mid svc.coronal & sagittal reformatted images confirm the above findings.
summary: no pulmonary embolus.there is evidence of pulmonary arterial hypertension.bibasilar pleural effusions with a more loculated component at the left base.diffuse ground-glass opacification with associated pleural effusion suggests chf.

text: there are extensive atherosclerotic calcifications involving the left anterior descending, left circumflex, and right coronary arteries.a focal area of aneurysmal dilatation of the distal left anterior descending coronary artery is evident, measuring 2.7 x 0.7 cm in the sagittal plane (2:81, 302b:43).the heart is moderately enlarged in size.there is no pericardial effusion.the aorta is normal in caliber and contour.there are no filling defects within the pulmonary arterial vasculature.a tiny linear defect within a right lower lobe subsegemental branch may represent mixing of contrast or other artifact (2:71).the pulmonary artery is enlarged, measuring 3.6 cm in diameter.prevascular lymph nodes measuring 10 and 6 mm in short- axis diameter are evident (2:35).a precarinal mediastinal lymph node measures 10 mm in short- axis diameter (2:34).there are no pathologically enlarged hilar or axillary lymph nodes.there is a small right- sided pleural effusion.lung windows demonstrate extensive septal thickening and diffuse ground-glass changes compatible with pulmonary edema.small hiatal hernia is noted.the imaged portions of the upper abdomen are otherwise unremarkable.there are no suspicious lytic or blastic lesions.
summary: no acute pulmonary embolism.aneurysmal dilatation of the left anterior descending coronary artery.enlarged pulmonary artery, indicative of pulmonary hypertension.evidence of volume overload including small right-sided pleural effusion.extensive coronary artery atherosclerotic calcifications.mediastinal lymphadenopathy, likely reactive.findings regarding the lad aneurysm were discussed with dr.___ ___ by dr.___ on the evening of ___.

text: consolidative right upper lobe findings seen on the pet/ct and prior ct of ___ have improved and the leftsided groundglass areas have resolved.two tiny nonspecific nodules in the left upper lobe are unchanged since scan of ___.there is emphysema and some residual groundglass opacity in the right upper lobe.there are pleural- based soft tissue masses involving the second and third ribs on the right with probable pathologic fracture.the size of these lesions is possibly slightly smaller than on the prior chest ct, though it is difficult to measure given its orientation along the rib.2 distinct areas of nodularity of the pleura, anteriorly and posteriorly, are relatively unchanged since the prior examination.there are no new areas of involvement identified.small pretracheal and small subcarinal lymph node is unchanged.there are no new enlarged lymph nodes seen.there is emphysema.small hypodense lesion in segment iii of the liver is identified and not fully characterized.this is not larger than on the prior examination.renal cysts are again noted bilaterally.no adrenal masses are seen.no additional bony lesions are seen.

text: the left main stem bronchus is narrowed.distal to this, there is consolidation and atelectasis within the left upper as well as the left lower lobe and lingula.small amount of pleural fluid with fluid tracking into the fissure.there is mild leftward mediastinal shift.several high right paraesophageal/paratracheal lymph nodes are enlarged, the largest measuring 11 mm (2:8).there is a 9-mm paracardial lymph node as well.the left hilum cannot be incompletely evaluated.the right hilum is unremarkable.the main pulmonary artery is enlarged, measuring 3.6 cm.with the exception of apical pleural parenchymal scarring and atelectasis of the right middle lobe, the right lung is clear.the thyroid gland is partially imaged but unremarkable.the main pulmonary artery is mildly enlarged measuring 3.6 cm.mitral annular calcifications as well as coronary artery disease are noted.though not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, the visualized portions of the upper abdomen including segments of the liver, spleen and pancreas are unremarkable.

text: there is a small left anterior pneumothorax.there is a tiny right-sided pneumothorax.a left-sided chest tube is in appropriate position.the heart and great vessels appear unremarkable.there is no evidence for aortic dissection or transsection.there is no free extravasation of contrast into the thorax.please note that a ct was done at an outside institution 3.5 hours earlier.the finding on outside exam that was suspicious for a traumatic aortic injury likely relates to cardiac and respiratory motion during the ct scan.the lungs appear clear.there is no significant axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.there is no shift of the mediastinum from the midline.ct abdomen without and with contrast: there is a laceration of the right hepatic lobe with puddling of contrast.there is a subcapsular hematoma which appears to be contained at this time.the appearance is unchanged from earlier exam.the gallbladder, spleen, pancreas, adrenals and kidneys appear to be within normal limits.normal bilateral nephrograms are demonstrated.there is high- attenuation fluid within the abdomen and pelvis which is consistent with hemoperitoneum.there is no significant mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.the non- opacified loops of large and small bowel appear grossly normal.bone windows demonstrate no evidence for fracture.the above findings were confirmed with the coronal and sagittal reformations.
summary: no evidence for traumatic aortic injury.small left-sided pneumothorax with appropriately positioned chest tube.tiny right-sided pneumothorax.laceration of the right hepatic lobe with puddling of contrast.there is a subcapsular hematoma which is contained at this time.high-attenuation fluid within the abdomen and pelvis is identified which is consistent with hemoperitoneum.the above findings were discussed with the surgery trauma resident at the time of the examination.

text: there is dependent atelectasis in the lungs bilaterally, without consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax.there is no evidence of pulmonary contusion or laceration.there are two small, 3-4 mm pulmonary nodules, one identified in the right lower lobe (2:27) and a second in the right middle lobe (2:34).there are no further pulmonary nodules or masses present.the heart is notable for coronary calcifications, without pericardial effusion.the aorta and great vessels are normal in caliber and configuration without evidence for acute aortic injury.main pulmonary artery is normal in caliber, and there is no large central pulmonary embolus.there is no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy.the esophagus appears normal.the trachea and central airways are widely patent.the thyroid enhances normally.there is no supraclavicular or axillary adenopathy.in the visualized upper abdomen, there is no acute abnormality identified.hypodense lesions in the kidneys bilaterally are unchanged from prior abdominal ct, and are compatible with benign cysts.there are no adrenal nodules or masses.small hypodense liver lesions are also present, and also stable.there are postsurgical changes from prior cholecystectomy and prior billroth.there is no free abdominal fluid or free air identified.
summary: minimally displaced right lateral seventh rib fracture, as seen on chest x-ray.pulmonary nodules as above.if at low risk for malignancy, no further follow-up is needed.if at high risk, follow-up in 12 months should be performed.coronary artery calcification.incidental in the upper abdomen, including small hypodense liver lesions, not fully characterized, bilateral renal cysts, and post-surgical changes from prior billroth and cholecystectomy.

text: there is interval resolution of the previously demonstrated substernal fluid collections with residual stranding consistent with post-op change.multiple median sternotomy wires are demonstrated and appear to be intact.bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (right worse than left) and multiple prominent mediastinal lymph nodes are unchanged, including a 27 x 17 mm subcarinal node, and a 10 x 19 mm precarinal node.the thoracic aorta appears intact.there is interval decrease in a right-sided pleural effusion with mild residual pleural effusion.there is a 3.5 mm nodule in the right upper lobe that appears to be present on the previous study, although it is less well demonstrated, probably due to slice selection.there is a 2 mm right upper lobe nodule and a vague left upper lobe nodule (series 2 image 29) that are stable.there is dependent atelectasis.additionally, there is a 1-2 mm right lower lobe nodule (series 2, image 25) that is probably stable compared to ___.there is a possible minimal pericardial effusion.limited images of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.bone windows reveal no suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions.the midline sternal defect from the sternotomy is still well visible.
summary: no substernal abscess.there is interval resolution of the previously demonstrated substernal collections.bilateral hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy that is stable.differential diagnosis includes reactive nodes, lymphoma, and sarcoid.multiple sub 5 mm pulmonary nodules are probably stable.followup by ct is recommended.

text: patient is status post esophagectomy with stomach pull-through procedure.there are multiple staples and sutures along the surgical sites.there is a small retained fluid within the mediastinal stomach.there is a small outpouching in the proximal mediastinum of the stomach (5:71) that appears contiguous with the stomach.there is no good evidence for leak.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.the heart and great vessels in the mediastinum are within normal limits though note is made of dense coronary artery calcifications.the pulmonary arteries opacify normally without filling defects.the evaluation for small subsegmental pulmonary emboli is limited secondary to contrast bolus timing.there is no pathologic adenopathy.there is a small loculated right pleural effusion containing multiple foci of air.a larger but yet still very small collection of pleural air is noted along the right anterior base.there is a small left pleural effusion that does not appear loculated.there is bilateral atelectasis.there is a small amount of residual free intraperitoneal air along the anterior midline associated with 6.6-cm fluid collection that likely represents post-operative seroma.there is no rim enhancement.there is confluent ossification along the left side of the thoracic vertebral body with relative preservation of the intervertebral discs, consistent with dish.no suspicious lesions are identified.there is a port-a-cath on the right side with the tip terminating in the distal svc.there are surgical staples overlying the neck and abdomen.
summary: small loculated right hydropneumothorax.small layering left pleural effusion.bilateral atelectases.no evidence for pulmonary embolism.free intraperitoneal air and fluid, all likely post-operative, though evaluation for a perforated viscus is thus suboptimal.if there is clinical concern for perforation, gastrografin contrast can be orally administered and the patient can be rescanned to evaluate for contrast extravasation.

text: the soft tissue window images reveal no significant axillary, mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy.there is extensive calcification of the aortic arch and the descending aorta.coronary calcification is also noted.there are no pleural or pericardial effusions.there is a 1 x 1.5 cm well circumscribed mass in the right lower lobe.it measures about 10 ___.it has smooth margins without evidence of spiculations.some bilateral basilar pleural thickening and plaques are also visualized.there are no filling defects seen within the pulmonary vasculature.the lung window images reveal no areas of consolidation.the airways appear patent to the level of segmental bronchi bilaterally.in the imaged portion of the upper abdomen, the visualized portion of the liver and spleen appear unremarkable.there are no suspicious lytic or blastic lesions in the osseous structures.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.1 x 1.5 cm mass in the right lower lobe.in the absence of spiculated margins and lymphadenopathy along with a density of 10 ___, this mass likely represents a bronchogenic cyst.

text: the heart is normal in size.there is no mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy.the airways are patent to level of subsegmental bronchi.the previously noted right lower lobe nodule measuring 3 mm is stable while the right basilar nodule measuring 4 mm noted on the prior study is thought to represent atelectasis.a 3-mm right lower lobe nodule (4:123), a 4- mm left lower lobe nodule (4:160), and a 6-mm ground-glass opacity at the left apex (4:33) are unchanged in comparison to the prior study.no pleural effusions or pneumothorax is identified.no lytic or sclerotic lesions within the bones are noted.incidentally noted is a hook like appearance of the xiphoid process.although the study was not designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, again noted is soft tissue density in the region of the right perinephric bed adjacent to loops of bowel which is unchanged in appearance compared to a prior ct of the abdomen dated ___.

text: the great vessels are unremarkable without evidence of aortic dissection, aneurysm, or pulmonary embolism.the visualized portion of the thyroid is unremarkable.no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymph nodes.the heart and mediastinum are slightly shifted rightward, but are otherwise unremarkable.the pericardium is intact without effusion.a large low-density left pleural effusion is present with near-complete compressive atelectasis of the left lung and slight rightward shift of the mediastinal structures.nonspecific ground-glass opacity is seen in the right upper lobe.the right lung is otherwise clear.the central airways are clear.the upper abdominal organs are unremarkable.
summary: large left pleural effusion with near-complete compressive atelectasis of the left lung and slight rightward mediastinal shift.nonspecific ground-glass opacity in right lung apex.numerous bilateral subacute-appearing rib fractures.

text: opacification of the pulmonary vasculature demonstrates filling defects in the distal right main pulmonary artery with extension to the right upper lobe, right middle lobe, and right lower lobe segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries.otherwise, no distinct filling defects are noted on the left.the intraventricular septum remains slightly convex towards the right ventricle.multiple prominent mediastinal lymph nodes are visualized and reach up to 17 mm in short axis in the right paratracheal station (3:11).additionally, soft tissue at bilateral hila is suggestive of lymphadenopathy.there is, however, no axillary lymphadenopathy by ct size criteria.the heart is normal in size and without a pericardial effusion.there are bilateral small nonhemorrhagic pleural effusions.while the airways appear patent to the subsegmental levels on the right, there is a large left hilar mass with extension to all segments of the left lung with circumscription and narrowing of the left main stem bronchus as well as the left upper and lower lobe bronchi.there is complete collapse of the left lower lobe.additionally, peribronchial soft tissue is visualized throughout the right upper lobe along with interstitial nodularity and consistent with lymphangitic carcinomatosis.while the lung mass is difficult to delineate, areas of hypodensity within the collapsed left lower lobe is suggestive of tumor.there is a focal consolidation is noted in the right lower lobe (3:43), which may be representative of developing pneumonia versus an infarction given the pulmonary emboli.there is a 5 x 3 mm right lower lobe nodule (4:80) as well as a 3 x 3 mm right lower lobe nodule (4:111).additionally, there is thickening along the right anterior pleura (4:41) which may be representative of pleural metastases.
summary: acute pulmonary embolus in the right main pulmonary artery with extension to the right upper, right middle, and right lower lobe segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries.additionally, there is a focal opacity in the right lower lobe which can be representative of a developing infarct versus a developing pneumonia.large left perihilar mass with extension and circumscription to all lobes of the left lung and complete collapse of the left lower lobe.additionally, hypodense foci within the collapsed left lower lobe are highly suggestive of tumor.evidence of lymphangitic carcinomatosis is visualized in the left upper lobe.hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy is associated with this tumor.two right lower lobe nodules which may be representative of metastatic foci, but are of unclear etiology.additionally, there is thickening of the anterior right pleura, which may be representative of a metastatic focus.bilateral small pleural effusions.although severely limited evaluation of the abdominal structures, the non-opacified visualized portion of the upper abdomen demonstrates a hypodensity in the right lobe of the liver which may be representative of a metastatic focus.further characterization with a dedicated abdominal study is recommended.

text: bilateral pleural effusions and associated atelectasis are greater on the right than the left.there is associated volume loss on the right, with segmental collapse.the right lower lobe bronchus remains patent.the trachea and left bronchi are patent to the subsegmental level.the aorta and its branches and the coronary arteries demonstrate heavy calcifications.the heart, aorta, and great vessels are otherwise unremarkable.there is mild thyroid enlargement without a discrete thyroid nodule identified.there is no supraclavicular, axillary, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.there is a soft tissue mass involving the right rotator cuff muscles and causing erosion into the right humeral head, which demonstrates pathologic fracture.there is no apparent involvement of the glenoid fossa.
summary: soft tissue metastases with bony erosion and pathologic fracture involving the right humeral head, right femoral head and acetabulum, and left acetabulum.lytic lesions without definite cortical breakthrough involving left femoral head.bilateral pleural effusions, right greater than left, with associated atelectasis and volume loss.no lymphadenopathy in the chest, abdomen, or pelvis.left adrenal adenoma.bilateral renal cysts.significant atherosclerotic disease involving the aorta and its branches.

text: the patient has had left pneumonectomy.nonhemorrhagic fluid fills the pneumonectomy space, and there is no mural nodularity, air, or evidence of expansion of the space.a small amount of thrombus in the transected left main pulmonary artery is not unusual after pneumonectomy.the bronchial stump, hilus and adjacent mediastinum have normal postoperative appearances.the heart and great vessels are otherwise unremarkable.a non-hemorrhagic pericardial effusion is small.no mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymph nodes are pathologically enlarged by ct size criteria.the pulmonary arteries are patent to the subsegmental level.the right lung is clear; there is no right pleural effusion.although this examination was not intended for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, the partially imaged abdomen is unremarkable.
summary: expected postoperative changes following pneumonectomy.no evidence of metastases or recurrence.

text: the thoracic aorta maintains a normal caliber and contour.the heart size is normal.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.no mediastinal or axillary lymphadenopathy is appreciated.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.patchy opacities in the dependent portion of the lower lobes is consistent with atelectasis.14 mm nodular ground-glass opacity in the left lung base (2:32) may reflect small contusion.there is a small air collection in the left lower lung adjacent to the displaced 8th rib fractures, which likely represents a pulmonary laceration.
summary: multiple left rib fractures, including segmental fractures in ribs ___.small loculated air collection adjacent to the displaced 8th rib fracture, likely represents a small pulmonay laceration.multifocal left renal cortical thinning is likely a sequela of prior infection.note is made of a duplicated left collecting system with ureters that unite distally in the pelvis.no evidence of intrabdominal parenchymal organ injury.

text: the patient is status post bentall procedure and replacement of the ascending aorta and hemiarch with a dacron graft.there is stable post-surgical appearance of the ascending thoracic aorta.mild periaortic soft tissue is seen in the region of the ascending aorta (2:18), this likely represents post-surgical scarring.there is no evidence of mediastinal fluid collections.moderate coronary arterial calcification and a non-opacified plaque are seen within the descending thoracic aorta and distal portion of the arch.the ascending thoracic aorta now maximally measures 3.3 cm.the imaged portion of the brachiocephalic left common carotid and left subclavian arteries at its origin are unremarkable except for mild atherosclerotic calcification.the heart and pericardium are normal, without evidence of pericardial effusions.the major airways are patent up to subsegmental levels bilaterally.mild scarring is seen within the right upper lobe (2:20), stable since the prior study.no pulmonary nodules, focal consolidation or pleural effusion is detected.there are scattered mediastinal lymph nodes, which do not meet ct criteria for significant adenopathy.
summary: status post bentall procedure and replacement of ascending thoracic aorta and hemiarch using dacron graft.mild periaortic soft tissue density suggests post-surgical change.no fluid collections are evident.there is no pericardial effusion.right renal cortical cyst and right external iliac lymph node, are stable since prior study.

text: no filling defect is noted within the main pulmonary artery and its subsegmental branches to suggest pulmonary embolism.the aorta has normal appearance.the coronary arteries are patent.the heart has normal appearance.the soft tissue windows do not demonstrate any pathologically enlarged hilar, mediastinal, or axillary lymph nodes, the largest node is noted in the anterior paratracheal space and measures 6 mm in short axis.the lung windows do not demonstrate any pulmonary nodule.no pleural effusion is noted.dependent atelectatic changes are noted at both lung bases.mild hyperinflation of the right lower lobe is noted.visualized portions of the upper abdomen including dome of the liver and spleen appear unremarkable.the patient is status post cholecystectomy with surgical clips noted within the gallbladder fossa.

text: mdct-axillary acquired imaging from the lung apices to the pubic symphysis displayed with 5-mm slice thickness with oral and iv contrast.coronal and sagittal reformations have been provided.
summary: no evidence of metastatic disease.there is diverticular change noted of the sigmoid colon without evidence for active diverticulitis.incidental subcutaneous nodule in the right axilla - clinical correlation recommended.

text: there has been interval resolution of the previously described bilateral pleural effusions.the area of consolidation within the left lower lobe has similarly resolved.biapical scarring with a few tiny nonspecific noncalcified nodular densities are present right greater than left and stable since prior exam of ___.linear densities consistent with atelectases in lingula and bilateral mild bronchiectasis, as previously demonstrated.a new ill- defined peribronchiolar opacity is seen within the left upper lobe (3:33).no other pulmonary opacities, pulmonary nodules, or pleural effusions are identified.the heart size is normal.there are coronary artery calcifications.the great vessels appear within normal limits.no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes are identified.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level.in the imaged upper abdomen, the liver demonstrates diffuse low attenuation consistent with fatty infiltration.the remainder of the visualized upper abdomen appears unremarkable.no osseous findings suspicious for malignancy are identified.

text: the thyroid gland is symmetric in appearance.the aorta and major branches are patent with normal three-vessel arch.the mediastinum is unremarkable.the heart and pericardium are normal, without pericardial effusion.the patient is intubated with endotracheal tube in appropriate position 4.9 cm above the carina.the trachea and central airways are patent to the segmental level.nasogastric tube courses through the esophagus into the stomach.there is mild right lower lobe and moderate left lobar consolidation which could reflect atelectasis or aspiration.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.
summary: left greater than right lower lobar opacification likely reflects atelectasis, although an element of aspiration, particularly on the left, cannot be excluded.no additional acute intrathoracic, abdominal, or pelvic process to explain the patient's circumstance.

text: there is a 26 x 25 mm right hilar lymph node/mass.no other significant adenopathy with scattered axillary and mediastinal lymph nodes not meeting size criteria for pathologic enlargement.no left hilar adenopathy.atherosclerotic calcification is noted within the coronary arteries and the thoracic aorta.the heart and great vessels are, otherwise, unremarkable.there is no evidence pericardial effusion.there are multiple scattered areas of ground-glass opacification with an upper lobe predominance that is nonspecific and could relate to infectious or inflammatory etiologies.in addition, there is right basilar patchy opacification with either mucus/aspirated material seen within the right lower lobe segmental bronchi that in this setting is concerning for aspiration.no discrete pulmonary nodules are noted.there is no evidence of pleural effusions.there is no evidence of acute aortic syndrome.there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism to the subsegmental levels.
summary: new scattered ground-glass opacification with upper lobe predominance, nonspecific, could be related to infectious or inflammatory etiologies.2.5 x 2.6 cm right hilar lymph node/mass.differential includes neoplasm or may be reactive in nature, recommend bronchoscopy to exclude neoplasm.expected post-surgical change status post puestow procedure.extensive pancreatic calcifications compatible with known chronic pancreatitis.likely right lower lobe aspiration.findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ at 2:30 p.m.on ___.

text: since most recent fdg examination, and most recent ct examination dating back to ___, there has been interval increase in size in area of spiculated right upper lobe apical density measuring up to 25 x 23 mm that has been recently demonstrated to show increased fdg avidity.this area of opacification is seen contiguous to the right hilus (3:17).geographic paramediastinal peribronchial opacification extending infrahilarly to the right lower lobe, grossly unchanged since ___, is radiation fibrosis.increased, moderate, multiloculated pleural fluid has paraspinal, fissural, and paracostal regions.nodular peribronchial wall thickening involving the right main stem bronchus is unchanged.the airways are patent, though there is post-treatment associated bronchiectasis involving the right upper and lower lobes.the right lung, otherwise is unremarkable with no new pulmonary nodules.the left lung remains well aerated with no pulmonary nodules, mass, or focal consolidation.there is increased loculated fluid on the left seen tracking along the major fissure and in a paraspinal location, overall, mild in extent.extensive mediastinal lymphadenopathy is grossly unchanged with the largest being a precarinal lymph node measuring up to 11 mm (2:18) and a right upper paratracheal lymph node (2:10) measuring up to 6 mm.there has been slight enlargement of a left hilar lymph node now measuring 11 mm where on prior examination it measured 8 mm.the aorta and pulmonary trunk is of normal caliber, though redemonstrated is extensive atherosclerotic calcification involving the entire aorta, he left subclavian artery, and all of the coronary arteries.heart is within normal limits in size with no pericardial effusion.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.the visualized portions of the abdomen are unremarkable.
summary: continued progession of fdg-avid area of irregular contoured opacification centered in the right upper lobe raises concern for malignancy.this area is accessible to transthoracic needle biopsy.however, confluency of opacification with stable paramediastinal radiation changes extending infrahilarly makes the opacification involving the right upper lobe, raises the slim possibility this is tumescent radiation fibrosis.interval increase in size of loculated pleural fluid, now moderate in extent on the right and mild on the left seen fissurally, paraspinal and pericostally.stable known extensive atherosclerotic calcification.grossly, stable mediastinal and hilar adenopathy, and stable peribronchial right main stem soft tissue nodularity.

text: soft tissue window images demonstrate no pathologically enlarged mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymphadenopathy.no pleural effusions are seen.the heart and pericardium are normal in appearance.lung window images demonstrate a 3 mm nodule in the right upper lobe.no other pulmonary nodules or parenchymal consolidation are seen.airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi bilaterally.
summary: there has been interval improvement in the areas of decreased contrast enhancement noted within the left kidney, consistent with pyelonephritis seen on the prior exam.however, there are small focal residual areas of decreased attenuation, which raises the possibility of residual versus resolving areas of infection, and continued follow up clincal evaluation for urinary tract infection is recommended.3 mm nodule seen in the right upper lung zone.further follow up evaluation is recommended.no other interval change from the prior exam.

text: as seen previously, there is a large defect in the right posterolateral thoracic chest wall with surgical packing in this area.there is right-sided volume loss from partial right lung resection.bilateral small pleural effusions are noted, and there is associated left-sided dependent atelectasis.there is a small pericardial effusion.the heart is upper limits of normal in size.a subpleural nodular opacity in the right upper lobe is unchanged.there is improvement in the previously seen consolidation layering posteriorly along the major fissure within the left upper lobe.there is diffuse patchy ground glass opacity and mild interlobular septal thickening suggestive of mild pulmonary edema.there is no change to the previously noted small mediastinal lymph nodes.no pneumothorax is seen.a tracheostomy tube is noted to be well positioned within the trachea.there is a left-sided picc line with its tip in the superior vena cava.no abnormalities are seen within the imaged portions of the upper abdomen.incidental note is again made of left-sided thyroid nodule.
summary: no pulmonary embolism identified.bilateral pleural effusions, improved on the left since the previous exam.small pericardial effusion, slightly greater than seen previously.marked improvement in consolidation/aspiration seen dependently along the major fissure within the left upper lobe.no change to peripheral subpleural nodular opacity in the right upper lobe.findings suggestive of mild pulmonary edema.

text: ill-defined soft tissue and fluid density is seen within the mediastinum extending subcarinally which may represent post-operative changes.there is a large right apical hydropneumothorax.there is mucous plugging of the right middle lobe bronchus with associated right middle lobe atelectasis.mucous plugging is also seen within several right lower lobe bronchi with associated atelectasis.there is abrupt termination of a right middle lobe artery (series 6, image 24).there are small bilateral pleural effusions and irregular right-sided pleural thickening.while this study is not dedicated for evaluation of pulmonary embolus, within the left upper lobar artery, there is a filling defect.while somewhat atypical in appearance, this is consistent with pulmonary embolus.lung windows reveal a patchy ill-defined opacity within the left upper lobe which may be infectious or inflammatory in nature.visualized portions of the upper abdomen demonstrate a large splenic infarct.osseous structures demonstrate a suspicious lytic focus within the l1 vertebral body.
summary: status post right upper lobe resection.large right apical hydropneumothorax.ill-defined soft tissue and fluid density is seen within the mediastinum tracking subcarinally likely post-operative, residual tumor cannot be excluded.mucus plugging of right middle and right lower lobe bronchi with complete right middle lobe and near complete right lower lobe atelectasis.atypical filling defect within left upper lobar pulmonary artery consistent with pulmonary embolus.large splenic infarct.findings discussed with dr.___ on ___.

text: the pulmonary arteries are well visualized up to the first segmental level showing no pe.beyond that the opacification is faint and so no peripheral pe can be excluded.the aorta is unremarkable in size, showing no evidence of dissection or aneurysmal dilatation.stable coronary calcifications are again seen.the heart size is within normal limits.mitral annular valve calcification is stable there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.the lungs have relatively cleared as previously there was diffuse tree-in-___ nodularity, indicative of an infectious process.however, there are persistent prominent lymph nodes in the mediastinum and hilar areas stable to slightly increased in size on today's examination.for example, the subcarinal lymph node which is 9.3 mm is stable in size while the 5.4-mm left prevascular lymph node was previously 4.6 mm in size.mitral annular valve calcification is stable.new minimal bibasilar atelectasis is seen in both lung fields.the bony structures do not show any lesion suspicious for malignancy, however, there are significant disc osteophyte complexes seen at multiple thoracic vertebral body levels better appreciated in the sagittal reformatted images.in the abdomen, stable subcentimeter right adrenal adenoma is noted.no other abnormalities are seen.
summary: negative examination for pe in the major and first segmental branches.almost complete resolution of the infectious process seen in both lungs.persistent but slightly increased bilateral lymphadenopathy.stable pulmonary artery calcifications.stable right adrenal adenoma.

text: there are probably multiple enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes, although beam hardening artifact from patient's pacemaker limits assessment somewhat.there is a 9 mm prevascular lymph node anterior to the ascending aorta.the esophagus appears dilated with fluid/debris level at the level of the aortic arch.there is a 4.0 x 5.4 cm collection in the posterior mediastinum on the left behind the left atrium which appears to be contiguous with the esophagus and demonstrates a fluid/debris level.an additional rounded low density area measuring 15 mm is seen at the level of the ge junction.there is a small left pleural effusion.there is no right pleural effusion or pericardial effusion.there is dense consolidation in the left upper lobe.no obstructing mass is identified.there is diffuse intralobular septal thickening and superimposed ground-glass opacity.limited assessment of the upper abdomen shows splenomegaly and multiple calcified granulomas in both the liver and spleen.right hilar lymph nodes are also present.bone windows show severe scoliotic changes in the thoracic spine.there are multiple healed right rib fractures.
summary: large area of consolidation in left upper lobe consistent with lobar pneumonia.superimposed congestive heart failure.large 5.4 cm fluid/debris collection in the posterior mediastinum.this is adjacent to the esophagus and appears contiguous, and is most likely an epiphrenic diverticulum.differential diagnosis would include a focal pleural abscess which is considered less likely.this could be confirmed via barium esophogram.

text: a small non-mass-like opacity is noted at the left lung apex and may be due to volume averaging, but a very small focus of atelectasis or pulmonary contusion is not excluded.there is no pneumothorax.there are equivocal non-displaced left second thru sixth posterior rib fractures; correlation with physical examination is recommended.small calcified nodules are noted in the lungs, likely related to prior granulomatous infection.the heart and great vessels are unremarkable without pericardial effusion.there is no evidence of aortic injury.there is no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy meeting ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.gynecomastia is noted.
summary: no acute intra-abdominal or pelvic injury.possible atelectasis versus very small pulmonary contusion or hemorrhage at the left lung apex.however, these findings may represent volume averaging and given the small size of the opaciy, are of doubtful significance.multiple fractures involving the left scapula, humerus and clavicle.please see dedicated left upper extremity radiographs for better evaluation of the humeral fracture.equivocal non-displaced left posterior 3rd through 6th rib fractures.cholelithiasis.findings were discussed with dr.___ ___ at the time of interpretation on ___.

text: several areas of patchy opacification are seen within the right middle, right lower, left lower, and left upper lobes.these may represent areas of aspiration or possibly developing infection.bibasilar atelectasis and consolidation is present, increased from the prior examination.previously seen pleural effusions are decreased on this examination.a small left pleural effusion remains.no pneumothorax is seen.there are dense calcifications of the aorta.no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are seen.a left-sided central line terminates within the superior vena cava.the airways are patent to the segmental level.
summary: patchy opacifications in the lungs with more consolidation in the bases could represent aspiration or developing multifocal infectious process.unchanged position of pigtail catheters within two distinct intra-abdominal fluid collections.these fluid collections are both decreased in size.no evidence of new abscess formation.

text: there is no central pe.subsegmental evaluation is limited; however, there is no substantial pe.largest lymph node in the subcarinal station measures 13 mm in shortest axis.additional lymph nodes in the left hilar region measure up to 11 mm (3:49 and 3:53).the left lung is essentially clear.almost the entire right lung, particularly the right middle and lower lobes, but also the anterior and posterior segments of the upper lobe, is densly opacified by a large irregular area of heterogeneously enhancing tissue extending from the hilus out to the periphery of the lung where it marginates irregularly with a small area of residually aerated upper lobe.endobronchial secretions/tumor infiltrate within multiple segmental bronchi of the right side is apparent with areas hyperdense material within the bronchus (4:90).there is a small right-sided pleural effusion.there is an abrupt cut-off the right secondary bronchi, specifically the right middle lobe bronchus.the exam is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation however, no gross abnormalities are noted.
summary: no evidence of pulmonary embolism.heterogeneously enhancing tissue involving all lobes of the right lung consistent with tumor invasion.multiple lytic lesions and rib fractures consistent with metastatic disease.

text: the heart and great vessels of the chest opacify well.there is no evidence of aortic aneurysm or dissection.there is no mediastinal hematoma.there is no pericardial fluid.there is no pathologic mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.a small 2-cm area of consolidation of the anteromedial right lower lobe is consistent with contusion.there is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
summary: nondisplaced fractures of the lateral eleventh and twelfth right ribs.small 2-cm area of pulmonary contusion of the anteromedial right lower lobe.no intra- abdominal traumatic injury.er dashboard wet read placed at 1:40 a.m.on ___.the final report was discussed with dr.___ ___ at 10:20am ___.

text: the patient has undergone interval stent placement with a new stent extending from the aortic arch to the mid thoracic aorta.there is no evidence for endoleak, and the aortic lumen conforms to the stent.the end of the stent is in the eccentric area of a saccular dilation measuring up to 5 cm in maximal transverse diameter and 4.5 cm in the ap attraction, unchanged (3:35).again seen just superior to the grafted ascending aorta is a focal ectasia, unchanged., measuring 4.6 cm x 3.6 cm in transverse diameter.the grafted ascending aorta is normal caliber.the distance from the distal stent to the celiac artery bifurcation is approximately 10 cm.lung windows demonstrate multiple patchy ground-glass opacities that could represent infection in the proper clinical setting.no pathologic adenopathy is identified.the heart is mildly enlarged with mild-to-moderate right atrial enlargement, unchanged.
summary: status post aortic arch, a stent placement.otherwise, unchanged appearance of markedly tortuous aorta post-ascending aorta graft replacement and focal ectatic thoracic aorta components as described above.interval placement of left ureteral stent with decompression of dilated left renal pelvis.note of moderate stenoses major aortic branches including the celiac, sma, and right renal artery.

text: the patient is intubated with the tip ending in the mid trachea.there is a large right-sided goiter.there is no evidence of pneumomediastinum, mediastinal hemorrhage, pericardial or pleural effusion.there is no pneumothorax.there is opacification of the apical and anterior segment of the right upper lobe as well as opacities in both left lower lobes, likely consistent with atelectasis, less likely pneumonia or contusion.there are also atelectatic changes surrounding the descending aorta.
summary: no evidence of acute process of the chest, abdomen and pelvis.right upper lobe atelectasis, less likely contusion or pneumonia.no evidence of acute fractures.chronic transverse fracture of the right l3 vertebral body.

text: widespread multifocal ground-glass opacities, worst at the upper lobe (2:94, 204b:20, 25), is most compatible with multifocal pneumonia.alternatively, these could represent hemorrhage.there is no pleural effusion.the airways are patent to the subsegmental levels.the great vessels are normal in caliber.there is no aortic dissection.due to suboptimal contrast timing and severe motion-related artifacts, the subsegmental pulmonary arterial branches are not well visualized, but no pulmonary embolus is detected to the segmental levels.there is no hilar, mediastinal, or axillary lymphadenopathy.the heart size is normal, and there is no pericardial effusion.there is no acute fracture.there is no bony lesion concerning for malignancy or infection.
summary: multifocal ground-glass opacities, worse in the upper zones, most compatible with multifocal pneumonia.hemorrhage can have a similar appearance.please correlate with symptoms.the examination is suboptimal for assessment of pulmonary emboli to the subsegmental levels, no large pe is detected.if there remains a high clinical concern for small emboli, a repeat cta could be considered.

text: pulmonary arteries enhance normally without filling defect to suggest embolus.the thoracic and upper abdominal aorta enhance normally without intimal flap or aneurysmal dilatation.there are small bilateral pleural effusions, slightly greater on the right with associated atelectasis.there is no ct evidence to suggest coexisting congestive heart failure or consolidation.no pneumothorax.incidental note is made of a low attenuation (15-20 hounsfield units) fluid collection in the prevascular space just lateral to the aortic arch which likely represents extension of a prominent pericardial recess.the aortic arch is otherwise sharp and there is no evidence to suggest aortic injury.no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes are seen within the axillary, mediastinal, or hilar distributions.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are unremarkable with the exception of mild coronary artery calcification.limited imaging through the upper abdomen demonstrates gallstones without ct evidence of cholecystitis.additionally, there is some nonspecific stranding and fluid adjacent to the left kidney of unclear clinical significance.no evidence to suggest hydronephrosis or pyelonephritis on the current study.incidental note is made of calcification at the takeoff of the proximal celiac artery.
summary: no pe or aortic dissection.small bilateral pleural effusions, without ct evidence of congestive heart failure.left renal calculus with small amount of nonspecific fluid and stranding lateral to the left kidney.ctu could be performed if concerned about obstructing ureteral stone.cholelithiasis.small hiatal hernia.

text: there is acute pulmonary embolism (3:30) seen within a egmental branch involving the right upper lobe.no additional areas of pulmonary artery filling defect are seen.the aorta is unremarkable with no evidence of aortic dissection.there is mild prominence of the main pulmonary artery measuring up to 3.3 cm suggesting a component of pulmonary hypertension.note is made of atherosclerotic calcification within the thoracic aorta.there is a moderate-sized pericardial effusion.there is no leftward bowing of the interventricular septum to suggest right heart strain.note is made of a small sized right pleural effusion.lung windows deomonstrate right basilar linear atelectasis.there are multiple areas of nodular opacification scattered throughout the lungs that are nonspecific, for example, within the left upper lobe, (3:6), the left upper lobe (3:15), the lingula (3:40), the right lower lobe (3:34), and the right upper lobe (3:23).the largest areas are seen within the right upper lobe (3:23) measuring approximately 10 mm and the lingula (3:40) measuring up to 13 mm.findings may be related to infectious or neoplastic (metastases) etiologies vs less likely inflammatory.there is no significant axillary, hilar or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.this examination is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic evaluation.there is nodularity of the liver contour.noted are large areas of ill-defined hypoattenuation within the liver particularly involving segment ___ and extending into at least segment viii, concerning for mass, incompletely evaluated.differential considerations include hepatocellular carcinoma or cholangiocarcinoma.findings are also suggestive of mild intrahepatic biliary dilatation.
summary: acute pulmonary embolism involving right upper lobe segmental branch.mild prominence of the main pulmonary artery suggests component of pulmonary artery hypertension.no evidence of right heart strain.widespread scattered pulmonary nodular opacities, nonspecific, could relate to infectious or neoplastic etiologies.given question of mass in the liver, as below if this is confirmed, findings would be worrisome for metatases.moderate-sized pericardial effusion.small right pleural effusion.large incompletely characterized regions of hypoattenuation in the liver.findings are concerning for neoplastic involvement (ie.hepatocellular or cholangiocarcioma).recommend dedicated imaging with liver mri or multiphasic ct for further evaluation.

text: there are no enlarged axillary lymph nodes.there are multiple nonenlarged mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes.a pacing wire is seen to terminate in the right ventricular apex.there is cardiomegaly with enlargement of the left atrium (6 cm ap dimension) and left ventricle.there are calcifications of the coronary arteries.there is no pericardial effusion.there is no pulmonary embolus.there is no mediastinal hematoma.the aorta has normal caliber throughout without areas of aneurysmal dilatation or dissection.there is no extravasation of iv contrast.atelectasis is seen within the lung bases, and there is also some respiratory motion.there is no focal consolidation.there is no effusion or pneumothorax.
summary: no aortic aneurysm or dissection.no pneumonia.scattered nonenlarged lymph nodes throughout the mesentery, but otherwise unremarkable appearance of the abdomen and imaged pelvis.

text: good contrast opacification of the pulmonary arteries allows to exclude the presence of pulmonary emboli in the central and segmental branches.there is no evidence of right heart strain or septal bulging.the aorta shows a diameter of 4.5 cm at the level of the ascending and arch part.the descending aorta has a diameter of 2.5 cm.no pericardial effusion, mild bilateral pleural effusions.small hiatal hernia.no evidence of contrast extravasation from the mediastinal vessels into the mediastinum.an aortic valve is in situ.small hiatal hernia.moderate coronary calcifications.lymph nodes of borderline size in the mediastinum.the lung parenchyma shows no evidence of recent infection.no suspicious pulmonary nodules.no evidence of inflammatory lung disease.no abnormalities in the upper abdomen.
summary: aortic valve in situ.no evidence of mediastinal or pericardial leakage of contrast material.no evidence of pulmonary embolism.moderate aortic and coronary calcifications.no pulmonary infection or malignancy.

text: the patient's known hepatic lesions are visualized, unchanged from the recent mri when allowing for the differences in technique and enhancement.a small solitary 16 mm in long axis, 10 mm in short axis lymph node is seen immediately anterior to the portal vein in the gastrohepatic ligament.no other lymphadenopathy.gallbladder, biliary tree, adrenal glands, kidneys, pancreas, visualized portion of the bowel and mesentery are unremarkable.there is a small left-sided pleural effusion and minimal atelectasis at the left lung base.the lungs are otherwise clear and incidental note is made of an azygous lobe which is a normal variant in the right upper lung.no mediastinal lymphadenopathy.no bony lesions to suggest a malignancy.
summary: small gastrohepatic ligament lymph node and the patient's known hepatic lesions as seen on recent mri.small left pleural effusion and minimal atelectasis at the left lung base.no other abnormality.specifically on this ct no finding is seen to suggest a primary source of malignancy to account for the hepatic lesions.

text: again noted is a loculated, heterogeneously attenuating left sided pleural effusion which contains gas.gas is likely related to the chest tube which courses through the lower thorax posteriorly.overall size is unchanged in the anteroapical portion of this collection, however the more inferior portions appear to have decreased in size in the interval since the present chest tube was inserted.the small right sided pleural effusion has nearly completely resolved in the interval.there are scattered areas of patchy opacity and atelectasis in both lungs.a tracheostomy tube is noted in situ.there is incidental note of multiple small gallstones.a g tube is also identified.
summary: overall improved appearance of hemorrhagic pleural effusion on the left with little to no change in the more apically positioned portion of the collection.after discussion with the referring surgical team decision not to drain the collection with a pig-tail catheter was made.surgical decortication will be performed if and when clinically indicated.

text: the thyroid gland is normal.atherosclerotic calcifications are noted in the aortic arch, descending thoracic aorta and the abdominal aorta.the aorta is otherwise normal in course and caliber.the heart is normal in size.coronary artery calcifications are seen.small 8-mm pretracheal node is identified.there is moderate-sized left pleural effusion with segmental atelectasis seen in the left lower lobe.the tracheobronchial tree is patent.the remainder of the lungs are clear.no evidence of pneumothorax.the study is not tailored for evaluation of the abdomen; however, the visualized liver, spleen and adrenal glands appear normal.the gallbladder is surgically absent.degenerative changes are seen in the thoracic spine.
summary: moderate-sized left pleural effusion with segmental atelectasis left lower lobe, otherwise patent tracheobronchial tree.the left hilum is normal.

text: the volume of a moderate layering left nonhemorrhagic pleural effusion is unchanged since ___.air was present in the left pleural space at that time, and the imaging of the upper chest shows a small to moderate volume of air, not necessarily any larger today, rising anteriorly and superiorly.the patient has had left upper lobectomy, and unless there has been the introduction of air to the left pleural space by a recent procedure, this raises concern for leak of the left upper lobe bronchial stump.emphysema is moderate to severe.irregular areas of opacification at both lung bases are more pronounced today than on ___ and there are similar areas in the upper lungs, particularly the right, suggestive of multifocal pneumonia, most commonly due to aspiration.aside from small amounts of mucus stranding in the trachea and right main bronchus, the tracheobronchial tree has a normal postoperative appearance.a small, discrete region of peribronchial infiltration in the right upper lobe has a suggestion of cavitation, 4:19, and an 8-mm wide ring shadow in the right middle lobe could be another cavity, 4:177.central lymph nodes are not pathologically enlarged.there is no right pleural or pericardial effusion.however, the intrapericardial right pulmonary artery, 27 mm, is mildly enlarged, and although this may be due in part to redirection of blood flow after the left upper lobectomy raises possibility of pulmonary hypertension.this examination is not designed for subdiaphragmatic diagnosis except to note the absence of adrenal mass and the presence of a 16-mm wide exophytic cyst at the upper pole of the left kidney adjacent to nodular thickening of the pararenal fascia.
summary: left hydropneumothorax raises concern for bronchial stump leak.no evidence of recurrent malignancy.multifocal pneumonia, probably aspiration.very small cavities in the right upper and middle lobe require followup.there is no evidence of active tuberculosis.severe emphysema.possible pulmonary arterial hypertension.

text: endotracheal tube is in place.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels are unremarkable.there is no pleural or pericardial effusion.central bronchi are patent to the subsegmental level.there are scattered mediastinal lymph nodes, but none meet ct criteria for pathologic enlargement.there is no axillary or hilar lymphadenopathy.thoracic aorta is normal in caliber and contour.there are minor atherosclerotic calcifications of the coronary arteries, aortic arch and descending aorta.lung windows demonstrate severe centrilobular emphysema, primarily affecting the lung apices.there is a large bulla medially in the right middle lobe.linear biapical densities are present.there is no focal consolidation or pulmonary nodule.there is moderate atelectasis, right greater than left, likely due to aspiration.
summary: no acute traumatic abnormality in the chest, abdomen or pelvis.severe centrilobular emphysema, most prominent at the lung apices.biapical linear densities most likely represent chronic scarring.however, no comparison imaging is available and lung neoplasm cannot be excluded.when the patient's identity becomes known, comparison to prior imaging to deomonstrate stability of these areas should be performed.if no prior imaging is available, followup chest ct in 3 months should be performed to determine stability.

text: there is hilar lymphadenopathy measuring on the right 2 cm width.further noted linear and nodular pattern predominantly at the upper lobes, more prominent on the right with some scarring of the lung tissue at the apex, findings are new as compared to the previous study and may be compatible with sarcoidosis.
summary: mild dilatation of ascending aorta measuring 3.9 cm.bilateral hilar adenopathy with nodular and linear pattern in the right upper lung fields may be consistent with sarcoidosis.further evaluation is warranted.

text: the pulmonary arterial vasculature is well contrast opacified and does not demonstrate filling defect to suggest the presence of pulmonary embolism.the heart, pericardium, and great vessels appear normal.there is no mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.the airways are patent to the subsegmental bronchi level.there are mild dependent atelectatic changes.no consolidations or pleural effusions are seen.images through the upper abdomen do not reveal acute pathology.the study is not designed for evaluation of abdominal organs.
summary: no evidence of pe, pneumonia or aortic dissection.mild atelectatic changes at the lung bases.

text: the study is compared with the most recent cect dated ___, performed for "___ hypoxia"; the current study is limited due to the timing of the contrast bolus.however, allowing for this limitation, there is relatively symmetric opacification of the main pulmonary arteries to the level of their segmental branches, with no "filling defect" to suggest central pulmonary embolism.noted is dilatation of the main pulmonary artery, measuring 3.7 cm diameter, likely representing pulmonary hypertension, perhaps secondary to the known osa; this finding appears to have progressed since the examination of ___.also incidentally noted is a prominent left superior intercostal vein draining into the accessory hemiazygos vein.the thoracic aorta is normal in caliber and contour and opacifies promptly and completely, with no finding to suggest aortic dissection.there is no mediastinal hemorrhage.there is no pericardial effusion.there is left lower lobe consolidation and collapse, particularly its posterior basal segment, new since the earlier study.however, there are numerous air bronchograms, and no evidence of central airway obstruction.otherwise, there is only subsegmental atelectasis involving the dependent portion of the right lower lobe.also noted are small bilateral pleural effusions, new.there is no pulmonary vascular congestion, ground-glass opacity or other evidence of chf.there is an endotracheal tube in situ with its tip roughly 3.3 cm proximal to the carina, in satisfactory position.there is an enteric tube in situ within the collapsed esophagus.there is no evidence of mediastinal, hilar or axillary lymphadenopathy.the abdominal viscera are essentially excluded from the study, with a grossly unremarkable appearance to the limited included portion of the splenic dome.
summary: study somewhat limited by poor contrast bolus timing, with: 1.no evidence of central pulmonary embolus to the level of the segmental pulmonary arteries.2.dilatation of the main pulmonary artery, which appears to have progressed since ___ and likely reflects pulmonary hypertension secondary to the patient's known obstructive sleep apnea.3.no evidence of thoracic aortic dissection.4.left lower lobe, particularly posterior basal segmental, consolidation and collapse, with no definite evidence of airway obstruction; a pneumonic process is a consideration.5.cardiomegaly with small bilateral pleural effusions but no pulmonary edema.

text: chest ct: a large bore dialysis catheter from the left internal jugular approach and a right subclavian approach central line are evident with the distal tips in the right atrium and at the cavoatrial junction, respectively.there is mediastinal lipomatosis presumably from prior steroid use.the aorta is normal in caliber, course, and contour.there is a diminutive left vertebral artery arising directly from the aortic arch.this is a right vertebral artery dominant system.the pulmonary artery is normal in size.the heart is mildly enlarged with a left ventricular predominance.there is a small amount of pericardial effusion, particularly at the heart apex.no adenopathy is present in the chest.minimal respiratory motion degrades evaluation of the most distal subsegmental branches of the pulmonary arterial circuit.within that limitation, no pulmonary embolism is identified.inward bowing of the posterior membrane of the trachea reflects expiratory phase imaging.no endobronchial lesion is identified and the airway is grossly patent to the segmental bronchiole level.there is atelectasis in the dependent aspects of both lungs, left slightly worse than right.small bilateral pleural effusions are evident.there is no focal consolidation to suggest underlying pneumonia.no pulmonary edema is seen.
summary: no pulmonary embolism or aortic pathology noted.minimal bibasilar atelectasis left worse than right with small bilateral pleural effusions.ct findings consistent with aggressive fluid resuscitation.questionable bowel wall thickening involving the cecum, ascending colon, and proximal transverse colon.diagnostic considerations include pseudomembranous colitis, typhlitis (if immunocompromised), further sequela of fluid resuscitation, and much less likely ischemia.internal fluid within the colon highly suggestive of diarrhea.no intra-abdominal abscess.explanted kidney transplant site unremarkable.results of the study were reviewed with dr.___ shortly after acquisition of the examination.a detailed wet read was entered into pacs by oncall radiologist, dr.___ shortly after acquisition.

text: heavy atherosclerotic calcifications are seen in the thoracic aorta and coronary arteries.there is a left-sided pacemaker with leads in the right atrium and the right ventricle.the pulmonary arteries are normal in caliber.there is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.the ascending aorta is mildly aneurysmal and measures approximately 4.4 cm in greatest diameter.this is not significantly changed since the prior study.as before, note is made of an exophytic aneurysm arising from the aortic arch just distal to the left subclavian takeoff.location of the pseudoaneurysm favors traumatic rather than mycotic etiology.the pseudoaneurysm is partially thrombosed.however, the pseudoaneurysm appears to have slightly increased in size since the prior study and now measures 4.3 x 3.8 cm in the axial plane ( previously 3.6 x 3.9 cm.the descending thoracic aorta is stable in size and measures approximately 2.0 x 2.8 cm.there has been interval progression in esophageal dilatation.the esophagus now measures approximately 2.0 cm in maximum diameter (previously 2.4 cm.large amount of fluid and debris is seen within the esophagus.evaluation of the lung windows demonstrates a spiculated density in the right lung apex which is unchanged since the prior study and may represent an area of scarring.there is a patchy area of consolidation in the posterior aspect of the right lower lobe which may reflect atelectasis.however, an element of aspiration pneumonia cannot be excluded.there are no pleural effusions.there is enlargement and heterogeneity of the right thyroid lobe, stable since the prior study.
summary: interval increase in size of pseudoaneurysm interval increase in distension and dilatation of the esophagus which now contains large amount of fluid and debris to the level of the thoracic inlet.3.patchy consolidation in the right lower lobe which may reflect atelectasis.however, underlying aspiration pneumonia cannot be excluded.findings were discussed with dr.___ at 3 p.m.on ___.

text: there are bilateral emphysematous changes.there are no pulmonary nodules.within the superior right chest subcutaneous tissues is a 7-mm soft tissue nodule, which could represent a sebaceous cyst.the heart is normal.the airways are patent to the level of the subsegmental bronchi bilaterally.there are coronary artery calcifications as well as atherosclerotic calcification of the aorta.there are small subcentimeter pretracheal and prevascular lymph nodes, measuring up to 7 mm.there are no pathologically enlarged axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymph nodes.

text: no evidence of aortic dissection.no pericardial effusion.no pneumothorax is identified.there are bilateral predominantly posterior areas of dense opacification of the lung parenchyma with other scattered areas of opacity including a linear opacity in the left upper lobe and multiple ill-defined areas of ground-glass opacity.no central obstructing lesions are seen.

text: study was not optimally timed to evaluate the pulmonary arteries, however allowing for this, there is no central pulmonary embolus.the subsegmental branches are not well evaluated.there is upper lobe emphysema.several large bullae in the right upper lobe.there are ill-defined alveolar and ground-glass opacities most prominent in the right lower lobe, but also in the left lower lobe and lingula which may relate to aspiration or multifocal pneumonia.borderline tracheomalacia.the esophagus is moderately dilated.

text: there are prominent lymph nodes within the prevascular and precarinal regions, increased in bulk since the previous exam.the largest of these is prevascular and measures 9 mm in greatest short-axis dimension.there is a new tracheostomy tube.there has been interval increase in size of bilateral pleural effusions, now moderate on the left and small on the right.patchy bilateral parenchymal densities persist, somewhat more confluent in some areas than on the prior study.there is no pericardial effusion.ng tube is present.

text: there is paraseptal and diffuse emphysematous change involving both lung fields, unchanged.there is mild coronary artery calcification, also unchanged.there is no hilar, mediastinal or axillary significant adenopathy.there is a focus of pleural parenchymal scarring at the left lung base, unchanged from ___.no parenchymal suspicious lesions are appreciated.

text: there is no pulmonary artery filling defects to suggest pulmonary embolism.additionally, there are no secondary signs of embolism including no evidence of right-sided heart strain.there is no pericardial or pleural effusion.aorta is normal in caliber without dissection.no pathologically enlarged axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymph nodes are observed.bilateral hypodense thyroid nodules, some of which are partially calcified, are again noted.esophageal varices persist.a small amount of peribronchial tree-in-___ opacity is noted in the superior segment of the right lower lobe (2:23).bandlike atelectasis is present in the right middle lobe.the airways are patent to the subsegmental level bilaterally.
summary: no pulmonary embolism.increase in size of multiple intrahepatic bilomas, several of which appear to rim enhance consistent with superinfection.apparent occlusion of the indwelling biliary stents is again associated.moderate ascites.marked gastric distension warrants decompression.a small amount of tree-in-___ opacity in the right lower lobe may represent small airways disease/infection.

text: ct of the abdomen.
summary: mildly dilated loops of small bowel, suggestive of partial small bowel obstruction.interval development of patchy lower lobe and focal right lobe opacities that may represent infectious or inflammatory process.interval improved aeration of both lungs and diminished bilateral pleural effusions.stable left diaphragmatic hernia.stable complex pericardial effusion.residual pulmonary artery embolus.stable, extensive ascites.polycystic kidney and liver disease.persistent left femoral vein thrombosis at site of central venous catheter.

text: there are significant vascular calcifications including ubiquitous coronary artery calcifications involving the left anterior descending, circumflex and right coronary artery.central airways are patent to the level of subsegmental bronchi.there are large bilateral pleural effusions with associated relaxation atelectasis.there is no central pulmonary embolus.there is no aortic dissection.there is no pronounced bowing of the intraventricular septum to suggest increased right ventricular pressures.tracheostomy tube is seen with tip terminating above the carina with a small amount of air at the instertion site.median sternotomy wire are seen.there is no pathologic axillary or mediastinal lymphadenopathy.in the visualized abdomen there is pneumoperitoneum that may be secondary to recent peg placement.there is moderate ascites.artifact limits the scan but the visualized liver, stomach and spleen appear unremarkable.
